Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: The Italian budget for 2019 that the European Commission rejected in October would have increased Italy’s risk of fiscal insolvency substantially.
Comment: A few basis points don't matter for a debt that stands at 130% of GDP. The problem is about unfunded liabilities.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question C: If France runs a 2019 budget deficit of around 3.4% of GDP, as announced by President Macron’s government, France’s risk of fiscal insolvency will increase substantially.
Comment: Same observation as for Italy.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: Capping the number of ride-sharing drivers as is being discussed in New York City, Chicago and London will make the average resident in that city worse off.
Comment: Some (those who don't use ride-sharing will benefit, others will lose.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext:
Question B:
To achieve a given level of congestion, it would be better to use taxes for driving that vary based on the level of congestion, rather than limiting the number of ride-sharing vehicles.
Comment: Can it be done well?

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: People who migrated to Europe between 2015 and 2018 are likely — over the next two decades — to contribute more in taxes paid than they receive in benefits and public services.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Ideas are nonrival, so increasing returns to scale is an essential feature of technological change in a market economy.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Voters overestimate the effect that current governments have on their economies’ concurrent economic performance.
Comment: In general, governments take small steps. But at crisis time, management capability is crucial. And in good time, silly governments...

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Over the next decade, autonomous cars will raise average welfare in the EU by at least as much as smartphones have over the past decade.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext:
Britain’s Labour party recently proposed giving the Bank of England a target of 3% annual labor productivity growth. Consider the following statement:
Central banks cannot significantly increase productivity growth over a ten year horizon, except perhaps by promoting macroeconomic stability.
Comment: Myriads of attempts to use central banks to boost growth have ended up in failure. Why can't people learn from the past?

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext:
Question A: The European Commission has proposed new rules to ensure that “digital business activities are taxed in a fair and growth-friendly way in the EU”. Consider two statements regarding this proposal:
An EU-wide 3% tax on revenue from digital activities would, on balance, be a good idea.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext:
Question B:
If the EU decides to tax digital service providers, it would be better — given the difficulties of measuring and verifying digital activity — to tax them on the revenue, rather than the profits, that they generate locally.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: The European Union often uses its antitrust powers to protect EU-based firms from international competition, rather than to promote greater competition in European markets.
Comment: Anti-trust is pro-competition but its use can be distorted for protectionist aims.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: Trade with China makes most Europeans better off because, among other advantages, they can buy goods that are made or assembled more cheaply in China.
Comment: No brainer

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: Some Europeans who work in the production of competing goods, such as clothing and furniture, are made worse off by trade with China.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question C: If the EU followed the new US steel tariffs by imposing similar EU tariffs on steel from China, it would improve Europeans’ welfare.
Comment: China would retaliate. It would worsen the trend toward global protectionism.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: Assuming it exits its third bailout program this summer without an immediate restructuring or other debt relief, Greece is unlikely to default on its sovereign debt in the coming decade.
Comment: Most serious studies find that the Greek debt is unlikely to be sustainable.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: Greece would be better off if it had decided to exit the euro between 2011 and 2015.
Comment: You don't exit the euro for a few years and then come back. If you exit, you're out, maybe better off in the medium run.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question C: If Greece had defaulted on (or restructured) its private debt in 2010, while also staying within the euro, that combination would have been better for Greece than either exiting the euro or proceeding as it has actually done.
Comment:
Barry Eichengreen and I tell the story, see the URL.
-see background information here

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to currency.
Comment: Bitcoins are a parallel currency, with no intrinsic value, very different from gold. But the supply is limited, like gold.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to Dutch tulips in the 1630s.
Comment: Tulips were subject to a bubble, which also applies to bitcoins, and occasionally to gold.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext:
The US spends roughly 17% of GDP on healthcare, according to the OECD; most European countries spend less than 12% of GDP.

Higher quality-adjusted US healthcare prices contribute relatively more to the extra US spending than does the combination of higher quantity and quality of US care (interpreting quantity and quality to reflect both greater American healthcare needs due to underlying population health and the delivery of more or better healthcare services to Americans).

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Over the past two years, all else equal, the appeal of the US as a destination for immigrants has changed in ways that will likely decrease innovation in the US economy.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: Holding other policies fixed, the average European would be better off if every European country taxed corporate profits at a rate of 20% (based as closely as possible on a common definition of profits).
Comment: Yes but the implied loss of tax revenue should be compensated by either less distortionary taxes or by inefficient spending cuts.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: If other policies were held fixed and every European country taxed corporate profits at a common rate of 20%, then reducing that common rate substantially below 20% would make the average European better off.
Comment: It may be difficult to make up for too large revenue losses.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, if corporations throughout Europe set quotas for a minimum number of women board members, the shareholder value of European companies would increase.
Comment: Diversity is good, but not sure that the impact will be significant.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: Taking into account the likely effects on investments in human capital by men and women, setting quotas throughout Europe for a minimum number of women board members would generate substantial net benefits for Europeans.
Comment: In the long run, removing discrimination can only be good. But how good?

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: Subsidizing renewable energy sources is better than taxing fossil fuels, assuming the subsidy or tax would be set at levels that would reduce carbon emissions by an equivalent amount.
Comment: These are equivalent measures, except that the first one raises the tax burden while the second one reduces it ceteris paribus.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: Germany’s solar-energy subsidies to date have produced net social benefits for Germany.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question C: Solar-energy subsidies to date in Germany and other countries have produced net social benefits for the world.
Comment: The rest of the world stands to benefit from less toxic emissions in Germany at German taxpayer's expense.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Insights from psychology about individual behavior – examples of which include limited rationality, low self-control, or a taste for fairness – predict several important types of observed market outcomes that fully-rational economic models do not.
Comment: I don't know enough

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: The influx of refugees into Germany beginning in the summer of 2015 will generate net economic benefits for German citizens over the succeeding decade.
Comment: This is a big plus given a sharply negative natural demography, but... Absorbing this population will be long and costly.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: Holding labor market institutions and job training fixed, rising use of robots and artificial intelligence is likely to increase substantially the number of workers in advanced countries who are unemployed for long periods.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: Rising use of robots and artificial intelligence in advanced countries is likely to create benefits large enough that they could be used to compensate those workers who are substantially negatively affected for their lost wages.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: Consumers will be better off, on balance, if European cities treat firms that provide ride-sharing platforms (such as Uber) as substantively different from taxi firms, and thus not necessarily warranting the same regulation.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: Assuming that taxi and ride-sharing companies were treated as substantively similar — including requirements that they operate on an equal footing regarding safety, insurance and taxation — letting ride-sharing services compete without restrictions on prices or routes would raise consumer welfare.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question C: Regardless of how ride-sharing services are treated, existing regulations for traditional taxi firms in many European cities harm consumers by limiting competition.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: Revising France’s labor market policies — by reducing employment protection, decentralizing labor negotiations to the firm level, and making training programs more accessible and responsive to labor demands — would, all else equal, increase productivity in France’s economy.
Comment: So far high direct and indirect labor costs have forced firms to achieve very high labor productivity through saving on employment.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: Reducing employment protection would reduce the equilibrium unemployment rate in France.
Comment: No brainer

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: The ECB's asset purchases over the past two years have reduced the threat of deflation in the euro area as a whole.
Comment: This is what comes from empirical studies, but SD are often large.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: If the economic outlook in the euro area becomes less favorable, then increasing the ECB's asset purchase program (in size or duration) would substantially increase the euro area's economic growth over the following five years.
Comment: Available assets are getting scarce.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: In general, absent any inside information, an equity investor can expect to do better by holding a well-diversified, low-fee, passive index fund than by holding a few stocks.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: Without changes in policy, a rising share of people who are over age 65 will exert a substantial downward influence on per capita real GDP in western European countries.
Comment: Mechanically, this seems true on both the demand and supply side. But many things may go in the other direction.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: In European countries where the share of those over 65 is rising, there are net social benefits to adjusting retirement ages for state-financed (including pay-as-you-go) pension systems upwards, so that revised retirement ages better reflect longer life expectancies.
Comment: Either this or reduced pensions.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, there are substantial advantages to having much of Europe’s human capital and infrastructure for international financial activity clustered in a single city, as they are at present in London.
Comment: We need to balance the benefits from local networks with the consequences of Brexit.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: All else equal, Britain’s rules on hiring, firing and working hours are significantly more conducive to financial activity than those in other large European countries.
Comment: One should add the prejudices against finance and wealth that permeate the continent.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: Setting the EU rules aside, and assuming it would take 2.5% of Italy’s GDP to recapitalize its banks, the Italian government would improve financial stability in Europe if it injected this amount of public funds into its banks.
Comment: A number of Italian banks need to be recapitalized. If it cannot be done otherwise, the government must step in.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: If Italy were to inject public funds into its banks without imposing losses on at least some claimants, an important cost would be the effect on future incentives (economic or political) in Europe.
Comment: We have adopted bail-in rules. Ditching them aside would indeed send a terrible signal. But the rules need to be better thought through.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: On the whole, the shift from state to private ownership of many industrial assets in central and eastern European countries after communism has increased productivity in those countries.
Comment: With rare exceptions, firms were highly inefficient beforehand. In some countries, private firms remain uncompetitive because of corruption.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: You see European people everywhere at work or in retirement.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: I can't remember studies on that issue. My intuition is that low skilled workers moved to services where they benefit from complementarities

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: Much evidence on more competition, economies of scale and of scope.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: Usual RIcardian redistribution as many firms have closed down. Many people recovered but some did not.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: In general, using more congestion charges in crowded transportation networks — such as higher tolls during peak travel times in cities, and peak fees for airplane takeoff and landing slots — and using the proceeds to lower other taxes would make citizens on average better off.
Comment: "On average" is crucial because these measures have income redistribution effects that hurt some and benefit others.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: Giving tax incentives to specific firms to locate operations in a country typically generates domestic benefits that outweigh the costs to the country providing the incentives.
Comment: Ireland says it all.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: Europe as a whole benefits when European cities or countries compete with each other by giving tax incentives to firms to locate operations in their jurisdictions.
Comment: Tax competition is a Nash game that stands to hurt every one. But, gIven high tax rates in Europe, tax competition keeps the lid on.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question A: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the UK's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: We do not know yet what will be the outcome of the negotiations. If Brexit occurs and is messed up, then it will hurt the UK.

Name: Charles Wyplosz
Qtext: Question B: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the rest of the EU's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment:
The UK is not that important for the EU for trade. What matters is that the UK was a reasonable voice among often confused leaders.
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Germany's current account surplus is undesirable even from a purely German viewpoint: the country would be better off if, for example, it ran a smaller primary surplus, in turn leading to a smaller current account surplus.
Comment:
Depends on sources of surplus for which no consensus. Yet agree GER should spend more on public R&D, incentives for private inv. &tax reform
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: The Eurozone would be in better shape if fiscal policy were more expansionary, which would allow monetary policy to be slightly less so.
Comment:
Again, depends on what money is spend on. Structural reform. Neg rates do not seem to work. In US, subsidies to banks seem to work better
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question C: If there is a recession in the Eurozone, it will be essential to have a coordinated fiscal expansion.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: The European Union goal of reaching net zero emissions of greenhouse gases by 2050 will be a major drag on economic growth.
Comment: Likely a drag but hard to know how large. Goals have consequences for competitiveness & require large investments.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Carbon taxes are a better way to implement climate policy than cap-and-trade.
Comment:
Tax has some advantages (link), but no clear dominance. Cap&trade may be politically easier to implement. Either one better than status quo.
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question C: A carbon border tax targeting imports from non-EU countries with less strict climate policies is likely to harm developing economies.
Comment: It hurts exports of some countries with high carbon use in production but could complement policies in EU if we lack global solution.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Following the UK election result, the certainty that the country is going to leave the European Union will provide a substantial short-term boost to the UK economy.
Comment: Uncertainty resolution is positive, but it made Brexit near certainty. So bump might not be large. Still huge uncertainty about trade deal.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Given that the transition period currently expires at the end of 2020, there is still a considerable risk that the UK will leave the European Union without a trade agreement.
Comment: Especially if BJ introduces bill that prevents extension beyond 2020.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question C: Leaving the European Union without a trade agreement would have a large negative impact on the UK economy.
Comment: BoJo aims for Canada-style FTA w/o alignment, so services not covered. Thus, even w/ such trade agreement likely negative impact from Brexit

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Under current policies on climate change, the associated physical risks (such as those arising from total seasonal rainfall and sea level changes, and increased frequency, severity, and correlation of extreme weather events) will be at most a very small factor in monetary policy decisions over the next decade.
Comment:
Climate change can certainly create supply shocks that are relevant to monetary policy. Hard to know how large these shocks might be.
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: The physical risks associated with climate change under current policies are likely to threaten financial stability over the next decade.
Comment: Agree climate change can pose systemic risks. But don't know how likely. There are huge time lags in (nonlinear) physical climate responses.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public R&D spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private R&D spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.
Comment:
Key Q: Is public RD complement or substitute? Evidence weakly favors former, esp @ higher aggregation & more general invstm. Not conclusive.
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public medical research spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private medical research spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.
Comment:
Again, evidence tends to favor complementarity, but difficult to measure. Complementarity appears stronger for basic research.
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for answering some long unsettled questions in development economics research.
Comment: Clearly an important tool not only in development. Work by 3 Nobel Laureates has demonstrated this for dev. But also not the only one.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for making significant progress in poverty reduction.
Comment: Pov reduct is complicated process involving mkts, institutions & politics. RCT can help but need many tools, incl. theory, for sign. reduct.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Having companies run to maximize shareholder value creates significant negative externalities for workers and communities.
Comment:
Co should max sh welfare not value. Even Milton F recognized these externalities, need laws & ethics as constraints & perhaps stronger ones.
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Appropriately managed corporations could create significantly greater value than they currently do for a range of stakeholders – including workers, suppliers, customers and community members – with small impacts on shareholder value.
Comment:
Unlikely as implies corp leave lots money on table or managers extract huge rents; yet maximizing stakeh. welfare could address externalit.
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext:
Question C:
Effective mechanisms for boards of directors to ensure that CEOs act in ways that balance the interests of all stakeholders would be straightforward to introduce.
Comment:
It would clearly be difficult but this does not imply that one should not try. There are many difficult governance problems.
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Rising inequality is straining the health of liberal democracy.
Comment:
Feels that way @moment. Theories to support; evidence less clear. Also argument: greater econ. inequality -> greater political inequality
-see background information here
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Enacting more redistributive expenditures and policies would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe.
Comment:
If link in A) is true & policies successful in limiting inequality, then agree. But evidence for link in A) is tenuous.
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question C: European governments should allocate more resources to policies that would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe, even if it means higher public debt or lower public spending in other areas.
Comment: While limiting extreme populism likely good, focus should be on inequality& its neg effects. Populism can be exercise of democratic rights.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: At this point, there is little that the European Central Bank can do to increase or maintain output in the Eurozone.
Comment: The ECB has bought countries and EU considerable time for structural reforms, but its measures also eased pressures for necessary reforms.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: When the economy is operating below its potential, larger fiscal deficits are likely to increase demand and output.
Comment: Depends also on time horizon over which outcome is considered.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question C: When the economy is operating below its potential and monetary policy is at the effective lower bound, fiscal policy should prioritize increasing output over decreasing public debt.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Selecting candidates for membership of the ECB Executive Board based primarily on nationality ahead of competence is likely to have a negative effect on the quality of monetary policy in the Eurozone.
Comment: Constraining the choice set should have weakly negative effects.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Although the central bank can never be an entirely technocratic institution, the selection process for the ECB President and members of the Executive Board is significantly worsened by intergovernmental trade-offs involving appointments to other European institutions.
Comment: Again hard to see how such trade offs should not have weakly negative effects. But not sure that it is significantly negative.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: On bids for infrastructure projects, the average European would be better off if Europe’s governments favored European firms over Chinese firms (or firms from any other country with non-profit-related geopolitical strategies) — even if it means sometimes choosing a higher-cost bidder.
Comment: Depends on reason. Protectionism clearly bad for consumers. But if a bid is skewed due to other motives, then costs not only consideration.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Breaking the “doom loop” — a negative spiral that can result when banks hold sovereign bonds and governments bail out banks — would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.
Comment:
Substantial evidence for doom loop and its effect on financial stability as well as that banks’ sovereign holdings are source of instability
-see background information here
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Regulators should try to break the doom loop by assigning positive risk weights — in calculating banks’ capital requirements — to banks’ holdings of domestic and other Eurozone sovereign bonds.
Comment:
Positive weights would be one way to reduce incentives to hold sovereign bonds, but not clear it is the best way to break doom loop. Limits?
-see background information here
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question C: Breaking the doom loop would impose substantial costs on powerful political constituencies.
Comment:
Likely but only indirect evidence based on governments' resistance to potential solutions
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Residents of big European cities would be better off, on balance, if governments did more to counter gentrification, for example by using rent and other housing subsidies, public housing investments, zoning regulations, or similar policies.
Comment:
Concerned about gentrification, but not much evidence on benefits of policies to counter it; have evidence policies have non-trivial costs.
-see background information here
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.
Comment:
In principle effect of DI in crisis is clear, but for EU DI much depends on implementation and harmonization. EU has mixed record on that.
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the likelihood of another financial crisis in Europe.
Comment:
Clear tradeoff w/ ex ante moral hazard. Evidence supports this & some suggests ex ante effect dominates but much depends on supervision.
-see background information here
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Overall, public spending on the arts in Europe creates benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.
Comment:
Often public good arg & WTP thru taxes can be high, but pos external & dw loss hard to measure. Complicated distributional& pol. econ consid
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Additional public spending on the arts in Europe would create incremental benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.
Comment:
Less likely than A, but still unclear. Some evidence that spending is opportunistic by politicians but also used to attract human capital.
-see background information here
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: The average European is better off if Europe’s competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.
Comment: Step in wrong direction; comp laws don't prevent mergers w/ strong econ rationale; if anything, we need stronger comp enforcemt

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: If China and other countries use policies that create giant international firms, then the average European is better off if Europe's competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.
Comment: Other legal&political ways to address unfair competition; Would we weaken EU IP laws just because other countries don't have/enforce them?

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Letting publicly traded European firms report earnings annually rather than quarterly would lead their executives to place more weight on long-term issues in their investments and other decisions.
Comment:
Conceivable, but evidence is quite mixed. Recent studies for Singapore&UK say no. Some studies show more emphasis on acc numbers w/ Q report
-see background information here
-see background information here
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: A switch from quarterly to annual earnings reports would, on net, benefit shareholders of European firms.
Comment:
Even w/ neg on invest, there are offsets. Q rep increases liquidity in secondary mkts&improves monitoring. Quite a few benefits from Q rep.
-see background information here
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: To the extent that public corporations pursue social and environmental initiatives, they tend to achieve higher risk-adjusted (private) returns than otherwise similar corporations that pursue such initiatives less.
Comment:
Evidence on doing well by doing good mixed. Metastudy finds small pos. association btw corp social & financial performance;tricky estimation
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: To the extent that Norway’s global government pension fund makes investments for social and environmental objectives — apart from investments that would bring the highest expected risk-adjusted returns — it improves the welfare of Norwegians.
Comment: Depends on non-classical&non-monetary preferences of Norwegians. Possible but hard to know. Note also global fund invests outside of Norway.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: The fiscal rules of the European Union should give more flexibility to member countries.
Comment: Flex good to avoid pro-cyclical tightening but issue is time inconsistency&incentives. Adopt bounds for deficits that depend on cycle in EU?

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: The Italian budget for 2019 that the European Commission rejected in October would have increased Italy’s risk of fiscal insolvency substantially.
Comment: Deficit was not much above rules, but debt is high & spreads reacted accordingly. Bigger issue may have been budget broke earlier promises.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question C: If France runs a 2019 budget deficit of around 3.4% of GDP, as announced by President Macron’s government, France’s risk of fiscal insolvency will increase substantially.
Comment: Absolute level still low, but rel. increase in spreads is substantial. Main concern is that reason for larger deficit is inability to reform

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Capping the number of ride-sharing drivers as is being discussed in New York City, Chicago and London will make the average resident in that city worse off.
Comment: Consumers benefit from lower prices due to ride sharing competition, but drivers' income and congestion are offsetting considerations

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext:
Question B:
To achieve a given level of congestion, it would be better to use taxes for driving that vary based on the level of congestion, rather than limiting the number of ride-sharing vehicles.
Comment: Tax finer instrument but should apply to all cars; w/ cap drivers stay longer on road. Cong pricing more efficient but distributional effect

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: People who migrated to Europe between 2015 and 2018 are likely — over the next two decades — to contribute more in taxes paid than they receive in benefits and public services.
Comment:
Too early to tell. Labor mkt outcomes often worse for long time. Demographics are plus. Much depends on fast integration into lab mkt.
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Ideas are nonrival, so increasing returns to scale is an essential feature of technological change in a market economy.
Comment: Non-rivalry gives rise to increasing returns to scale; most ideas are non-rival (unless protected) and central to technological change.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Voters overestimate the effect that current governments have on their economies’ concurrent economic performance.
Comment:
There is evidence for link between voting choice & current/past econ performance, but link is weaker than conventional wisdom may suggest.
-see background information here
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Over the next decade, autonomous cars will raise average welfare in the EU by at least as much as smartphones have over the past decade.
Comment: A.cars reduce opp. cost & productivity, but impact could take longer. Relat magnitude unclear. Sm phone hard to assess, so many apps & uses

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext:
Britain’s Labour party recently proposed giving the Bank of England a target of 3% annual labor productivity growth. Consider the following statement:
Central banks cannot significantly increase productivity growth over a ten year horizon, except perhaps by promoting macroeconomic stability.
Comment: Traditional CB tools don't directly affect productivity. Indirect effects via demand conceivable, but not clear how large&persistent.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext:
Question A: The European Commission has proposed new rules to ensure that “digital business activities are taxed in a fair and growth-friendly way in the EU”. Consider two statements regarding this proposal:
An EU-wide 3% tax on revenue from digital activities would, on balance, be a good idea.
Comment: Good idea to put the topic on agenda, but costs and benefits are quite uncertain at this point. Revenue generated is small given exemptions

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext:
Question B:
If the EU decides to tax digital service providers, it would be better — given the difficulties of measuring and verifying digital activity — to tax them on the revenue, rather than the profits, that they generate locally.
Comment: I agree local profits for digital are very difficult to determine, easy to shift & taxing consumption could make sense. But much uncertain.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: The European Union often uses its antitrust powers to protect EU-based firms from international competition, rather than to promote greater competition in European markets.
Comment:
Little hard evidence to support protectionism for mergers or fines. Could be in other areas&we lack similar EU tech firms as counterfactuals
-see background information here
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Trade with China makes most Europeans better off because, among other advantages, they can buy goods that are made or assembled more cheaply in China.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Some Europeans who work in the production of competing goods, such as clothing and furniture, are made worse off by trade with China.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question C: If the EU followed the new US steel tariffs by imposing similar EU tariffs on steel from China, it would improve Europeans’ welfare.
Comment: Small group might benefit from tariffs, but most are hurt. Overall costs outweigh benefits considering how widely steel is used in economy.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Assuming it exits its third bailout program this summer without an immediate restructuring or other debt relief, Greece is unlikely to default on its sovereign debt in the coming decade.
Comment: Very hard to predict. Much depends on continued structural reforms & if there is a major shock to world economy. Not much room for error.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Greece would be better off if it had decided to exit the euro between 2011 and 2015.
Comment:
Exit restores competitiveness, but would have led to default on euro liab thereafter would have been little political will to help Greece.
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question C: If Greece had defaulted on (or restructured) its private debt in 2010, while also staying within the euro, that combination would have been better for Greece than either exiting the euro or proceeding as it has actually done.
Comment:
Default w/ liquidity for GR/EU banking system & money for structural reform would have been better than giving money to creditors. See oped.
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to currency.
Comment:
Bitcoin is neither close to gold nor to a currency. Studies show that its asset prices so far do not behave like gold or other currencies.
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to Dutch tulips in the 1630s.
Comment: Investors might be speculating on bitcoins being used in some future application, but there are many competitors or alternatives.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext:
The US spends roughly 17% of GDP on healthcare, according to the OECD; most European countries spend less than 12% of GDP.

Higher quality-adjusted US healthcare prices contribute relatively more to the extra US spending than does the combination of higher quantity and quality of US care (interpreting quantity and quality to reflect both greater American healthcare needs due to underlying population health and the delivery of more or better healthcare services to Americans).
Comment:
Lots evidence: It's not quantity; price is main&biggest factor; only Q is whether care intensity (the other big driver) is quality or price.
-see background information here
-see background information here
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Over the past two years, all else equal, the appeal of the US as a destination for immigrants has changed in ways that will likely decrease innovation in the US economy.
Comment: Will have neg impact on US human capital, which has tight link to innovation. Magnitude less clear. Impact seen in applications for MBA prgs

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Holding other policies fixed, the average European would be better off if every European country taxed corporate profits at a rate of 20% (based as closely as possible on a common definition of profits).
Comment:
Weakly agree but case in EU not clear cut (see link). Only effective if base harmonized too. Tricky Q as ctries like IRE need big adjustment
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: If other policies were held fixed and every European country taxed corporate profits at a common rate of 20%, then reducing that common rate substantially below 20% would make the average European better off.
Comment:
Benefits are uncertain & concerns about effect on inequality, esp if policies are fixed & govnmts cannot compensate for inequality effects
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, if corporations throughout Europe set quotas for a minimum number of women board members, the shareholder value of European companies would increase.
Comment:
In short run, evidence suggests negative effects likely bc supply of qualified women is not yet large enough. Not much evidence on long-run.
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Taking into account the likely effects on investments in human capital by men and women, setting quotas throughout Europe for a minimum number of women board members would generate substantial net benefits for Europeans.
Comment: Even if effects on firm value were negative, could still make sense for society to do it. But GE & long run effects are very hard to judge.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Subsidizing renewable energy sources is better than taxing fossil fuels, assuming the subsidy or tax would be set at levels that would reduce carbon emissions by an equivalent amount.
Comment: CO2 tax better than either one; Subs require govmnt to pick energy source & hard to justify unless spur innovation w/ large spillovers.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Germany’s solar-energy subsidies to date have produced net social benefits for Germany.
Comment:
Wide range of estimates&benefits abroad; FiT&output sub often expensive; wind did better. Maybe offsetting benefits w/ energy independence
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question C: Solar-energy subsidies to date in Germany and other countries have produced net social benefits for the world.
Comment:
Subs spurred tech dev & adoption that w’d not have occurred as quickly; also evidence of tech spillovers but size unclear yet crucial to Q.
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Insights from psychology about individual behavior – examples of which include limited rationality, low self-control, or a taste for fairness – predict several important types of observed market outcomes that fully-rational economic models do not.
Comment: Tend to agree, but depends on setting & details. Often traditional models can be extended to explain as well. Point is not always to predict

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: The influx of refugees into Germany beginning in the summer of 2015 will generate net economic benefits for German citizens over the succeeding decade.
Comment:
Agree for migrants,esp w/ low birth rate as DE. Less clear w/ large ref influx. Key is quick right to work&access to education. DE too rigid
-see background information here
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Holding labor market institutions and job training fixed, rising use of robots and artificial intelligence is likely to increase substantially the number of workers in advanced countries who are unemployed for long periods.
Comment:
History&prior evidence disagree. Some job polarization&lots of complementarity. Could AI&robots be different? Yes, but so far very uncertain
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Rising use of robots and artificial intelligence in advanced countries is likely to create benefits large enough that they could be used to compensate those workers who are substantially negatively affected for their lost wages.
Comment: Assuming firms generally make tech investments when NPV positive, gains should be large enough. But not clear that the transfers take place.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Consumers will be better off, on balance, if European cities treat firms that provide ride-sharing platforms (such as Uber) as substantively different from taxi firms, and thus not necessarily warranting the same regulation.
Comment: Uber is more than info society service as it sets price&driver pay, so treating as transport w/minimum quality reg makes sense.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Assuming that taxi and ride-sharing companies were treated as substantively similar — including requirements that they operate on an equal footing regarding safety, insurance and taxation — letting ride-sharing services compete without restrictions on prices or routes would raise consumer welfare.
Comment:
Classic concerns about open entry mitigated with online platforms. Not letting them compete on equal footing likely violates EU law.
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question C: Regardless of how ride-sharing services are treated, existing regulations for traditional taxi firms in many European cities harm consumers by limiting competition.
Comment: Entry regulation mostly harmful. But there clearly is a case for (minimum) quality regulation, though some quality competition can be good.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Revising France’s labor market policies — by reducing employment protection, decentralizing labor negotiations to the firm level, and making training programs more accessible and responsive to labor demands — would, all else equal, increase productivity in France’s economy.
Comment: Unclear as UE protection can also spur firm-specific invt & more lab flex brings in less prod wrkrs; FR prod already among highest in world

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Reducing employment protection would reduce the equilibrium unemployment rate in France.
Comment: Ambig evidence & theory bc opposite effect on turnover & duration; likely composition effect (CDD to CDI), which could be good for young

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: The ECB's asset purchases over the past two years have reduced the threat of deflation in the euro area as a whole.
Comment: QE likely helped w/ deflationary pressures but by how much is unclear. There are also negative effects that question sets aside.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: If the economic outlook in the euro area becomes less favorable, then increasing the ECB's asset purchase program (in size or duration) would substantially increase the euro area's economic growth over the following five years.
Comment: Perhaps one could make a case for an extension of the program (in case of a shock) but I am skeptical about further expansion.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: In general, absent any inside information, an equity investor can expect to do better by holding a well-diversified, low-fee, passive index fund than by holding a few stocks.
Comment:
Lots of evidence. Few people consistently earn risk-adj. ret > index ret. And even then, much might be compensation for time & effort.
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Without changes in policy, a rising share of people who are over age 65 will exert a substantial downward influence on per capita real GDP in western European countries.
Comment: #NAME?

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: In European countries where the share of those over 65 is rising, there are net social benefits to adjusting retirement ages for state-financed (including pay-as-you-go) pension systems upwards, so that revised retirement ages better reflect longer life expectancies.
Comment: If benefits defined as pc GDP, not so clear if defined broader. Likely unpopular so indexing is option. Consider alternatives as well.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, there are substantial advantages to having much of Europe’s human capital and infrastructure for international financial activity clustered in a single city, as they are at present in London.
Comment: Substantial agglomeration benefits in cities (Krugman, 1991); applies esp. to financial services and skilled labor

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: All else equal, Britain’s rules on hiring, firing and working hours are significantly more conducive to financial activity than those in other large European countries.
Comment:
Not clear that significantly so; depending on dimension of labor law, NL, IE, DE, CH can be close. And, less flex can be good for innovation
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Setting the EU rules aside, and assuming it would take 2.5% of Italy’s GDP to recapitalize its banks, the Italian government would improve financial stability in Europe if it injected this amount of public funds into its banks.
Comment: Helps in short-run but not clear in long-run w/o other reforms, as issue is also profitability & bank density; can increase sovereign risks

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: If Italy were to inject public funds into its banks without imposing losses on at least some claimants, an important cost would be the effect on future incentives (economic or political) in Europe.
Comment: Bending BRRD would create bad political incentives & undermine EU rules but excluding missold retail would not have same moral hazard effect

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: On the whole, the shift from state to private ownership of many industrial assets in central and eastern European countries after communism has increased productivity in those countries.
Comment:
During transition in those economies, we also saw productivity gains for state-owned firms but gains for privatized firms were much larger.
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: Especially when considering that many western European countries have low birth rates and aging populations.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment:
Native wages for lowest-skilled decrease, but also depends on relative skills of migrants to low-skilled natives
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: Especially in the long run.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment:
Benefit from lower prices but neg. employment effects; net effect depends on horizon & transfers. Bigger effect for them is technology
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: In general, using more congestion charges in crowded transportation networks — such as higher tolls during peak travel times in cities, and peak fees for airplane takeoff and landing slots — and using the proceeds to lower other taxes would make citizens on average better off.
Comment:
Congestion pricing is like pricing externalities. But welfare effects are not entirely obvious.
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Giving tax incentives to specific firms to locate operations in a country typically generates domestic benefits that outweigh the costs to the country providing the incentives.
Comment:
Can be local benefits but unclear politicians offer tax incentives only when net beneficial locally. Governmental agency problems get in way
-see background information here

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Europe as a whole benefits when European cities or countries compete with each other by giving tax incentives to firms to locate operations in their jurisdictions.
Comment: Zero sum unless companies would otherwise leave EU. Inefficient but it can help when tax rates are too high due to political economy reasons

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question A: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the UK's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: Trade barriers and uncertainty are negative. But much will depend on terms of exit and when it will be triggered.

Name: Christian Leuz
Qtext: Question B: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the rest of the EU's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: EU larger than UK, so impact likely smaller but same caveat as in first part. Also, EU lost force for more open and flexible markets.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: Germany's current account surplus is undesirable even from a purely German viewpoint: the country would be better off if, for example, it ran a smaller primary surplus, in turn leading to a smaller current account surplus.
Comment: on a very short term basis I might have agreed but Germany is facing an ageing population and they are saving for the future. Good for them!

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: The Eurozone would be in better shape if fiscal policy were more expansionary, which would allow monetary policy to be slightly less so.
Comment: fiscal policy directed to productivity-enhancing public investment would definitely benefit it more than monetary policy

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question C: If there is a recession in the Eurozone, it will be essential to have a coordinated fiscal expansion.
Comment: Keynes explained it in 1936, no need to repeat

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: The European Union goal of reaching net zero emissions of greenhouse gases by 2050 will be a major drag on economic growth.
Comment: Switching to lower or zero emissions will create jobs that will offset any negative effects on GDP

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: Carbon taxes are a better way to implement climate policy than cap-and-trade.
Comment: Both are needed. If I had to choose one only I would choose taxes

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question C: A carbon border tax targeting imports from non-EU countries with less strict climate policies is likely to harm developing economies.
Comment: Yes, but it will save the planet, so it is necessary. Eventually they will switch production techniques anyway

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: Following the UK election result, the certainty that the country is going to leave the European Union will provide a substantial short-term boost to the UK economy.
Comment: Brexit uncertainty has been a dampener on investment. There will be a boost, although maybe not substantial until we know the deal

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: Given that the transition period currently expires at the end of 2020, there is still a considerable risk that the UK will leave the European Union without a trade agreement.
Comment: I expect some kind of incomplete trade deal, especially on goods, because of the opposition of supporters of the government to no deal

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question C: Leaving the European Union without a trade agreement would have a large negative impact on the UK economy.
Comment: UK depends on trade with the EU. No trade deal brings a big barrier to such trade

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: Under current policies on climate change, the associated physical risks (such as those arising from total seasonal rainfall and sea level changes, and increased frequency, severity, and correlation of extreme weather events) will be at most a very small factor in monetary policy decisions over the next decade.
Comment: Big events will require big responses but their occurrence is uncertain

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: The physical risks associated with climate change under current policies are likely to threaten financial stability over the next decade.
Comment: Same as before. Climate change events are unpredictable but their implications can be destabilising

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public R&D spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private R&D spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public medical research spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private medical research spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for answering some long unsettled questions in development economics research.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for making significant progress in poverty reduction.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: Having companies run to maximize shareholder value creates significant negative externalities for workers and communities.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: Appropriately managed corporations could create significantly greater value than they currently do for a range of stakeholders – including workers, suppliers, customers and community members – with small impacts on shareholder value.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext:
Question C:
Effective mechanisms for boards of directors to ensure that CEOs act in ways that balance the interests of all stakeholders would be straightforward to introduce.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: Rising inequality is straining the health of liberal democracy.
Comment: The idea of liberal democracy is that there is sharing in the rewards from growth.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: Enacting more redistributive expenditures and policies would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe.
Comment: Only proviso is that they are done in a way that targets mainly poverty - e.g., as in the Nordics

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question C: European governments should allocate more resources to policies that would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe, even if it means higher public debt or lower public spending in other areas.
Comment: Populism is the biggest risk to European unity

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: At this point, there is little that the European Central Bank can do to increase or maintain output in the Eurozone.
Comment: There is no evidence of bottlenecks in the financial sector that monetary policy could relax

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: When the economy is operating below its potential, larger fiscal deficits are likely to increase demand and output.
Comment: Old fashioned Keynesianism works!

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question C: When the economy is operating below its potential and monetary policy is at the effective lower bound, fiscal policy should prioritize increasing output over decreasing public debt.
Comment: The only potential problem I see is that confidence in the country might fall and affect investment otherwise I would say strongly agree

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: Selecting candidates for membership of the ECB Executive Board based primarily on nationality ahead of competence is likely to have a negative effect on the quality of monetary policy in the Eurozone.
Comment: Using nationality as a selection criterion is silly. Competence in monetary policy has nothing to do with nationality

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: Although the central bank can never be an entirely technocratic institution, the selection process for the ECB President and members of the Executive Board is significantly worsened by intergovernmental trade-offs involving appointments to other European institutions.
Comment: Although the best person should always be selected, having many key institutions headed by the same nationality is fraught with dangers

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: On bids for infrastructure projects, the average European would be better off if Europe’s governments favored European firms over Chinese firms (or firms from any other country with non-profit-related geopolitical strategies) — even if it means sometimes choosing a higher-cost bidder.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: Breaking the “doom loop” — a negative spiral that can result when banks hold sovereign bonds and governments bail out banks — would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: Regulators should try to break the doom loop by assigning positive risk weights — in calculating banks’ capital requirements — to banks’ holdings of domestic and other Eurozone sovereign bonds.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question C: Breaking the doom loop would impose substantial costs on powerful political constituencies.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Residents of big European cities would be better off, on balance, if governments did more to counter gentrification, for example by using rent and other housing subsidies, public housing investments, zoning regulations, or similar policies.
Comment: In principle the suggestion sounds good but governments are unlike to do a good job and the result will be worse than before

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the likelihood of another financial crisis in Europe.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: Overall, public spending on the arts in Europe creates benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.
Comment: The non-monetary benefits in Europeans' preference functions far exceed any dead weight costs

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: Additional public spending on the arts in Europe would create incremental benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.
Comment: Governments panic about the votes taxation loses them and spend too little on things like the arts

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: The average European is better off if Europe’s competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.
Comment: But also some regulation is required to ensure that the conglomerate does not exploit its market position to the detriment of consumers

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: If China and other countries use policies that create giant international firms, then the average European is better off if Europe's competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.
Comment: Better allow mergers to compete with open borders than restrict trade a la Trump

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: Letting publicly traded European firms report earnings annually rather than quarterly would lead their executives to place more weight on long-term issues in their investments and other decisions.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: A switch from quarterly to annual earnings reports would, on net, benefit shareholders of European firms.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: To the extent that public corporations pursue social and environmental initiatives, they tend to achieve higher risk-adjusted (private) returns than otherwise similar corporations that pursue such initiatives less.
Comment: Without government incentives the statement about private returns is wrong. But there could be tax advantages that make it true

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: To the extent that Norway’s global government pension fund makes investments for social and environmental objectives — apart from investments that would bring the highest expected risk-adjusted returns — it improves the welfare of Norwegians.
Comment: Norwegians feel very strongly about environmental issues, so they are happier - broader welfare concept

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: The fiscal rules of the European Union should give more flexibility to member countries.
Comment: Member countries are still exposed to different shocks and fiscal policy should partly respond to idiosyncratic requirements

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: The Italian budget for 2019 that the European Commission rejected in October would have increased Italy’s risk of fiscal insolvency substantially.
Comment: Depends on the commentary from the European Commission and on the fiscal policies agreed at central policy level

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question C: If France runs a 2019 budget deficit of around 3.4% of GDP, as announced by President Macron’s government, France’s risk of fiscal insolvency will increase substantially.
Comment: France is less at risk than Italy (better finances and debt) and Macron's policies should bring more growth in the medium term

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: Capping the number of ride-sharing drivers as is being discussed in New York City, Chicago and London will make the average resident in that city worse off.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext:
Question B:
To achieve a given level of congestion, it would be better to use taxes for driving that vary based on the level of congestion, rather than limiting the number of ride-sharing vehicles.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: People who migrated to Europe between 2015 and 2018 are likely — over the next two decades — to contribute more in taxes paid than they receive in benefits and public services.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Ideas are nonrival, so increasing returns to scale is an essential feature of technological change in a market economy.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Voters overestimate the effect that current governments have on their economies’ concurrent economic performance.
Comment: Modern economies are driven by private initiative which depends partially on government policy. Governments can do more damage than good

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Over the next decade, autonomous cars will raise average welfare in the EU by at least as much as smartphones have over the past decade.
Comment: Smartphones have given access to millions to new information and opened up channels of communication. Autonomous cars will get nowhere near

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext:
Britain’s Labour party recently proposed giving the Bank of England a target of 3% annual labor productivity growth. Consider the following statement:
Central banks cannot significantly increase productivity growth over a ten year horizon, except perhaps by promoting macroeconomic stability.
Comment: Productivity growth depends on technology, infrastructure and the like. Monetary policy has nothing to do with it

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext:
Question A: The European Commission has proposed new rules to ensure that “digital business activities are taxed in a fair and growth-friendly way in the EU”. Consider two statements regarding this proposal:
An EU-wide 3% tax on revenue from digital activities would, on balance, be a good idea.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext:
Question B:
If the EU decides to tax digital service providers, it would be better — given the difficulties of measuring and verifying digital activity — to tax them on the revenue, rather than the profits, that they generate locally.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: The European Union often uses its antitrust powers to protect EU-based firms from international competition, rather than to promote greater competition in European markets.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: Trade with China makes most Europeans better off because, among other advantages, they can buy goods that are made or assembled more cheaply in China.
Comment: It also benefits European luxury goods maker, whose biggest market today is China

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: Some Europeans who work in the production of competing goods, such as clothing and furniture, are made worse off by trade with China.
Comment: They are made better off if they move to new jobs. An economy has to evolve for everyone's benefit

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question C: If the EU followed the new US steel tariffs by imposing similar EU tariffs on steel from China, it would improve Europeans’ welfare.
Comment: Europe has no comparative advantage in steel production. Let it go to China and let Europe produce more hi-tech goods

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: Assuming it exits its third bailout program this summer without an immediate restructuring or other debt relief, Greece is unlikely to default on its sovereign debt in the coming decade.
Comment: Repayment terms are easy if interest rates do not hike. The economy will grow and fiscal budget is in surplus

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: Greece would be better off if it had decided to exit the euro between 2011 and 2015.
Comment: The transition cost would have been very high and governments would have resorted to inflation-finance, devaluations and no reforms

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question C: If Greece had defaulted on (or restructured) its private debt in 2010, while also staying within the euro, that combination would have been better for Greece than either exiting the euro or proceeding as it has actually done.
Comment: Cypriot deposit haircut had similar effects. In Cyprus unsuspecting depositors lost their assets in Greece's lenders would have lost them

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to currency.
Comment: They are not currency: no central bank involved and not used in every day transactions. Not exactly like gold: gold has other uses

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to Dutch tulips in the 1630s.
Comment: Tulips, from what I know, have very little other uses

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext:
The US spends roughly 17% of GDP on healthcare, according to the OECD; most European countries spend less than 12% of GDP.

Higher quality-adjusted US healthcare prices contribute relatively more to the extra US spending than does the combination of higher quantity and quality of US care (interpreting quantity and quality to reflect both greater American healthcare needs due to underlying population health and the delivery of more or better healthcare services to Americans).
Comment: The US is an outlier in OECD data plots, far more expensive than the rest. Disease and death rates are not better than elsewhere

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Over the past two years, all else equal, the appeal of the US as a destination for immigrants has changed in ways that will likely decrease innovation in the US economy.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: Holding other policies fixed, the average European would be better off if every European country taxed corporate profits at a rate of 20% (based as closely as possible on a common definition of profits).

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question B: If other policies were held fixed and every European country taxed corporate profits at a common rate of 20%, then reducing that common rate substantially below 20% would make the average European better off.

Name: Christopher Pissarides
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, if corporations throughout Europe set quotas for a minimum number of women board members, the shareholder value of European companies would increase.
Comment: It will ensure more diversity in the views expressed and potential shareholders will have more confidence in the board as a supervisory body

Name: Christopher Pissarides

Qtext: Question C: When the economy is operating below its potential and monetary policy is at the effective lower bound, fiscal policy should prioritize increasing output over decreasing public debt.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question A: Selecting candidates for membership of the ECB Executive Board based primarily on nationality ahead of competence is likely to have a negative effect on the quality of monetary policy in the Eurozone.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question B: Although the central bank can never be an entirely technocratic institution, the selection process for the ECB President and members of the Executive Board is significantly worsened by intergovernmental trade-offs involving appointments to other European institutions.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: On bids for infrastructure projects, the average European would be better off if Europe’s governments favored European firms over Chinese firms (or firms from any other country with non-profit-related geopolitical strategies) — even if it means sometimes choosing a higher-cost bidder.
Comment: This is really a question about geopolitics rather than economics, but it seems unwise to become too dependent on a non-democratic regime.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question A: Breaking the “doom loop” — a negative spiral that can result when banks hold sovereign bonds and governments bail out banks — would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question B: Regulators should try to break the doom loop by assigning positive risk weights — in calculating banks’ capital requirements — to banks’ holdings of domestic and other Eurozone sovereign bonds.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question C: Breaking the doom loop would impose substantial costs on powerful political constituencies.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Residents of big European cities would be better off, on balance, if governments did more to counter gentrification, for example by using rent and other housing subsidies, public housing investments, zoning regulations, or similar policies.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question A: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question B: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the likelihood of another financial crisis in Europe.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question A: Overall, public spending on the arts in Europe creates benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question B: Additional public spending on the arts in Europe would create incremental benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question A: The average European is better off if Europe’s competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question B: If China and other countries use policies that create giant international firms, then the average European is better off if Europe's competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question A: Letting publicly traded European firms report earnings annually rather than quarterly would lead their executives to place more weight on long-term issues in their investments and other decisions.
Comment: Many projects take more than a year to pay off and it is not clear that such a reform would do much other than reduce incentives to perform.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question B: A switch from quarterly to annual earnings reports would, on net, benefit shareholders of European firms.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question A: To the extent that public corporations pursue social and environmental initiatives, they tend to achieve higher risk-adjusted (private) returns than otherwise similar corporations that pursue such initiatives less.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question B: To the extent that Norway’s global government pension fund makes investments for social and environmental objectives — apart from investments that would bring the highest expected risk-adjusted returns — it improves the welfare of Norwegians.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question A: The fiscal rules of the European Union should give more flexibility to member countries.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question B: The Italian budget for 2019 that the European Commission rejected in October would have increased Italy’s risk of fiscal insolvency substantially.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question C: If France runs a 2019 budget deficit of around 3.4% of GDP, as announced by President Macron’s government, France’s risk of fiscal insolvency will increase substantially.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: Question A: Capping the number of ride-sharing drivers as is being discussed in New York City, Chicago and London will make the average resident in that city worse off.
Comment: Ride-sharing improves residents transport options, with better transport being key for successful urban areas.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext:
Question B:
To achieve a given level of congestion, it would be better to use taxes for driving that vary based on the level of congestion, rather than limiting the number of ride-sharing vehicles.
Comment: Selectively reducing one type of car traffic has no long-run effect on congestion, which can only be reduced with congestion charging.

Name: Daniel Sturm
Qtext: People who migrated to Europe between 2015 and 2018 are likely — over the next two decades — to contribute more in taxes paid than they receive in benefits and public services.
Comment:
Being younger and typically better educated their fiscal contribution tends to be positive as suggested by recent research for the UK.

Qtext: Ideas are nonrival, so increasing returns to scale is an essential feature of technological change in a market economy.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question B: The physical risks associated with climate change under current policies are likely to threaten financial stability over the next decade.
