Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext:
Question C:

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext:
Britain’s Labour party recently proposed giving the Bank of England a target of 3% annual labor productivity growth. Consider the following statement:
Central banks cannot significantly increase productivity growth over a ten year horizon, except perhaps by promoting macroeconomic stability.
Comment: Even over a ten-year horizon, maintaining macroeconomic stability and avoiding slumps in investment can probably affect productivity.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext:
Question A: The European Commission has proposed new rules to ensure that “digital business activities are taxed in a fair and growth-friendly way in the EU”. Consider two statements regarding this proposal:
An EU-wide 3% tax on revenue from digital activities would, on balance, be a good idea.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext:
Question B:
If the EU decides to tax digital service providers, it would be better — given the difficulties of measuring and verifying digital activity — to tax them on the revenue, rather than the profits, that they generate locally.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: The European Union often uses its antitrust powers to protect EU-based firms from international competition, rather than to promote greater competition in European markets.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question A: Trade with China makes most Europeans better off because, among other advantages, they can buy goods that are made or assembled more cheaply in China.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question B: Some Europeans who work in the production of competing goods, such as clothing and furniture, are made worse off by trade with China.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question C: If the EU followed the new US steel tariffs by imposing similar EU tariffs on steel from China, it would improve Europeans’ welfare.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question A: Assuming it exits its third bailout program this summer without an immediate restructuring or other debt relief, Greece is unlikely to default on its sovereign debt in the coming decade.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question B: Greece would be better off if it had decided to exit the euro between 2011 and 2015.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question C: If Greece had defaulted on (or restructured) its private debt in 2010, while also staying within the euro, that combination would have been better for Greece than either exiting the euro or proceeding as it has actually done.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question A: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to currency.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question B: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to Dutch tulips in the 1630s.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext:
The US spends roughly 17% of GDP on healthcare, according to the OECD; most European countries spend less than 12% of GDP.

Higher quality-adjusted US healthcare prices contribute relatively more to the extra US spending than does the combination of higher quantity and quality of US care (interpreting quantity and quality to reflect both greater American healthcare needs due to underlying population health and the delivery of more or better healthcare services to Americans).

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Over the past two years, all else equal, the appeal of the US as a destination for immigrants has changed in ways that will likely decrease innovation in the US economy.

Name: Elena Carletti

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question B: If other policies were held fixed and every European country taxed corporate profits at a common rate of 20%, then reducing that common rate substantially below 20% would make the average European better off.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, if corporations throughout Europe set quotas for a minimum number of women board members, the shareholder value of European companies would increase.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question B: Taking into account the likely effects on investments in human capital by men and women, setting quotas throughout Europe for a minimum number of women board members would generate substantial net benefits for Europeans.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question A: Subsidizing renewable energy sources is better than taxing fossil fuels, assuming the subsidy or tax would be set at levels that would reduce carbon emissions by an equivalent amount.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question B: Germany’s solar-energy subsidies to date have produced net social benefits for Germany.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question C: Solar-energy subsidies to date in Germany and other countries have produced net social benefits for the world.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Insights from psychology about individual behavior – examples of which include limited rationality, low self-control, or a taste for fairness – predict several important types of observed market outcomes that fully-rational economic models do not.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: The influx of refugees into Germany beginning in the summer of 2015 will generate net economic benefits for German citizens over the succeeding decade.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question A: Holding labor market institutions and job training fixed, rising use of robots and artificial intelligence is likely to increase substantially the number of workers in advanced countries who are unemployed for long periods.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question B: Rising use of robots and artificial intelligence in advanced countries is likely to create benefits large enough that they could be used to compensate those workers who are substantially negatively affected for their lost wages.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question A: Consumers will be better off, on balance, if European cities treat firms that provide ride-sharing platforms (such as Uber) as substantively different from taxi firms, and thus not necessarily warranting the same regulation.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question B: Assuming that taxi and ride-sharing companies were treated as substantively similar — including requirements that they operate on an equal footing regarding safety, insurance and taxation — letting ride-sharing services compete without restrictions on prices or routes would raise consumer welfare.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question C: Regardless of how ride-sharing services are treated, existing regulations for traditional taxi firms in many European cities harm consumers by limiting competition.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question A: Revising France’s labor market policies — by reducing employment protection, decentralizing labor negotiations to the firm level, and making training programs more accessible and responsive to labor demands — would, all else equal, increase productivity in France’s economy.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question B: Reducing employment protection would reduce the equilibrium unemployment rate in France.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question A: The ECB's asset purchases over the past two years have reduced the threat of deflation in the euro area as a whole.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question B: If the economic outlook in the euro area becomes less favorable, then increasing the ECB's asset purchase program (in size or duration) would substantially increase the euro area's economic growth over the following five years.
Comment: the ECB program is not targeted directly to stimulate growth. It may help the economy recovering but it is not its main goal

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: In general, absent any inside information, an equity investor can expect to do better by holding a well-diversified, low-fee, passive index fund than by holding a few stocks.

Name: Elena Carletti

Comment: The effect of injecting public funds into the Italian banking system depends a lot on how this is done and on the investors' reactions.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question B: If Italy were to inject public funds into its banks without imposing losses on at least some claimants, an important cost would be the effect on future incentives (economic or political) in Europe.
Comment: The rules leave the possibility of injecting public funds without private losses, but I agree that this may have important signaling effects

Name: Elena Carletti

Name: Elena Carletti

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: In general, using more congestion charges in crowded transportation networks — such as higher tolls during peak travel times in cities, and peak fees for airplane takeoff and landing slots — and using the proceeds to lower other taxes would make citizens on average better off.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question A: Giving tax incentives to specific firms to locate operations in a country typically generates domestic benefits that outweigh the costs to the country providing the incentives.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question B: Europe as a whole benefits when European cities or countries compete with each other by giving tax incentives to firms to locate operations in their jurisdictions.
Comment: this may lead to too lax competition

Qtext: Question A: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the UK's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: Britain will be poorer as a consequence of the exit from the EU but a lot will depend on how the negotiations will go.

Name: Elena Carletti
Qtext: Question B: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the rest of the EU's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.

Qtext: Question C: If Greece had defaulted on (or restructured) its private debt in 2010, while also staying within the euro, that combination would have been better for Greece than either exiting the euro or proceeding as it has actually done.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question A: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to currency.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question B: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to Dutch tulips in the 1630s.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext:
The US spends roughly 17% of GDP on healthcare, according to the OECD; most European countries spend less than 12% of GDP.

Higher quality-adjusted US healthcare prices contribute relatively more to the extra US spending than does the combination of higher quantity and quality of US care (interpreting quantity and quality to reflect both greater American healthcare needs due to underlying population health and the delivery of more or better healthcare services to Americans).

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Over the past two years, all else equal, the appeal of the US as a destination for immigrants has changed in ways that will likely decrease innovation in the US economy.
Comment: on average really motivated people will still be able to get there

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question A: Holding other policies fixed, the average European would be better off if every European country taxed corporate profits at a rate of 20% (based as closely as possible on a common definition of profits).

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question B: If other policies were held fixed and every European country taxed corporate profits at a common rate of 20%, then reducing that common rate substantially below 20% would make the average European better off.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, if corporations throughout Europe set quotas for a minimum number of women board members, the shareholder value of European companies would increase.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question B: Taking into account the likely effects on investments in human capital by men and women, setting quotas throughout Europe for a minimum number of women board members would generate substantial net benefits for Europeans.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question A: Subsidizing renewable energy sources is better than taxing fossil fuels, assuming the subsidy or tax would be set at levels that would reduce carbon emissions by an equivalent amount.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question B: Germany’s solar-energy subsidies to date have produced net social benefits for Germany.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question C: Solar-energy subsidies to date in Germany and other countries have produced net social benefits for the world.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Insights from psychology about individual behavior – examples of which include limited rationality, low self-control, or a taste for fairness – predict several important types of observed market outcomes that fully-rational economic models do not.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: The influx of refugees into Germany beginning in the summer of 2015 will generate net economic benefits for German citizens over the succeeding decade.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question A: Holding labor market institutions and job training fixed, rising use of robots and artificial intelligence is likely to increase substantially the number of workers in advanced countries who are unemployed for long periods.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question B: Rising use of robots and artificial intelligence in advanced countries is likely to create benefits large enough that they could be used to compensate those workers who are substantially negatively affected for their lost wages.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question A: Consumers will be better off, on balance, if European cities treat firms that provide ride-sharing platforms (such as Uber) as substantively different from taxi firms, and thus not necessarily warranting the same regulation.
Comment: I agree but existing owners of taxi licencesnshouldb be compensated on a scale depending on the lucence age

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question B: Assuming that taxi and ride-sharing companies were treated as substantively similar — including requirements that they operate on an equal footing regarding safety, insurance and taxation — letting ride-sharing services compete without restrictions on prices or routes would raise consumer welfare.
Comment: conditional on the caveat above

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question C: Regardless of how ride-sharing services are treated, existing regulations for traditional taxi firms in many European cities harm consumers by limiting competition.
Comment: The licencing system with a predetermined number of licences should be replaced with one that only controls safety and similar stadards

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question A: Revising France’s labor market policies — by reducing employment protection, decentralizing labor negotiations to the firm level, and making training programs more accessible and responsive to labor demands — would, all else equal, increase productivity in France’s economy.
Comment: The positive experience of the Italian jobs Act

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question B: Reducing employment protection would reduce the equilibrium unemployment rate in France.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question A: The ECB's asset purchases over the past two years have reduced the threat of deflation in the euro area as a whole.
Comment: Hard to distinguish between role of purchases and of negative rates (via the exchange rate channel). Both probably helped

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question B: If the economic outlook in the euro area becomes less favorable, then increasing the ECB's asset purchase program (in size or duration) would substantially increase the euro area's economic growth over the following five years.
Comment: purchases have achieved what they were supposed to. Unlikely they can do more--though in the case described they should not be removed

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: In general, absent any inside information, an equity investor can expect to do better by holding a well-diversified, low-fee, passive index fund than by holding a few stocks.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question A: Without changes in policy, a rising share of people who are over age 65 will exert a substantial downward influence on per capita real GDP in western European countries.
Comment: indeed it depends on policies. Aging accompanied by improvemente in human capital of the youth could have the opposite effect.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question B: In European countries where the share of those over 65 is rising, there are net social benefits to adjusting retirement ages for state-financed (including pay-as-you-go) pension systems upwards, so that revised retirement ages better reflect longer life expectancies.
Comment: in some countries (e.g. Italy) retirement age isindedd already indexed to average life expectancy

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, there are substantial advantages to having much of Europe’s human capital and infrastructure for international financial activity clustered in a single city, as they are at present in London.
Comment: Enrico Morretti's work on cities (The New Geography of Jobs) is a good starting point

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question B: All else equal, Britain’s rules on hiring, firing and working hours are significantly more conducive to financial activity than those in other large European countries.
Comment: no brainer

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question A: Setting the EU rules aside, and assuming it would take 2.5% of Italy’s GDP to recapitalize its banks, the Italian government would improve financial stability in Europe if it injected this amount of public funds into its banks.
Comment: zombie banks would eventually drive Italy out of the euro

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question B: If Italy were to inject public funds into its banks without imposing losses on at least some claimants, an important cost would be the effect on future incentives (economic or political) in Europe.
Comment: it has happened elsewhere in Europe and there is no dign of a serious deterioration of incentives

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: On the whole, the shift from state to private ownership of many industrial assets in central and eastern European countries after communism has increased productivity in those countries.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: again the question is about movements within europe, thus no doubts

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: the questions asks about movements WITHIN Europe: here there is no doubt

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: again the question is about trade within europe, thus no doubts

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: In general, using more congestion charges in crowded transportation networks — such as higher tolls during peak travel times in cities, and peak fees for airplane takeoff and landing slots — and using the proceeds to lower other taxes would make citizens on average better off.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question A: Giving tax incentives to specific firms to locate operations in a country typically generates domestic benefits that outweigh the costs to the country providing the incentives.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question B: Europe as a whole benefits when European cities or countries compete with each other by giving tax incentives to firms to locate operations in their jurisdictions.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question A: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the UK's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.

Name: Francesco Giavazzi
Qtext: Question B: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the rest of the EU's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Germany's current account surplus is undesirable even from a purely German viewpoint: the country would be better off if, for example, it ran a smaller primary surplus, in turn leading to a smaller current account surplus.
Comment: Depends what the money is spent on. Germany is probably underinvesting in infrastructure and education.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: The Eurozone would be in better shape if fiscal policy were more expansionary, which would allow monetary policy to be slightly less so.
Comment: Again it depends on what the money is being spent on with the expanded fiscal policy relative to what is the optimal public expenditure.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question C: If there is a recession in the Eurozone, it will be essential to have a coordinated fiscal expansion.
Comment: Not clear in the long run that policy interventions of this kind are beneficial. Again depends on how productively spending is.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: The European Union goal of reaching net zero emissions of greenhouse gases by 2050 will be a major drag on economic growth.
Comment: There are a lot of opportunities building new businesses from the climate change initiative. The time horizon is long enough for it to be ok

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Carbon taxes are a better way to implement climate policy than cap-and-trade.
Comment: This is an interesting question. I do not know the research in this area well.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question C: A carbon border tax targeting imports from non-EU countries with less strict climate policies is likely to harm developing economies.
Comment: In the short run there may be negative effects unless there is a long lead in time. In the long run it will help climate change.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Following the UK election result, the certainty that the country is going to leave the European Union will provide a substantial short-term boost to the UK economy.
Comment: Investment has been low since the Brexit vote. Now there is more clarity after the election it should increase.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Given that the transition period currently expires at the end of 2020, there is still a considerable risk that the UK will leave the European Union without a trade agreement.
Comment: The law outlawing extension appears to be a negotiating strategy. There is a risk that they don't the deal.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question C: Leaving the European Union without a trade agreement would have a large negative impact on the UK economy.
Comment: I think there is likely to be a negative short term effect but in the medium and long term it is not clear what will happen.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Under current policies on climate change, the associated physical risks (such as those arising from total seasonal rainfall and sea level changes, and increased frequency, severity, and correlation of extreme weather events) will be at most a very small factor in monetary policy decisions over the next decade.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: The physical risks associated with climate change under current policies are likely to threaten financial stability over the next decade.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public R&D spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private R&D spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.
Comment: It depends significantly on the country and what exactly the money would be spent on in both public and private cases.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public medical research spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private medical research spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.
Comment: Private research tends to spent on rich world lifestyle medical problems while public research can focus on deadly diseases like TB.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for answering some long unsettled questions in development economics research.
Comment: RCTs are a very good way in certain circumstances to establish whether certain business strategies and public policies are beneficial.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for making significant progress in poverty reduction.
Comment: They can help identify the uses for new technologies and how they can best be implemented.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Having companies run to maximize shareholder value creates significant negative externalities for workers and communities.
Comment: I think the issue of stakeholder governance is a very important and much understudied subject. It has been difficult to publish papers.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Appropriately managed corporations could create significantly greater value than they currently do for a range of stakeholders – including workers, suppliers, customers and community members – with small impacts on shareholder value.
Comment: Again very understudied.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext:
Question C:
Effective mechanisms for boards of directors to ensure that CEOs act in ways that balance the interests of all stakeholders would be straightforward to introduce.
Comment: I think it will be very difficult to do in practice. The German system of codetermination may be better.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Rising inequality is straining the health of liberal democracy.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Enacting more redistributive expenditures and policies would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question C: European governments should allocate more resources to policies that would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe, even if it means higher public debt or lower public spending in other areas.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: At this point, there is little that the European Central Bank can do to increase or maintain output in the Eurozone.
Comment: It is probably close to the limits of what it can achieve using previous tools. But there may be new ones they can come up with.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: When the economy is operating below its potential, larger fiscal deficits are likely to increase demand and output.
Comment: Maybe in the short run but in the long run good investment decisions associated with innovation are likely to have more effect.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question C: When the economy is operating below its potential and monetary policy is at the effective lower bound, fiscal policy should prioritize increasing output over decreasing public debt.
Comment: It depends on the circumstances of the country. If it is not very indebted and public investment would be beneficial then it makes sense.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Selecting candidates for membership of the ECB Executive Board based primarily on nationality ahead of competence is likely to have a negative effect on the quality of monetary policy in the Eurozone.
Comment: Competence is clearly extremely important. However, in a severe Eurozone crisis understanding key countries' position may also be important

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Although the central bank can never be an entirely technocratic institution, the selection process for the ECB President and members of the Executive Board is significantly worsened by intergovernmental trade-offs involving appointments to other European institutions.
Comment: If all the positions were held by male northern Europeans, it would not be good for the democratic legitimacy of the Union.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: On bids for infrastructure projects, the average European would be better off if Europe’s governments favored European firms over Chinese firms (or firms from any other country with non-profit-related geopolitical strategies) — even if it means sometimes choosing a higher-cost bidder.
Comment: For 5G, high speed trains, etc., Chinese technology is better than European, US or Japanese. It would be a shame for Euope not to use it.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Breaking the “doom loop” — a negative spiral that can result when banks hold sovereign bonds and governments bail out banks — would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.
Comment: The doom loop is a real problem still, particularly for some southern European countries.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Regulators should try to break the doom loop by assigning positive risk weights — in calculating banks’ capital requirements — to banks’ holdings of domestic and other Eurozone sovereign bonds.
Comment: I think this would be helpful.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question C: Breaking the doom loop would impose substantial costs on powerful political constituencies.
Comment: It would be interesting to see exactly what the political opposition would be to this measure.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Residents of big European cities would be better off, on balance, if governments did more to counter gentrification, for example by using rent and other housing subsidies, public housing investments, zoning regulations, or similar policies.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.
Comment:
Theoretically it can go both ways as deposit insurance can increase risk taking. Empirically there is some evidence crises can increase.
-see background information here

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the likelihood of another financial crisis in Europe.
Comment:
Complicated issue because of the effect of deposit insurance on risk taking.
-see background information here

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Overall, public spending on the arts in Europe creates benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.
Comment: It's difficult issue involving both funding of public goods and inequality issues.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Additional public spending on the arts in Europe would create incremental benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.
Comment: Ascertaining the optimal level is again very difficult.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: The average European is better off if Europe’s competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.
Comment: I would say it depends on the extent of global competition and the amount of access to EU markets.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: If China and other countries use policies that create giant international firms, then the average European is better off if Europe's competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.
Comment: Again it depends on global versus local competition.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Letting publicly traded European firms report earnings annually rather than quarterly would lead their executives to place more weight on long-term issues in their investments and other decisions.
Comment: This is an interesting trade-off. I'm afraid I am not up on the literature enough to express a meaningful opinion.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: A switch from quarterly to annual earnings reports would, on net, benefit shareholders of European firms.
Comment: This is an interesting trade-off. I am afraid I am not sufficiently knowledgeable about this to give a meaningful opinion.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: To the extent that public corporations pursue social and environmental initiatives, they tend to achieve higher risk-adjusted (private) returns than otherwise similar corporations that pursue such initiatives less.
Comment: Not sure of the entire literature in this field. Would guess there are a range of results here.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: To the extent that Norway’s global government pension fund makes investments for social and environmental objectives — apart from investments that would bring the highest expected risk-adjusted returns — it improves the welfare of Norwegians.
Comment: Not very knowledgeable about the current ESG policies of Norwegian Global Pension fund.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: The fiscal rules of the European Union should give more flexibility to member countries.
Comment: There are arguments both ways. Not fully persuaded either way.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: The Italian budget for 2019 that the European Commission rejected in October would have increased Italy’s risk of fiscal insolvency substantially.
Comment: Italy has significant fiscal problems. They need to get their debt under control.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question C: If France runs a 2019 budget deficit of around 3.4% of GDP, as announced by President Macron’s government, France’s risk of fiscal insolvency will increase substantially.
Comment: France's fiscal situation is still under control. The problem is the effect on the Commission's interaction with Italy.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Capping the number of ride-sharing drivers as is being discussed in New York City, Chicago and London will make the average resident in that city worse off.
Comment: Complicated issue with many factors involved including price, convenience, availability, safety, and so forth,

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext:
Question B:
To achieve a given level of congestion, it would be better to use taxes for driving that vary based on the level of congestion, rather than limiting the number of ride-sharing vehicles.
Comment: Taxing road use is is good way of dealing with congestion. Main downside is income distribution so could use revenues for public transport.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: People who migrated to Europe between 2015 and 2018 are likely — over the next two decades — to contribute more in taxes paid than they receive in benefits and public services.
Comment: I'm not well informed about the demographics of all EU immigrants in the time period considered. Usually immigrants provide net benefits.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Ideas are nonrival, so increasing returns to scale is an essential feature of technological change in a market economy.
Comment: Not exactly sure what the question is suggesting.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Voters overestimate the effect that current governments have on their economies’ concurrent economic performance.
Comment: The lags in terms of the effects of policy are uncertain and probably highly variable. It seems unlikely that voters understand this well.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Over the next decade, autonomous cars will raise average welfare in the EU by at least as much as smartphones have over the past decade.
Comment: Autonomous cars may take some time before they are widely used.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext:
Britain’s Labour party recently proposed giving the Bank of England a target of 3% annual labor productivity growth. Consider the following statement:
Central banks cannot significantly increase productivity growth over a ten year horizon, except perhaps by promoting macroeconomic stability.
Comment: As far as I know, there's not much evidence that central bank policies are very effective in affecting productivity.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext:
Question A: The European Commission has proposed new rules to ensure that “digital business activities are taxed in a fair and growth-friendly way in the EU”. Consider two statements regarding this proposal:
An EU-wide 3% tax on revenue from digital activities would, on balance, be a good idea.
Comment: The digital companies need to be taxed. This seems the best way to do it that I have heard.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext:
Question B:
If the EU decides to tax digital service providers, it would be better — given the difficulties of measuring and verifying digital activity — to tax them on the revenue, rather than the profits, that they generate locally.
Comment: Profits are fairly meaningless for these companies since they can use accounting charges to move the profits to very low tax rate places.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: The European Union often uses its antitrust powers to protect EU-based firms from international competition, rather than to promote greater competition in European markets.
Comment: I would say the evidence is mixed and I do not enough about it to draw a reasonable conclusion.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Trade with China makes most Europeans better off because, among other advantages, they can buy goods that are made or assembled more cheaply in China.
Comment: By and large, I agree with free trade. The question is well phrased to avoid some of the downsides of free trade.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Some Europeans who work in the production of competing goods, such as clothing and furniture, are made worse off by trade with China.
Comment: In the short run this is often true. In the medium and long term, it's more difficult to say. Retraining is not that successful so far.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question C: If the EU followed the new US steel tariffs by imposing similar EU tariffs on steel from China, it would improve Europeans’ welfare.
Comment: Contrary to what President Trump said, outcomes of trade wars are difficult to predict but are probably not good for anybody.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Assuming it exits its third bailout program this summer without an immediate restructuring or other debt relief, Greece is unlikely to default on its sovereign debt in the coming decade.
Comment: I would say there is a great deal of uncertainty about this with much depending on how things develop in the Eurozone in the coming years.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Greece would be better off if it had decided to exit the euro between 2011 and 2015.
Comment: It has suffered a punishing depression and has only recently started growing. It would have grown much faster outside the Eurozone.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question C: If Greece had defaulted on (or restructured) its private debt in 2010, while also staying within the euro, that combination would have been better for Greece than either exiting the euro or proceeding as it has actually done.
Comment: It would have removed the debt overhang and could have grown much faster as a result.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to currency.
Comment: At the moment Bitcoin is more of an investment than a medium of exchange and so is closer to gold. The reason is the price volatility.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to Dutch tulips in the 1630s.
Comment: I think Bitcoin is not necessarily a bubble since it does have uses, eg, transferring value from Venezuela to the US.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext:
The US spends roughly 17% of GDP on healthcare, according to the OECD; most European countries spend less than 12% of GDP.

Higher quality-adjusted US healthcare prices contribute relatively more to the extra US spending than does the combination of higher quantity and quality of US care (interpreting quantity and quality to reflect both greater American healthcare needs due to underlying population health and the delivery of more or better healthcare services to Americans).

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Over the past two years, all else equal, the appeal of the US as a destination for immigrants has changed in ways that will likely decrease innovation in the US economy.
Comment: Trump's election has put off many creative people who might otherwise be interested in moving to the US.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Holding other policies fixed, the average European would be better off if every European country taxed corporate profits at a rate of 20% (based as closely as possible on a common definition of profits).

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: If other policies were held fixed and every European country taxed corporate profits at a common rate of 20%, then reducing that common rate substantially below 20% would make the average European better off.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, if corporations throughout Europe set quotas for a minimum number of women board members, the shareholder value of European companies would increase.
Comment: I am not knowledgeable about the evidence in this area. Setting quotas is a good idea in my view but not because of value increase.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Taking into account the likely effects on investments in human capital by men and women, setting quotas throughout Europe for a minimum number of women board members would generate substantial net benefits for Europeans.
Comment: I think there would be long term benefits of quotas for this kind of reason.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Subsidizing renewable energy sources is better than taxing fossil fuels, assuming the subsidy or tax would be set at levels that would reduce carbon emissions by an equivalent amount.
Comment: There seem to be strong learning by doing effects. Subsidies can help target these where these effects are largest.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Germany’s solar-energy subsidies to date have produced net social benefits for Germany.
Comment: The quicker we get up the learning curve for these technologies the better.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question C: Solar-energy subsidies to date in Germany and other countries have produced net social benefits for the world.
Comment: Not so clear solar-power is the best alternative for Germany. I am afraid I don't know enough about the technologies and Germany's climate.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Insights from psychology about individual behavior – examples of which include limited rationality, low self-control, or a taste for fairness – predict several important types of observed market outcomes that fully-rational economic models do not.
Comment: I think this is true in many markets. In financial markets it may be less true because of the money at stake but they matter there too.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: The influx of refugees into Germany beginning in the summer of 2015 will generate net economic benefits for German citizens over the succeeding decade.
Comment: I am not very well informed on the skill sets of the refugees that have been allowed to stay. In general I think immigration is beneficial.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Holding labor market institutions and job training fixed, rising use of robots and artificial intelligence is likely to increase substantially the number of workers in advanced countries who are unemployed for long periods.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Rising use of robots and artificial intelligence in advanced countries is likely to create benefits large enough that they could be used to compensate those workers who are substantially negatively affected for their lost wages.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Consumers will be better off, on balance, if European cities treat firms that provide ride-sharing platforms (such as Uber) as substantively different from taxi firms, and thus not necessarily warranting the same regulation.
Comment: Uber provides a different kind of service to regular taxi services that helps consumers. Leck of worker's rights may be a problem though.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Assuming that taxi and ride-sharing companies were treated as substantively similar — including requirements that they operate on an equal footing regarding safety, insurance and taxation — letting ride-sharing services compete without restrictions on prices or routes would raise consumer welfare.
Comment: This seems an area where competition would be beneficial.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question C: Regardless of how ride-sharing services are treated, existing regulations for traditional taxi firms in many European cities harm consumers by limiting competition.
Comment: Trade-off of worker'w rights and consumers benefits is a difficult one.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Revising France’s labor market policies — by reducing employment protection, decentralizing labor negotiations to the firm level, and making training programs more accessible and responsive to labor demands — would, all else equal, increase productivity in France’s economy.
Comment: Giving flexibility should improve things in the long run. The short run effects may be more problematic if there is a lot of dissent,

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Reducing employment protection would reduce the equilibrium unemployment rate in France.
Comment: This seems to have been the case in other countries. The unions response may lead to a different outcome in the case of France.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: The ECB's asset purchases over the past two years have reduced the threat of deflation in the euro area as a whole.
Comment: It's difficult to know the effect of these asset purchases on consumer price inflation.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: If the economic outlook in the euro area becomes less favorable, then increasing the ECB's asset purchase program (in size or duration) would substantially increase the euro area's economic growth over the following five years.
Comment: It seems quite uncertain to me what the effect on growth of the asset purchases. It will depend among other things on how they are unwound

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: In general, absent any inside information, an equity investor can expect to do better by holding a well-diversified, low-fee, passive index fund than by holding a few stocks.
Comment: In the absence of inside information, on average a diversified strategy should do better unless the person has good judgment.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Without changes in policy, a rising share of people who are over age 65 will exert a substantial downward influence on per capita real GDP in western European countries.
Comment: It depends on how easy it is for them to keep working. The easier it is the less likely this scenario will unfold.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: In European countries where the share of those over 65 is rising, there are net social benefits to adjusting retirement ages for state-financed (including pay-as-you-go) pension systems upwards, so that revised retirement ages better reflect longer life expectancies.
Comment: Yes, people need to work longer given the demographic distribution and increased longevity.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, there are substantial advantages to having much of Europe’s human capital and infrastructure for international financial activity clustered in a single city, as they are at present in London.
Comment: There are huge agglomeration effects from having clusters of expertise.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: All else equal, Britain’s rules on hiring, firing and working hours are significantly more conducive to financial activity than those in other large European countries.
Comment: Most other large European countries have higher social payments, taxes and more secure employment. Providing incentives is more difficult.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Setting the EU rules aside, and assuming it would take 2.5% of Italy’s GDP to recapitalize its banks, the Italian government would improve financial stability in Europe if it injected this amount of public funds into its banks.
Comment: Italy's banks are significantly undercapitalized, particularly if you consider market rather than accounting capital.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: If Italy were to inject public funds into its banks without imposing losses on at least some claimants, an important cost would be the effect on future incentives (economic or political) in Europe.
Comment: Shareholders and non-retail bondholders need to be penalised if a bank fails to provide the right incentives going forward.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: On the whole, the shift from state to private ownership of many industrial assets in central and eastern European countries after communism has increased productivity in those countries.
Comment: For many but not all industries, privatization increases efficiency. I think this is true in many central and eastern European countries.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: Free movement is a good thing economically and in many other ways.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: I think we are all better off from immigration.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: Free trade increases the efficiency of the economy. Although there significant distributional issues, the average person is better off.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: Some workers are made worse off but as consumers they are probably better off.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: In general, using more congestion charges in crowded transportation networks — such as higher tolls during peak travel times in cities, and peak fees for airplane takeoff and landing slots — and using the proceeds to lower other taxes would make citizens on average better off.
Comment: These kinds of taxes are beneficial in my view provided the technology for implementing them is sufficiently low cost.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Giving tax incentives to specific firms to locate operations in a country typically generates domestic benefits that outweigh the costs to the country providing the incentives.
Comment: Difficult to answer such a general question - more information about the particular circumstances is required.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Europe as a whole benefits when European cities or countries compete with each other by giving tax incentives to firms to locate operations in their jurisdictions.
Comment: Small countries have an incentive to offer low rates since their fixed costs are smaller.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question A: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the UK's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: It's very difficult to know how the negotiations for trade and immigration will play out. The benefits of being outside the EU are unclear.

Name: Franklin Allen
Qtext: Question B: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the rest of the EU's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: Again very difficult to know how things will play out at this stage.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Germany's current account surplus is undesirable even from a purely German viewpoint: the country would be better off if, for example, it ran a smaller primary surplus, in turn leading to a smaller current account surplus.
Comment: Germany is famously poor in investing its surpluses abroad

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: The Eurozone would be in better shape if fiscal policy were more expansionary, which would allow monetary policy to be slightly less so.
Comment: I am not convinced that more expansionary policy in the Southern states is desirable; debt is already high and spending is often wasted

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question C: If there is a recession in the Eurozone, it will be essential to have a coordinated fiscal expansion.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: The European Union goal of reaching net zero emissions of greenhouse gases by 2050 will be a major drag on economic growth.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Carbon taxes are a better way to implement climate policy than cap-and-trade.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question C: A carbon border tax targeting imports from non-EU countries with less strict climate policies is likely to harm developing economies.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Following the UK election result, the certainty that the country is going to leave the European Union will provide a substantial short-term boost to the UK economy.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Given that the transition period currently expires at the end of 2020, there is still a considerable risk that the UK will leave the European Union without a trade agreement.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question C: Leaving the European Union without a trade agreement would have a large negative impact on the UK economy.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Under current policies on climate change, the associated physical risks (such as those arising from total seasonal rainfall and sea level changes, and increased frequency, severity, and correlation of extreme weather events) will be at most a very small factor in monetary policy decisions over the next decade.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: The physical risks associated with climate change under current policies are likely to threaten financial stability over the next decade.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public R&D spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private R&D spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public medical research spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private medical research spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for answering some long unsettled questions in development economics research.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for making significant progress in poverty reduction.
Comment: external validity is a real concern with all RCTs, as Duflo and Banerjee also argue ("The plumbing matters")

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Having companies run to maximize shareholder value creates significant negative externalities for workers and communities.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Appropriately managed corporations could create significantly greater value than they currently do for a range of stakeholders – including workers, suppliers, customers and community members – with small impacts on shareholder value.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext:
Question C:
Effective mechanisms for boards of directors to ensure that CEOs act in ways that balance the interests of all stakeholders would be straightforward to introduce.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Rising inequality is straining the health of liberal democracy.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Enacting more redistributive expenditures and policies would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe.
Comment: Redistribution is already very high and it does not seem ti mollify people much

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question C: European governments should allocate more resources to policies that would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe, even if it means higher public debt or lower public spending in other areas.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: At this point, there is little that the European Central Bank can do to increase or maintain output in the Eurozone.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: When the economy is operating below its potential, larger fiscal deficits are likely to increase demand and output.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question C: When the economy is operating below its potential and monetary policy is at the effective lower bound, fiscal policy should prioritize increasing output over decreasing public debt.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Selecting candidates for membership of the ECB Executive Board based primarily on nationality ahead of competence is likely to have a negative effect on the quality of monetary policy in the Eurozone.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Although the central bank can never be an entirely technocratic institution, the selection process for the ECB President and members of the Executive Board is significantly worsened by intergovernmental trade-offs involving appointments to other European institutions.
Comment: Its been surprisingly ok so far...

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: On bids for infrastructure projects, the average European would be better off if Europe’s governments favored European firms over Chinese firms (or firms from any other country with non-profit-related geopolitical strategies) — even if it means sometimes choosing a higher-cost bidder.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Breaking the “doom loop” — a negative spiral that can result when banks hold sovereign bonds and governments bail out banks — would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Regulators should try to break the doom loop by assigning positive risk weights — in calculating banks’ capital requirements — to banks’ holdings of domestic and other Eurozone sovereign bonds.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question C: Breaking the doom loop would impose substantial costs on powerful political constituencies.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Residents of big European cities would be better off, on balance, if governments did more to counter gentrification, for example by using rent and other housing subsidies, public housing investments, zoning regulations, or similar policies.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the likelihood of another financial crisis in Europe.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Overall, public spending on the arts in Europe creates benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Additional public spending on the arts in Europe would create incremental benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: The average European is better off if Europe’s competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.
Comment: Doubtful even in the long run

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: If China and other countries use policies that create giant international firms, then the average European is better off if Europe's competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Letting publicly traded European firms report earnings annually rather than quarterly would lead their executives to place more weight on long-term issues in their investments and other decisions.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: A switch from quarterly to annual earnings reports would, on net, benefit shareholders of European firms.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: To the extent that public corporations pursue social and environmental initiatives, they tend to achieve higher risk-adjusted (private) returns than otherwise similar corporations that pursue such initiatives less.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: To the extent that Norway’s global government pension fund makes investments for social and environmental objectives — apart from investments that would bring the highest expected risk-adjusted returns — it improves the welfare of Norwegians.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: The fiscal rules of the European Union should give more flexibility to member countries.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: The Italian budget for 2019 that the European Commission rejected in October would have increased Italy’s risk of fiscal insolvency substantially.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question C: If France runs a 2019 budget deficit of around 3.4% of GDP, as announced by President Macron’s government, France’s risk of fiscal insolvency will increase substantially.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Capping the number of ride-sharing drivers as is being discussed in New York City, Chicago and London will make the average resident in that city worse off.
Comment: In principle, regulatory arbitrage is not ideal; but taxi regulation is so hopeless in most cities that Uber et can only make things better

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext:
Question B:
To achieve a given level of congestion, it would be better to use taxes for driving that vary based on the level of congestion, rather than limiting the number of ride-sharing vehicles.
Comment: A good part of congestion is caused by searching for a parking space; ride sharing reduces that, balancing shifts away from public trans.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: People who migrated to Europe between 2015 and 2018 are likely — over the next two decades — to contribute more in taxes paid than they receive in benefits and public services.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Ideas are nonrival, so increasing returns to scale is an essential feature of technological change in a market economy.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Voters overestimate the effect that current governments have on their economies’ concurrent economic performance.
Comment: "Learning the Wealth of Nations"...

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Over the next decade, autonomous cars will raise average welfare in the EU by at least as much as smartphones have over the past decade.
Comment: In 1960, people thought that machine translation was around the corner...

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext:
Britain’s Labour party recently proposed giving the Bank of England a target of 3% annual labor productivity growth. Consider the following statement:
Central banks cannot significantly increase productivity growth over a ten year horizon, except perhaps by promoting macroeconomic stability.
Comment: It's clear that bad policy can screw up things; but long-run productivity growth is not under the thumb of central bankers...

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext:
Question A: The European Commission has proposed new rules to ensure that “digital business activities are taxed in a fair and growth-friendly way in the EU”. Consider two statements regarding this proposal:
An EU-wide 3% tax on revenue from digital activities would, on balance, be a good idea.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext:
Question B:
If the EU decides to tax digital service providers, it would be better — given the difficulties of measuring and verifying digital activity — to tax them on the revenue, rather than the profits, that they generate locally.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: The European Union often uses its antitrust powers to protect EU-based firms from international competition, rather than to promote greater competition in European markets.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Trade with China makes most Europeans better off because, among other advantages, they can buy goods that are made or assembled more cheaply in China.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Some Europeans who work in the production of competing goods, such as clothing and furniture, are made worse off by trade with China.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question C: If the EU followed the new US steel tariffs by imposing similar EU tariffs on steel from China, it would improve Europeans’ welfare.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Assuming it exits its third bailout program this summer without an immediate restructuring or other debt relief, Greece is unlikely to default on its sovereign debt in the coming decade.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Greece would be better off if it had decided to exit the euro between 2011 and 2015.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question C: If Greece had defaulted on (or restructured) its private debt in 2010, while also staying within the euro, that combination would have been better for Greece than either exiting the euro or proceeding as it has actually done.
Comment: Not very clear what doing the same thing 2 years earlier would have bought them...

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to currency.
Comment: Bitcoins are almost useless as currency... but like gold, in limited supply.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to Dutch tulips in the 1630s.
Comment: Tulips are highly differentiated goods; bitcoin are not. But both bitcoin and tulips have no business being very valuable...

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext:
The US spends roughly 17% of GDP on healthcare, according to the OECD; most European countries spend less than 12% of GDP.

Higher quality-adjusted US healthcare prices contribute relatively more to the extra US spending than does the combination of higher quantity and quality of US care (interpreting quantity and quality to reflect both greater American healthcare needs due to underlying population health and the delivery of more or better healthcare services to Americans).

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Over the past two years, all else equal, the appeal of the US as a destination for immigrants has changed in ways that will likely decrease innovation in the US economy.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Holding other policies fixed, the average European would be better off if every European country taxed corporate profits at a rate of 20% (based as closely as possible on a common definition of profits).

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: If other policies were held fixed and every European country taxed corporate profits at a common rate of 20%, then reducing that common rate substantially below 20% would make the average European better off.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, if corporations throughout Europe set quotas for a minimum number of women board members, the shareholder value of European companies would increase.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Taking into account the likely effects on investments in human capital by men and women, setting quotas throughout Europe for a minimum number of women board members would generate substantial net benefits for Europeans.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Subsidizing renewable energy sources is better than taxing fossil fuels, assuming the subsidy or tax would be set at levels that would reduce carbon emissions by an equivalent amount.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Germany’s solar-energy subsidies to date have produced net social benefits for Germany.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question C: Solar-energy subsidies to date in Germany and other countries have produced net social benefits for the world.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Insights from psychology about individual behavior – examples of which include limited rationality, low self-control, or a taste for fairness – predict several important types of observed market outcomes that fully-rational economic models do not.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: The influx of refugees into Germany beginning in the summer of 2015 will generate net economic benefits for German citizens over the succeeding decade.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Holding labor market institutions and job training fixed, rising use of robots and artificial intelligence is likely to increase substantially the number of workers in advanced countries who are unemployed for long periods.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Rising use of robots and artificial intelligence in advanced countries is likely to create benefits large enough that they could be used to compensate those workers who are substantially negatively affected for their lost wages.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Consumers will be better off, on balance, if European cities treat firms that provide ride-sharing platforms (such as Uber) as substantively different from taxi firms, and thus not necessarily warranting the same regulation.
Comment: Uber etc are monopolization plays; where taxi regulation works today, as in most European cities, the long-run impact may be negative

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Assuming that taxi and ride-sharing companies were treated as substantively similar — including requirements that they operate on an equal footing regarding safety, insurance and taxation — letting ride-sharing services compete without restrictions on prices or routes would raise consumer welfare.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question C: Regardless of how ride-sharing services are treated, existing regulations for traditional taxi firms in many European cities harm consumers by limiting competition.
Comment: The picture is mixed; some cities have been captured by the taxi lobby, as in the US; others boast cheap, safe, plentiful taxi services...

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Revising France’s labor market policies — by reducing employment protection, decentralizing labor negotiations to the firm level, and making training programs more accessible and responsive to labor demands — would, all else equal, increase productivity in France’s economy.
Comment: Longer-term contracts can be a good thing for prouctivity, if firms and workers invest in the "match"...

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Reducing employment protection would reduce the equilibrium unemployment rate in France.
Comment: Modern labor econ overwhelmingly suggests that firms have a lot of market power; that means that this is likely but not guaranteed

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: The ECB's asset purchases over the past two years have reduced the threat of deflation in the euro area as a whole.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: If the economic outlook in the euro area becomes less favorable, then increasing the ECB's asset purchase program (in size or duration) would substantially increase the euro area's economic growth over the following five years.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: In general, absent any inside information, an equity investor can expect to do better by holding a well-diversified, low-fee, passive index fund than by holding a few stocks.
Comment:
Just look at the long-term Warren Buffett bet against managed funds -- whenever there is outperformance, fees eat them up
-see background information here

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Without changes in policy, a rising share of people who are over age 65 will exert a substantial downward influence on per capita real GDP in western European countries.
Comment: this is a supposition that seems logical but empirical evidence seems weak in general

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: In European countries where the share of those over 65 is rising, there are net social benefits to adjusting retirement ages for state-financed (including pay-as-you-go) pension systems upwards, so that revised retirement ages better reflect longer life expectancies.
Comment: The benefits for the finances of pay-as-you-go systems are fairly obvious...

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, there are substantial advantages to having much of Europe’s human capital and infrastructure for international financial activity clustered in a single city, as they are at present in London.
Comment: Wholesale financial services naturally congregate in a handful of locations....that's why there are financial centers in the first place.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: All else equal, Britain’s rules on hiring, firing and working hours are significantly more conducive to financial activity than those in other large European countries.
Comment: I think this is really secondary; "light touch" regulation and the lock-in from pre-existing activity are much more important.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Setting the EU rules aside, and assuming it would take 2.5% of Italy’s GDP to recapitalize its banks, the Italian government would improve financial stability in Europe if it injected this amount of public funds into its banks.
Comment: I think this could easily backfire. Bailouts done right can be a jolly goood thing but i have at least some reservations about the prospects

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: If Italy were to inject public funds into its banks without imposing losses on at least some claimants, an important cost would be the effect on future incentives (economic or political) in Europe.
Comment: There is already a lot of concern in Germany about EMU rules being broken. This could be the final straw

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: On the whole, the shift from state to private ownership of many industrial assets in central and eastern European countries after communism has increased productivity in those countries.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: hugely heterogenous - strongly positive for Germany etc., probably a small minus in places with a weaker manufacturing base

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: In general, using more congestion charges in crowded transportation networks — such as higher tolls during peak travel times in cities, and peak fees for airplane takeoff and landing slots — and using the proceeds to lower other taxes would make citizens on average better off.

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Giving tax incentives to specific firms to locate operations in a country typically generates domestic benefits that outweigh the costs to the country providing the incentives.
Comment: distortionary effects on factor markets are rarely accounted for

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Europe as a whole benefits when European cities or countries compete with each other by giving tax incentives to firms to locate operations in their jurisdictions.
Comment: this favors large firms and creates size-dependent distortions

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question A: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the UK's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: we know very little about the long-run effects of common market access on service trade, the most important component of UK exports

Name: Hans-Joachim Voth
Qtext: Question B: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the rest of the EU's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: It depends on how much free market momentum is lost within the EU due to Brexit

Name: Hélène Rey
Qtext: Question A: Germany's current account surplus is undesirable even from a purely German viewpoint: the country would be better off if, for example, it ran a smaller primary surplus, in turn leading to a smaller current account surplus.
Comment: Investing now to tackle e.g climate change is prudent strategy instead of getting low returns on external assets. Low gvt borrowing rates.

Name: Hélène Rey
Qtext: Question B: The Eurozone would be in better shape if fiscal policy were more expansionary, which would allow monetary policy to be slightly less so.
Comment: fiscal policy now would be effective to boost economy and invest for future. Would help constrained monetary policy.

Name: Hélène Rey
Qtext: Question C: If there is a recession in the Eurozone, it will be essential to have a coordinated fiscal expansion.

Name: Hélène Rey
Qtext: Question A: The European Union goal of reaching net zero emissions of greenhouse gases by 2050 will be a major drag on economic growth.
Comment: This all depends how we get there. If major EU coordinated investments, R&D and leadership role, costs will be mitigated

Name: Hélène Rey
Qtext: Question B: Carbon taxes are a better way to implement climate policy than cap-and-trade.
Comment: Best way is predictably rising carbon price path with redistribution of carbon dividend and accompanying investments

Name: Hélène Rey
Qtext: Question C: A carbon border tax targeting imports from non-EU countries with less strict climate policies is likely to harm developing economies.
Comment: Depends on accompanying policies: technological transfers and aid to mitigate costs could help a lot.

Name: Hélène Rey
Qtext: Question A: Following the UK election result, the certainty that the country is going to leave the European Union will provide a substantial short-term boost to the UK economy.
Comment: There is great uncertainty about the path that will be chosen, from no deal to soft Brexit.

Name: Hélène Rey
Qtext: Question B: Given that the transition period currently expires at the end of 2020, there is still a considerable risk that the UK will leave the European Union without a trade agreement.
Comment: Short time to negotiate increases chances of no deal and of soft Brexit. Everything in between takes time to negotiate.

Name: Hélène Rey
Qtext: Question C: Leaving the European Union without a trade agreement would have a large negative impact on the UK economy.
Comment: Most independent studies have shown large effects of no deal.

Name: Hélène Rey
Qtext: Question A: Under current policies on climate change, the associated physical risks (such as those arising from total seasonal rainfall and sea level changes, and increased frequency, severity, and correlation of extreme weather events) will be at most a very small factor in monetary policy decisions over the next decade.
Comment: Climate related events can be supply (for some) or demand (for others) shocks. Some are transitory. They affect monetary policy.

Name: Hélène Rey
