Comment: Depends on the Brexit deal.

Name: Jan Eeckhout
Qtext: Question B: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the rest of the EU's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Germany's current account surplus is undesirable even from a purely German viewpoint: the country would be better off if, for example, it ran a smaller primary surplus, in turn leading to a smaller current account surplus.
Comment: If the EU is one economy, some countries will always run a surplus/deficit; there is no point in balancing the current account by country.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: The Eurozone would be in better shape if fiscal policy were more expansionary, which would allow monetary policy to be slightly less so.
Comment: There are pros and cons, as some countries have hard-to sustain government debt levels, others not. Thus, a case by case analysis is needed.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question C: If there is a recession in the Eurozone, it will be essential to have a coordinated fiscal expansion.
Comment: Fiscal policies in the Eurozone are by and large regional/national decisions, so coordination may be either not justified, or not needed.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: The European Union goal of reaching net zero emissions of greenhouse gases by 2050 will be a major drag on economic growth.
Comment: The policy will require significant public and private investments, allowing for knock-on effects that are likely to spur growth.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Carbon taxes are a better way to implement climate policy than cap-and-trade.
Comment: The big difference is the "cap" - without it, taxes may distort investment and consumption, but will not necessarily reduce emissions.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question C: A carbon border tax targeting imports from non-EU countries with less strict climate policies is likely to harm developing economies.
Comment: The question leaves open whether or not the border tax is accompanied by higher levies for CO2 production within borders.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Following the UK election result, the certainty that the country is going to leave the European Union will provide a substantial short-term boost to the UK economy.
Comment: The demise of the "fork" (in versus out) reduces ambiguity greatly, allowing longer term planning once again.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Given that the transition period currently expires at the end of 2020, there is still a considerable risk that the UK will leave the European Union without a trade agreement.
Comment: I don't thing that the EU on the other side of the table will play hard ball - they will rather give in, allowing for a trade arrangement.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question C: Leaving the European Union without a trade agreement would have a large negative impact on the UK economy.
Comment: This is too complicated a case to think it through properly now.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Under current policies on climate change, the associated physical risks (such as those arising from total seasonal rainfall and sea level changes, and increased frequency, severity, and correlation of extreme weather events) will be at most a very small factor in monetary policy decisions over the next decade.
Comment: The answer is "uncertain", because I fear political pressure combined with central bank hubris may lead to action based on a false positive

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: The physical risks associated with climate change under current policies are likely to threaten financial stability over the next decade.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public R&D spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private R&D spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.
Comment: I believe in the direct plus indirect benefit of basic research, which is more likely to be public rather than private R&D.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public medical research spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private medical research spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.
Comment: Public R&D may have positive second round effects in the form of private R&D, whereas the opposite is less likely to happen.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for answering some long unsettled questions in development economics research.
Comment: This is an overall YES, because it addresses directly the identification problem, thereby hinting at effective policy instruments.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for making significant progress in poverty reduction.
Comment: The fact that I learn something about causality does not imply implementing isolated changes (of instruments) in the real world is easy.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Having companies run to maximize shareholder value creates significant negative externalities for workers and communities.
Comment: There is a route to maximizing shareholder value while simultaneously upholding stakeholder utility: That is German Ordnungspolitik.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Appropriately managed corporations could create significantly greater value than they currently do for a range of stakeholders – including workers, suppliers, customers and community members – with small impacts on shareholder value.
Comment: In its generality, the statement is hard to disagree with...

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext:
Question C:
Effective mechanisms for boards of directors to ensure that CEOs act in ways that balance the interests of all stakeholders would be straightforward to introduce.
Comment: Long term profitability will not be maximized when other stakeholders' interests are manifestly violated.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Rising inequality is straining the health of liberal democracy.
Comment: Not inequality per se undermines democracy, but the degree to which being rich or poor becomes hereditary.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Enacting more redistributive expenditures and policies would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe.
Comment: Populism - as today's new nationalism - is driven by doubts about future living standard and way of life, rather than inequality at home.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question C: European governments should allocate more resources to policies that would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe, even if it means higher public debt or lower public spending in other areas.
Comment: Fighting populism-nationalism needs bold decisions promoting a sense of relevance and pride for European politics. That is no spending issue

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: At this point, there is little that the European Central Bank can do to increase or maintain output in the Eurozone.
Comment: The ECB can influence output via interest rates if and only if the investment function is monotonic everywhere. But this may not be true.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: When the economy is operating below its potential, larger fiscal deficits are likely to increase demand and output.
Comment: There are two caveats in the statement: first, output is below potential, and second, Ricardian equivalence does not hold.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question C: When the economy is operating below its potential and monetary policy is at the effective lower bound, fiscal policy should prioritize increasing output over decreasing public debt.
Comment: I disagree because of unconditional nature of the statement. What if Ricardian equivalence holds, and investment function bends backwards?

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Selecting candidates for membership of the ECB Executive Board based primarily on nationality ahead of competence is likely to have a negative effect on the quality of monetary policy in the Eurozone.
Comment: Yes, a negative influence is possible because national elctorates may believe "their" agent will bias his/her decisions.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Although the central bank can never be an entirely technocratic institution, the selection process for the ECB President and members of the Executive Board is significantly worsened by intergovernmental trade-offs involving appointments to other European institutions.
Comment: The phrase overstates the effective influence of trade-offs. An appointment balance may help to achieve mutual recognition, given quality.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: On bids for infrastructure projects, the average European would be better off if Europe’s governments favored European firms over Chinese firms (or firms from any other country with non-profit-related geopolitical strategies) — even if it means sometimes choosing a higher-cost bidder.
Comment: The response to geopolitical interests is a wise strong set of conditionalities if awarded, rather than exclusion from the bidding process.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Breaking the “doom loop” — a negative spiral that can result when banks hold sovereign bonds and governments bail out banks — would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.
Comment: In the Eurozone, banks' home bias creates bankruptcy risk because states cannot print the money needed to redeem their debt.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Regulators should try to break the doom loop by assigning positive risk weights — in calculating banks’ capital requirements — to banks’ holdings of domestic and other Eurozone sovereign bonds.
Comment: I only weakly agree, because there are second order effects of risk weights, and there are better alternatives, like concentration limits.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question C: Breaking the doom loop would impose substantial costs on powerful political constituencies.
Comment: Second order (political) effects of changing risk weights are only poorly understood.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Residents of big European cities would be better off, on balance, if governments did more to counter gentrification, for example by using rent and other housing subsidies, public housing investments, zoning regulations, or similar policies.
Comment: Too homogeneous a neighborhood in inner cities, as wel as in "les banlieues", may undermine cohesion and solidarity in society at large.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.
Comment: “Fully implemented” implies implementation in a way that minimizes moral hazard, e.g. through a European reinsurance scheme.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the likelihood of another financial crisis in Europe.
Comment: No, it would not iprovided it is implemented cleverly, e.g. relying on a reinsurance scheme.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Overall, public spending on the arts in Europe creates benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.
Comment: Clearly, the statement is subject to decreasing marginal returns, so the optimal amount of spending is finite.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Additional public spending on the arts in Europe would create incremental benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.
Comment: Given the high level of public spending on the arts in Europe, we may have reached the point of negative marginal returns in some countries.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: The average European is better off if Europe’s competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.
Comment: There are pros and cons, and I do not see easily how to weigh these arguments...

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: If China and other countries use policies that create giant international firms, then the average European is better off if Europe's competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Letting publicly traded European firms report earnings annually rather than quarterly would lead their executives to place more weight on long-term issues in their investments and other decisions.
Comment: The point is that Board-level brain-time needed to justify volatile results is reduced to an -arguably- more reasonable time span.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: A switch from quarterly to annual earnings reports would, on net, benefit shareholders of European firms.
Comment: Board-level brain time is redirected to longer horizons - which on balance may benefit shareholders.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: To the extent that public corporations pursue social and environmental initiatives, they tend to achieve higher risk-adjusted (private) returns than otherwise similar corporations that pursue such initiatives less.
Comment: It is an unlikely combination, doing good and having private benefits too.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: To the extent that Norway’s global government pension fund makes investments for social and environmental objectives — apart from investments that would bring the highest expected risk-adjusted returns — it improves the welfare of Norwegians.
Comment: There is an emotional benefit in pursuing such an investment stratategy that may be relevant here.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: The fiscal rules of the European Union should give more flexibility to member countries.
Comment: The rule itself should be rock-solid, the user should herself select the buffers required to achieve the desired degree of flexibility.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: The Italian budget for 2019 that the European Commission rejected in October would have increased Italy’s risk of fiscal insolvency substantially.
Comment: It increasese default probability through its indirect effect on future debt incentives; while the direct effect may be negligible.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question C: If France runs a 2019 budget deficit of around 3.4% of GDP, as announced by President Macron’s government, France’s risk of fiscal insolvency will increase substantially.
Comment: As in the case of Italy, rule-breaking carries the risk of repetition, although to a lessor extent for France.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Capping the number of ride-sharing drivers as is being discussed in New York City, Chicago and London will make the average resident in that city worse off.
Comment: Too many side and cross effects to consider in order to arrive at a "safe" welfare conclusion.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext:
Question B:
To achieve a given level of congestion, it would be better to use taxes for driving that vary based on the level of congestion, rather than limiting the number of ride-sharing vehicles.
Comment: The marginal cost of adding or subtracting vehicles instantly, according to traffic status, is lower with ride-sharers than with cabs.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: People who migrated to Europe between 2015 and 2018 are likely — over the next two decades — to contribute more in taxes paid than they receive in benefits and public services.
Comment: As employment rate among migrants goes up over time, and much of taxation is indirect anyway, chances are that the statement comes true.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Ideas are nonrival, so increasing returns to scale is an essential feature of technological change in a market economy.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Voters overestimate the effect that current governments have on their economies’ concurrent economic performance.
Comment: Often, in public debate, external forces and uncontrolled markets are blamed for poor economic performance, not true own political omissions

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Over the next decade, autonomous cars will raise average welfare in the EU by at least as much as smartphones have over the past decade.
Comment: Autonomous cars are relevant for urban areas, whereas smartphones have affected the life of almost everybody, thus a larger welfare effect.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext:
Britain’s Labour party recently proposed giving the Bank of England a target of 3% annual labor productivity growth. Consider the following statement:
Central banks cannot significantly increase productivity growth over a ten year horizon, except perhaps by promoting macroeconomic stability.
Comment: Quite an absurd suggestion, vastly overestimating what monetary policy can achieve - in the end frustrating central bankers and the public.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext:
Question A: The European Commission has proposed new rules to ensure that “digital business activities are taxed in a fair and growth-friendly way in the EU”. Consider two statements regarding this proposal:
An EU-wide 3% tax on revenue from digital activities would, on balance, be a good idea.
Comment: A "fair" digital tax should allocate the tax base (profits) virtually among producer and consumer countries; a 3% tax may start negotiations

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext:
Question B:
If the EU decides to tax digital service providers, it would be better — given the difficulties of measuring and verifying digital activity — to tax them on the revenue, rather than the profits, that they generate locally.
Comment: Yes, but profit taxation requires negotiations between countries to share the tax base (unlikely to work in todays protectionist world)

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: The European Union often uses its antitrust powers to protect EU-based firms from international competition, rather than to promote greater competition in European markets.
Comment: A generalized answer to this question needs to be specify a particular industry. In banking I do not agree, in others I don't know enough.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Trade with China makes most Europeans better off because, among other advantages, they can buy goods that are made or assembled more cheaply in China.
Comment: Trade with China, as with other countries, is of a reciprocal nature, and it helps Europeans (and Chinese) in consumption and employment.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Some Europeans who work in the production of competing goods, such as clothing and furniture, are made worse off by trade with China.
Comment: This statement is in a way a no-brainer. But it begs the question whether it does not also help affected European producers to find a niche.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question C: If the EU followed the new US steel tariffs by imposing similar EU tariffs on steel from China, it would improve Europeans’ welfare.
Comment: I do not believe in strategic trade policy as an instrument of welfare improvement: European and Chinese welfare are not substitutes.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Assuming it exits its third bailout program this summer without an immediate restructuring or other debt relief, Greece is unlikely to default on its sovereign debt in the coming decade.
Comment: Greece is now back on track, has accepted many hardships in order to comply with European requests - why should it change its stance?

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Greece would be better off if it had decided to exit the euro between 2011 and 2015.
Comment: Exiting a currency union is tough. Lots of international exposures will be in default, because of the extreme devaluation.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question C: If Greece had defaulted on (or restructured) its private debt in 2010, while also staying within the euro, that combination would have been better for Greece than either exiting the euro or proceeding as it has actually done.
Comment: The default-in-2010 option would have been close to Banking Union rules: Bail-in creditors - which at the time were mostly foreign banks

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to currency.
Comment: A bitcoin is a private bet on becoming a (public) legal tender, and on earning the seignorage.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to Dutch tulips in the 1630s.
Comment: Again, tulips had developed into a mutually accepted expression of value, and bulbs were seen as the key (algorithm) to replication/mining.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext:
The US spends roughly 17% of GDP on healthcare, according to the OECD; most European countries spend less than 12% of GDP.

Higher quality-adjusted US healthcare prices contribute relatively more to the extra US spending than does the combination of higher quantity and quality of US care (interpreting quantity and quality to reflect both greater American healthcare needs due to underlying population health and the delivery of more or better healthcare services to Americans).

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Over the past two years, all else equal, the appeal of the US as a destination for immigrants has changed in ways that will likely decrease innovation in the US economy.
Comment: I know a few excellent students who in earlier years would have applied for a top US school, and who now prefer to stay in Europe.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Holding other policies fixed, the average European would be better off if every European country taxed corporate profits at a rate of 20% (based as closely as possible on a common definition of profits).
Comment: The effect of lower tax rate on average income is probably stronger than that of lower taxable income (given concurrent US-tax reduction).

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: If other policies were held fixed and every European country taxed corporate profits at a common rate of 20%, then reducing that common rate substantially below 20% would make the average European better off.
Comment: Same as before.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, if corporations throughout Europe set quotas for a minimum number of women board members, the shareholder value of European companies would increase.
Comment: Even if more women on boards meant better decisions, the effect on shareholder value in general equilibrium is likely non-positive.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Taking into account the likely effects on investments in human capital by men and women, setting quotas throughout Europe for a minimum number of women board members would generate substantial net benefits for Europeans.
Comment: The sum of two marginal effects - one positive (women), the other negative (men) - is likely to be positive in this case.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Subsidizing renewable energy sources is better than taxing fossil fuels, assuming the subsidy or tax would be set at levels that would reduce carbon emissions by an equivalent amount.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Germany’s solar-energy subsidies to date have produced net social benefits for Germany.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question C: Solar-energy subsidies to date in Germany and other countries have produced net social benefits for the world.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Insights from psychology about individual behavior – examples of which include limited rationality, low self-control, or a taste for fairness – predict several important types of observed market outcomes that fully-rational economic models do not.
Comment: while I see the impact of nudging on macro outcomes (e.g. pension fund participation), I am uncertain whether this is due to irrationality.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: The influx of refugees into Germany beginning in the summer of 2015 will generate net economic benefits for German citizens over the succeeding decade.
Comment: Direct effects likely negative, while indirect effects -ranging from fiscal stimuli to change in immigration policy- likely positive. Sum=?

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Holding labor market institutions and job training fixed, rising use of robots and artificial intelligence is likely to increase substantially the number of workers in advanced countries who are unemployed for long periods.
Comment: We will see lots of changes, not only robots coming in. But also very different ways of working, leading also to shorter employment spells.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Rising use of robots and artificial intelligence in advanced countries is likely to create benefits large enough that they could be used to compensate those workers who are substantially negatively affected for their lost wages.
Comment: Absolutely. But mind the term "could". Whether or not it happens depends critically on fundamental adjustments of our societal architecture.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Consumers will be better off, on balance, if European cities treat firms that provide ride-sharing platforms (such as Uber) as substantively different from taxi firms, and thus not necessarily warranting the same regulation.
Comment: Exempting ride sharing services from existing regulations would put taxi firms at an imposed disadvantage, undermining efficiency.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Assuming that taxi and ride-sharing companies were treated as substantively similar — including requirements that they operate on an equal footing regarding safety, insurance and taxation — letting ride-sharing services compete without restrictions on prices or routes would raise consumer welfare.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question C: Regardless of how ride-sharing services are treated, existing regulations for traditional taxi firms in many European cities harm consumers by limiting competition.
Comment: Welfare is affected by two effects, reduced competition (a minus), and increased safety/reliability (a plus). The sum is thus indeterminate.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Revising France’s labor market policies — by reducing employment protection, decentralizing labor negotiations to the firm level, and making training programs more accessible and responsive to labor demands — would, all else equal, increase productivity in France’s economy.
Comment: The second policy option in the list (decentralized labor negotiations) may backfire, boosting strike incentives and lowering productivity.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Reducing employment protection would reduce the equilibrium unemployment rate in France.
Comment: I only note in passing that the relationship between equilibrium unemployment rate and welfare is likely to be non-monotonic.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: The ECB's asset purchases over the past two years have reduced the threat of deflation in the euro area as a whole.
Comment: APP has desired real effects iff credit supply is the problem, not demand, nor structural reform. Moreover, is mild deflation a threat?

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: If the economic outlook in the euro area becomes less favorable, then increasing the ECB's asset purchase program (in size or duration) would substantially increase the euro area's economic growth over the following five years.
Comment: APP may have opposite effect: Expectations of unsustainable debt levels at states and banks leading to low interest rates & low growth.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: In general, absent any inside information, an equity investor can expect to do better by holding a well-diversified, low-fee, passive index fund than by holding a few stocks.
Comment: A quant hedge fund may extract extra return by big data strategies, but an average guy, like myself, will likely fail with stock-picking.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Without changes in policy, a rising share of people who are over age 65 will exert a substantial downward influence on per capita real GDP in western European countries.
Comment: The emphasis is on "without change in policy" - but it is those changes that will weigh heavily on the policy agenda, e.g. retirement age.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: In European countries where the share of those over 65 is rising, there are net social benefits to adjusting retirement ages for state-financed (including pay-as-you-go) pension systems upwards, so that revised retirement ages better reflect longer life expectancies.
Comment: Increasing retirement age will go hand in hand with changing work conditions. As a consequence, productivity of elderly is likely to rise.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, there are substantial advantages to having much of Europe’s human capital and infrastructure for international financial activity clustered in a single city, as they are at present in London.
Comment:
For hub-and-spoke structure, we need to balance agglomeration synergy against systemic risk externality (created at hub, borne by spokes).
-see background information here

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: All else equal, Britain’s rules on hiring, firing and working hours are significantly more conducive to financial activity than those in other large European countries.
Comment: For non-tariff employees, income tax law and conducive (friendly) regulatory policies are way more important than hiring and firing rules.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Setting the EU rules aside, and assuming it would take 2.5% of Italy’s GDP to recapitalize its banks, the Italian government would improve financial stability in Europe if it injected this amount of public funds into its banks.
Comment: Inject all capital into strong banks, not weak ones, thus restructuring and scaling down the entire sector. Good plan, but will not happen.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: If Italy were to inject public funds into its banks without imposing losses on at least some claimants, an important cost would be the effect on future incentives (economic or political) in Europe.
Comment:
Europe's new regulatory architecture aims for market discipline through bail-inability of equity and junior debt. US pursues different model
-see background information here

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: On the whole, the shift from state to private ownership of many industrial assets in central and eastern European countries after communism has increased productivity in those countries.
Comment: While productivity has increased almost surely, production may actually have dropped significantly, as industry was largely dismantled.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: Welfare comparisons are hard to substantiate. Moreover, note the identification problem: EU trade and migration happened simultaneously.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: Freer migration has increased GDP, and thus has raised transfers to lower-skilled people. The balance, I believe (!), may well be positive.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: Citizens, not workers or consumers are evaluated. Gains from trade have probably increased in terms of averaging across Europeans.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: Gains from trade have increased the extent to which redistribution via the social security system can be effective.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: In general, using more congestion charges in crowded transportation networks — such as higher tolls during peak travel times in cities, and peak fees for airplane takeoff and landing slots — and using the proceeds to lower other taxes would make citizens on average better off.
Comment: Note that crowdedness is endogenous, and an allocation of proceeds to all citizens (rather than other transportation users) is third best.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Giving tax incentives to specific firms to locate operations in a country typically generates domestic benefits that outweigh the costs to the country providing the incentives.
Comment: While benefits are consummated locally, negative externalities and allocative distortions are largely outside the country.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Europe as a whole benefits when European cities or countries compete with each other by giving tax incentives to firms to locate operations in their jurisdictions.
Comment: Compare innovation and competition (pro) with rent seeking and allocative distortions (contra). For Europe, the "contra" argument dominates.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question A: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the UK's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: Think of the EU as a collective good with some redistributive features. Strong countries that separate leave tab on the table for remainers.

Name: Jan Pieter Krahnen
Qtext: Question B: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the rest of the EU's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: As the UK leaves, an advocate of markets and free competition departs - with negative consequences for the rest of the EU.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Germany's current account surplus is undesirable even from a purely German viewpoint: the country would be better off if, for example, it ran a smaller primary surplus, in turn leading to a smaller current account surplus.
Comment: provided the public investments are real productivity boosters!

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: The Eurozone would be in better shape if fiscal policy were more expansionary, which would allow monetary policy to be slightly less so.
Comment: under same condition!

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question C: If there is a recession in the Eurozone, it will be essential to have a coordinated fiscal expansion.
Comment:
At the zero-lower-bound fiscal-monetary coordination is essential to avoid sub-optimal monetary policies.
-see background information here

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: The European Union goal of reaching net zero emissions of greenhouse gases by 2050 will be a major drag on economic growth.
Comment: A well crafted and timed transition strategy will create significant economic opportunities.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Carbon taxes are a better way to implement climate policy than cap-and-trade.
Comment: I tend to agree but reaching the goal while taking political constraints into account requires being pragmatic

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question C: A carbon border tax targeting imports from non-EU countries with less strict climate policies is likely to harm developing economies.
Comment: Yes in the absence of compensating financial mechanisms that should be put in place to avoid that outcome.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Following the UK election result, the certainty that the country is going to leave the European Union will provide a substantial short-term boost to the UK economy.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Given that the transition period currently expires at the end of 2020, there is still a considerable risk that the UK will leave the European Union without a trade agreement.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question C: Leaving the European Union without a trade agreement would have a large negative impact on the UK economy.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Under current policies on climate change, the associated physical risks (such as those arising from total seasonal rainfall and sea level changes, and increased frequency, severity, and correlation of extreme weather events) will be at most a very small factor in monetary policy decisions over the next decade.
Comment: Serious economic disruptions are likely without significant policy changes to which central banks will have to react.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: The physical risks associated with climate change under current policies are likely to threaten financial stability over the next decade.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public R&D spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private R&D spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public medical research spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private medical research spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.
Comment: Stronger public regulation (e.g. on pricing and accounting transparency) with private investment may be a better combination

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for answering some long unsettled questions in development economics research.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for making significant progress in poverty reduction.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Having companies run to maximize shareholder value creates significant negative externalities for workers and communities.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Appropriately managed corporations could create significantly greater value than they currently do for a range of stakeholders – including workers, suppliers, customers and community members – with small impacts on shareholder value.
Comment: Provided a long run perspective is adopted

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext:
Question C:
Effective mechanisms for boards of directors to ensure that CEOs act in ways that balance the interests of all stakeholders would be straightforward to introduce.
Comment: Regulation and legal mechanisms must be complemented by changes in investors’ convictions!

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Rising inequality is straining the health of liberal democracy.
Comment: True where there is a rise in inequality. Inequalities are not the only, neither always the main source of pressure on liberal democracies.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Enacting more redistributive expenditures and policies would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe.
Comment: Unemployment, immigration and the design of the European project are as important causes of populism in Europe. Redistribution is not all.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question C: European governments should allocate more resources to policies that would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe, even if it means higher public debt or lower public spending in other areas.
Comment: Agree (even though vague statement and fighting populism is not only a money issue) because populism is a very important threat.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: At this point, there is little that the European Central Bank can do to increase or maintain output in the Eurozone.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: When the economy is operating below its potential, larger fiscal deficits are likely to increase demand and output.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question C: When the economy is operating below its potential and monetary policy is at the effective lower bound, fiscal policy should prioritize increasing output over decreasing public debt.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Selecting candidates for membership of the ECB Executive Board based primarily on nationality ahead of competence is likely to have a negative effect on the quality of monetary policy in the Eurozone.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Although the central bank can never be an entirely technocratic institution, the selection process for the ECB President and members of the Executive Board is significantly worsened by intergovernmental trade-offs involving appointments to other European institutions.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: On bids for infrastructure projects, the average European would be better off if Europe’s governments favored European firms over Chinese firms (or firms from any other country with non-profit-related geopolitical strategies) — even if it means sometimes choosing a higher-cost bidder.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Breaking the “doom loop” — a negative spiral that can result when banks hold sovereign bonds and governments bail out banks — would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Regulators should try to break the doom loop by assigning positive risk weights — in calculating banks’ capital requirements — to banks’ holdings of domestic and other Eurozone sovereign bonds.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question C: Breaking the doom loop would impose substantial costs on powerful political constituencies.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Residents of big European cities would be better off, on balance, if governments did more to counter gentrification, for example by using rent and other housing subsidies, public housing investments, zoning regulations, or similar policies.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the likelihood of another financial crisis in Europe.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Overall, public spending on the arts in Europe creates benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Additional public spending on the arts in Europe would create incremental benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: The average European is better off if Europe’s competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: If China and other countries use policies that create giant international firms, then the average European is better off if Europe's competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.
Comment: There could be a case in areas where security/privacy issues are at stake

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Letting publicly traded European firms report earnings annually rather than quarterly would lead their executives to place more weight on long-term issues in their investments and other decisions.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: A switch from quarterly to annual earnings reports would, on net, benefit shareholders of European firms.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: To the extent that public corporations pursue social and environmental initiatives, they tend to achieve higher risk-adjusted (private) returns than otherwise similar corporations that pursue such initiatives less.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: To the extent that Norway’s global government pension fund makes investments for social and environmental objectives — apart from investments that would bring the highest expected risk-adjusted returns — it improves the welfare of Norwegians.
Comment: uncertain about Norwegians' material welfare (exclus. foreign investments) but revealed preference implies higher subjective welfare.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: The fiscal rules of the European Union should give more flexibility to member countries.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: The Italian budget for 2019 that the European Commission rejected in October would have increased Italy’s risk of fiscal insolvency substantially.
Comment: Needs to distinguish between a one-shot deviation from set deficit limit and a significant weakening of commitment to decrease debt to GDP

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question C: If France runs a 2019 budget deficit of around 3.4% of GDP, as announced by President Macron’s government, France’s risk of fiscal insolvency will increase substantially.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Capping the number of ride-sharing drivers as is being discussed in New York City, Chicago and London will make the average resident in that city worse off.
Comment: At the expense however of all incumbents taxi drivers for whom compensatory measures of a transitory nature could be justified.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext:
Question B:
To achieve a given level of congestion, it would be better to use taxes for driving that vary based on the level of congestion, rather than limiting the number of ride-sharing vehicles.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: People who migrated to Europe between 2015 and 2018 are likely — over the next two decades — to contribute more in taxes paid than they receive in benefits and public services.
Comment: To guarantee this outcome the States should invest generously in training and integrating the least qualified immigrants (refugees)

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Ideas are nonrival, so increasing returns to scale is an essential feature of technological change in a market economy.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Voters overestimate the effect that current governments have on their economies’ concurrent economic performance.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Over the next decade, autonomous cars will raise average welfare in the EU by at least as much as smartphones have over the past decade.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext:
Britain’s Labour party recently proposed giving the Bank of England a target of 3% annual labor productivity growth. Consider the following statement:
Central banks cannot significantly increase productivity growth over a ten year horizon, except perhaps by promoting macroeconomic stability.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext:
Question A: The European Commission has proposed new rules to ensure that “digital business activities are taxed in a fair and growth-friendly way in the EU”. Consider two statements regarding this proposal:
An EU-wide 3% tax on revenue from digital activities would, on balance, be a good idea.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext:
Question B:
If the EU decides to tax digital service providers, it would be better — given the difficulties of measuring and verifying digital activity — to tax them on the revenue, rather than the profits, that they generate locally.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: The European Union often uses its antitrust powers to protect EU-based firms from international competition, rather than to promote greater competition in European markets.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Trade with China makes most Europeans better off because, among other advantages, they can buy goods that are made or assembled more cheaply in China.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Some Europeans who work in the production of competing goods, such as clothing and furniture, are made worse off by trade with China.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question C: If the EU followed the new US steel tariffs by imposing similar EU tariffs on steel from China, it would improve Europeans’ welfare.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Assuming it exits its third bailout program this summer without an immediate restructuring or other debt relief, Greece is unlikely to default on its sovereign debt in the coming decade.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Greece would be better off if it had decided to exit the euro between 2011 and 2015.
Comment: under the assumption of a prepared, coordinated exit

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question C: If Greece had defaulted on (or restructured) its private debt in 2010, while also staying within the euro, that combination would have been better for Greece than either exiting the euro or proceeding as it has actually done.
Comment: Staying in the euro under reduced debt is better if the necessary reforms are also implemented

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to currency.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to Dutch tulips in the 1630s.
Comment: Both gold and tulips are bubbles. Gold has a larger intrinsic value plus a long history as a safe haven asset.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext:
The US spends roughly 17% of GDP on healthcare, according to the OECD; most European countries spend less than 12% of GDP.

Higher quality-adjusted US healthcare prices contribute relatively more to the extra US spending than does the combination of higher quantity and quality of US care (interpreting quantity and quality to reflect both greater American healthcare needs due to underlying population health and the delivery of more or better healthcare services to Americans).

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Over the past two years, all else equal, the appeal of the US as a destination for immigrants has changed in ways that will likely decrease innovation in the US economy.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Holding other policies fixed, the average European would be better off if every European country taxed corporate profits at a rate of 20% (based as closely as possible on a common definition of profits).

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: If other policies were held fixed and every European country taxed corporate profits at a common rate of 20%, then reducing that common rate substantially below 20% would make the average European better off.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, if corporations throughout Europe set quotas for a minimum number of women board members, the shareholder value of European companies would increase.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Taking into account the likely effects on investments in human capital by men and women, setting quotas throughout Europe for a minimum number of women board members would generate substantial net benefits for Europeans.
Comment: A voluntary push to increase the number of women board members would be beneficial but it should be progressive and adapted to startingpoint

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Subsidizing renewable energy sources is better than taxing fossil fuels, assuming the subsidy or tax would be set at levels that would reduce carbon emissions by an equivalent amount.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Germany’s solar-energy subsidies to date have produced net social benefits for Germany.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question C: Solar-energy subsidies to date in Germany and other countries have produced net social benefits for the world.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Insights from psychology about individual behavior – examples of which include limited rationality, low self-control, or a taste for fairness – predict several important types of observed market outcomes that fully-rational economic models do not.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: The influx of refugees into Germany beginning in the summer of 2015 will generate net economic benefits for German citizens over the succeeding decade.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Holding labor market institutions and job training fixed, rising use of robots and artificial intelligence is likely to increase substantially the number of workers in advanced countries who are unemployed for long periods.
Comment: Some advanced countries have adequate institutions to facilitate the transition and a demography foreboding a shortage of workers.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Rising use of robots and artificial intelligence in advanced countries is likely to create benefits large enough that they could be used to compensate those workers who are substantially negatively affected for their lost wages.
Comment: Compensating the losers will require fiscal adaptations in order to improve the scope for redistribution

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Consumers will be better off, on balance, if European cities treat firms that provide ride-sharing platforms (such as Uber) as substantively different from taxi firms, and thus not necessarily warranting the same regulation.
Comment: I cannot answer the question before assessing the justification and efficiency of existing regulation.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Assuming that taxi and ride-sharing companies were treated as substantively similar — including requirements that they operate on an equal footing regarding safety, insurance and taxation — letting ride-sharing services compete without restrictions on prices or routes would raise consumer welfare.
Comment: With a level playing field I agree that the new form of competition brings in benefits. The legacy of past licensing has to be address, howe

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question C: Regardless of how ride-sharing services are treated, existing regulations for traditional taxi firms in many European cities harm consumers by limiting competition.
Comment: Some form of regulation may well be justified over the medium run even if it limits competition

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Revising France’s labor market policies — by reducing employment protection, decentralizing labor negotiations to the firm level, and making training programs more accessible and responsive to labor demands — would, all else equal, increase productivity in France’s economy.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Reducing employment protection would reduce the equilibrium unemployment rate in France.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: The ECB's asset purchases over the past two years have reduced the threat of deflation in the euro area as a whole.
Comment: I am skeptical that there was a real threat of deflation

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: If the economic outlook in the euro area becomes less favorable, then increasing the ECB's asset purchase program (in size or duration) would substantially increase the euro area's economic growth over the following five years.
Comment: I am not convinced that simply more of the same (QE) would have a significant impact at this stage.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: In general, absent any inside information, an equity investor can expect to do better by holding a well-diversified, low-fee, passive index fund than by holding a few stocks.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Without changes in policy, a rising share of people who are over age 65 will exert a substantial downward influence on per capita real GDP in western European countries.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: In European countries where the share of those over 65 is rising, there are net social benefits to adjusting retirement ages for state-financed (including pay-as-you-go) pension systems upwards, so that revised retirement ages better reflect longer life expectancies.
Comment: Promoting flexibility in the retirement age (with actuarially fair rent adjustments) is more important than compulsory later retirement

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, there are substantial advantages to having much of Europe’s human capital and infrastructure for international financial activity clustered in a single city, as they are at present in London.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: All else equal, Britain’s rules on hiring, firing and working hours are significantly more conducive to financial activity than those in other large European countries.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Setting the EU rules aside, and assuming it would take 2.5% of Italy’s GDP to recapitalize its banks, the Italian government would improve financial stability in Europe if it injected this amount of public funds into its banks.
Comment: The counterpart should be an equity stake in the banks that the Italian State could re-sell in the future hopefully with an overall profit

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: If Italy were to inject public funds into its banks without imposing losses on at least some claimants, an important cost would be the effect on future incentives (economic or political) in Europe.
Comment: But the cost could be containd if this is clearly viewed as a transition to a new regime where this will no longer be possible.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: On the whole, the shift from state to private ownership of many industrial assets in central and eastern European countries after communism has increased productivity in those countries.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: Instances of excessive mobility may have led to negative perceptions (feeling of being worse off)

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: Again inadequate policies are more to blame than mobility itself. Moreover many other low skilled workers have been made better off.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: but appropriate training and labour market policies have the overall impact of free trade positive for almost everyone in some countries

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: In general, using more congestion charges in crowded transportation networks — such as higher tolls during peak travel times in cities, and peak fees for airplane takeoff and landing slots — and using the proceeds to lower other taxes would make citizens on average better off.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Giving tax incentives to specific firms to locate operations in a country typically generates domestic benefits that outweigh the costs to the country providing the incentives.
Comment: It is a matter of self-interest for the region itself but there may be circumstances where the region's interests are not well represented.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Europe as a whole benefits when European cities or countries compete with each other by giving tax incentives to firms to locate operations in their jurisdictions.
Comment: Under transparent rules tax competition is positive, but this condition is often not met.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question A: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the UK's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: We do not know the terms of the Brexit. There is a possibility but small probability that the negotiated deal amounts to a status quo.

Name: Jean-Pierre Danthine
Qtext: Question B: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the rest of the EU's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: Brexit is a negative but it could lead the Europeans to adopt better policies in reaction

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Germany's current account surplus is undesirable even from a purely German viewpoint: the country would be better off if, for example, it ran a smaller primary surplus, in turn leading to a smaller current account surplus.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: The Eurozone would be in better shape if fiscal policy were more expansionary, which would allow monetary policy to be slightly less so.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question C: If there is a recession in the Eurozone, it will be essential to have a coordinated fiscal expansion.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: The European Union goal of reaching net zero emissions of greenhouse gases by 2050 will be a major drag on economic growth.
Comment:
My 2016 JPE paper with Aghion et al showed how carbon taxes (and R&D policies) could direct technical change towards cleaner innovation
-see background information here

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Carbon taxes are a better way to implement climate policy than cap-and-trade.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question C: A carbon border tax targeting imports from non-EU countries with less strict climate policies is likely to harm developing economies.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Following the UK election result, the certainty that the country is going to leave the European Union will provide a substantial short-term boost to the UK economy.
Comment:
Brexit is a certain economic bad, so the fact this will happen outweighs any benefits from the reduction in uncertainty
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Given that the transition period currently expires at the end of 2020, there is still a considerable risk that the UK will leave the European Union without a trade agreement.
Comment:
Government announced it will legislate against extension. Although it could change this, it makes no-deal more likely
-see background information here

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question C: Leaving the European Union without a trade agreement would have a large negative impact on the UK economy.
Comment:
It's obvious that driving up trade costs with UK's neighbours will mean lower incomes, and the bigger the trade cost the more the damage
-see background information here

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Under current policies on climate change, the associated physical risks (such as those arising from total seasonal rainfall and sea level changes, and increased frequency, severity, and correlation of extreme weather events) will be at most a very small factor in monetary policy decisions over the next decade.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: The physical risks associated with climate change under current policies are likely to threaten financial stability over the next decade.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public R&D spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private R&D spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public medical research spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private medical research spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for answering some long unsettled questions in development economics research.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for making significant progress in poverty reduction.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Having companies run to maximize shareholder value creates significant negative externalities for workers and communities.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Appropriately managed corporations could create significantly greater value than they currently do for a range of stakeholders – including workers, suppliers, customers and community members – with small impacts on shareholder value.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext:
Question C:
Effective mechanisms for boards of directors to ensure that CEOs act in ways that balance the interests of all stakeholders would be straightforward to introduce.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Rising inequality is straining the health of liberal democracy.
Comment:
Inequality & stagnation of median pay more of an influence; e.g. Brexit
-see background information here

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Enacting more redistributive expenditures and policies would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question C: European governments should allocate more resources to policies that would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe, even if it means higher public debt or lower public spending in other areas.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: At this point, there is little that the European Central Bank can do to increase or maintain output in the Eurozone.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: When the economy is operating below its potential, larger fiscal deficits are likely to increase demand and output.
Comment: Lots of evidence now of the positive effect fiscal policy at zero lower bound

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question C: When the economy is operating below its potential and monetary policy is at the effective lower bound, fiscal policy should prioritize increasing output over decreasing public debt.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Selecting candidates for membership of the ECB Executive Board based primarily on nationality ahead of competence is likely to have a negative effect on the quality of monetary policy in the Eurozone.
Comment:
See family firms work: choosing leaders based on connections rather than talent generally leads to disaster
-see background information here

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Although the central bank can never be an entirely technocratic institution, the selection process for the ECB President and members of the Executive Board is significantly worsened by intergovernmental trade-offs involving appointments to other European institutions.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: On bids for infrastructure projects, the average European would be better off if Europe’s governments favored European firms over Chinese firms (or firms from any other country with non-profit-related geopolitical strategies) — even if it means sometimes choosing a higher-cost bidder.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Breaking the “doom loop” — a negative spiral that can result when banks hold sovereign bonds and governments bail out banks — would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Regulators should try to break the doom loop by assigning positive risk weights — in calculating banks’ capital requirements — to banks’ holdings of domestic and other Eurozone sovereign bonds.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question C: Breaking the doom loop would impose substantial costs on powerful political constituencies.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Residents of big European cities would be better off, on balance, if governments did more to counter gentrification, for example by using rent and other housing subsidies, public housing investments, zoning regulations, or similar policies.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the likelihood of another financial crisis in Europe.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Overall, public spending on the arts in Europe creates benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Additional public spending on the arts in Europe would create incremental benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.

Name: John Van Reenen

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: If China and other countries use policies that create giant international firms, then the average European is better off if Europe's competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: A switch from quarterly to annual earnings reports would, on net, benefit shareholders of European firms.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: To the extent that Norway’s global government pension fund makes investments for social and environmental objectives — apart from investments that would bring the highest expected risk-adjusted returns — it improves the welfare of Norwegians.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: The fiscal rules of the European Union should give more flexibility to member countries.
Comment: Eurocrisis period showed that Commission had too much of a pro-austerity bias

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: The Italian budget for 2019 that the European Commission rejected in October would have increased Italy’s risk of fiscal insolvency substantially.

Name: John Van Reenen

Qtext:
Question B:
To achieve a given level of congestion, it would be better to use taxes for driving that vary based on the level of congestion, rather than limiting the number of ride-sharing vehicles.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: People who migrated to Europe between 2015 and 2018 are likely — over the next two decades — to contribute more in taxes paid than they receive in benefits and public services.
Comment:
At least in terms of the UK, there have been generally positive fiscal benefits. See my work below or recent MAC report by alan Manning
-see background information here

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Ideas are nonrival, so increasing returns to scale is an essential feature of technological change in a market economy.
Comment:
Ideas are non-rival hence do not get constant returns to scale at macro-level because standard replication argument breaks down.
-see background information here

Qtext:
Question A: The European Commission has proposed new rules to ensure that “digital business activities are taxed in a fair and growth-friendly way in the EU”. Consider two statements regarding this proposal:
An EU-wide 3% tax on revenue from digital activities would, on balance, be a good idea.
Comment: There needs to be a good rationale for further distorting tax system in this way and if don’t see it.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext:
Question B:
If the EU decides to tax digital service providers, it would be better — given the difficulties of measuring and verifying digital activity — to tax them on the revenue, rather than the profits, that they generate locally.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: The European Union often uses its antitrust powers to protect EU-based firms from international competition, rather than to promote greater competition in European markets.
Comment:
EU anti-trust policy similar to US, but enforced more vigorously
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Trade with China makes most Europeans better off because, among other advantages, they can buy goods that are made or assembled more cheaply in China.
Comment:
Chinese trade has also simulated productivity growth and innovation in Europe - see link
-see background information here

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Some Europeans who work in the production of competing goods, such as clothing and furniture, are made worse off by trade with China.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question C: If the EU followed the new US steel tariffs by imposing similar EU tariffs on steel from China, it would improve Europeans’ welfare.

Comment:
My work shows that prices are major driver of private US healthcare spending. This is related to market power of hospitals
-see background information here

Qtext: Over the past two years, all else equal, the appeal of the US as a destination for immigrants has changed in ways that will likely decrease innovation in the US economy.

Comment: Reduce harmful tax competition

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: If other policies were held fixed and every European country taxed corporate profits at a common rate of 20%, then reducing that common rate substantially below 20% would make the average European better off.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Taking into account the likely effects on investments in human capital by men and women, setting quotas throughout Europe for a minimum number of women board members would generate substantial net benefits for Europeans.

Comment: Carbon taxes can be very effective in steering technical change & doesn't require so direction http://cep.lse.ac.uk/pubs/download/dp1178.pdf

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Germany’s solar-energy subsidies to date have produced net social benefits for Germany.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question C: Solar-energy subsidies to date in Germany and other countries have produced net social benefits for the world.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Holding labor market institutions and job training fixed, rising use of robots and artificial intelligence is likely to increase substantially the number of workers in advanced countries who are unemployed for long periods.
Comment:
Hard to predict impact of technology on jobs with our current levels of knowledge. Innovation often has positive as well as negative effects
-see background information here

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Rising use of robots and artificial intelligence in advanced countries is likely to create benefits large enough that they could be used to compensate those workers who are substantially negatively affected for their lost wages.
Comment:
Technology expands the economic pie, so definitely offers chances to share greater wealth
-see background information here

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Consumers will be better off, on balance, if European cities treat firms that provide ride-sharing platforms (such as Uber) as substantively different from taxi firms, and thus not necessarily warranting the same regulation.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Assuming that taxi and ride-sharing companies were treated as substantively similar — including requirements that they operate on an equal footing regarding safety, insurance and taxation — letting ride-sharing services compete without restrictions on prices or routes would raise consumer welfare.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question C: Regardless of how ride-sharing services are treated, existing regulations for traditional taxi firms in many European cities harm consumers by limiting competition.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Revising France’s labor market policies — by reducing employment protection, decentralizing labor negotiations to the firm level, and making training programs more accessible and responsive to labor demands — would, all else equal, increase productivity in France’s economy.
Comment:
My 2016 AER piece shows a French GDP loss of about 3.4% due to heavy labor regulation for firms over 50 employees
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Reducing employment protection would reduce the equilibrium unemployment rate in France.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: The ECB's asset purchases over the past two years have reduced the threat of deflation in the euro area as a whole.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: If the economic outlook in the euro area becomes less favorable, then increasing the ECB's asset purchase program (in size or duration) would substantially increase the euro area's economic growth over the following five years.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: In general, absent any inside information, an equity investor can expect to do better by holding a well-diversified, low-fee, passive index fund than by holding a few stocks.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Without changes in policy, a rising share of people who are over age 65 will exert a substantial downward influence on per capita real GDP in western European countries.
Comment: Key thing is to extend working life through extending retirement age and making it more flexible to enable healthy older people to wrok

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: In European countries where the share of those over 65 is rising, there are net social benefits to adjusting retirement ages for state-financed (including pay-as-you-go) pension systems upwards, so that revised retirement ages better reflect longer life expectancies.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, there are substantial advantages to having much of Europe’s human capital and infrastructure for international financial activity clustered in a single city, as they are at present in London.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: All else equal, Britain’s rules on hiring, firing and working hours are significantly more conducive to financial activity than those in other large European countries.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Setting the EU rules aside, and assuming it would take 2.5% of Italy’s GDP to recapitalize its banks, the Italian government would improve financial stability in Europe if it injected this amount of public funds into its banks.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: If Italy were to inject public funds into its banks without imposing losses on at least some claimants, an important cost would be the effect on future incentives (economic or political) in Europe.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: On the whole, the shift from state to private ownership of many industrial assets in central and eastern European countries after communism has increased productivity in those countries.

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment:
People sort according to their comparative advantage. Complement to other EU freedoms
-see background information here

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: Main wage effect of immigrants is small & is on previous cohorts of immigrants

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: Numerous studies, especially of the impact of single market

Name: John Van Reenen
