Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment:
Overall income growth is greater; no obvious differential impact by skill (all relatively wealthy countries). Our Brexit analysis summarises
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: In general, using more congestion charges in crowded transportation networks — such as higher tolls during peak travel times in cities, and peak fees for airplane takeoff and landing slots — and using the proceeds to lower other taxes would make citizens on average better off.
Comment: The most efficient way to make use of congested resources. Just lacks political will

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Giving tax incentives to specific firms to locate operations in a country typically generates domestic benefits that outweigh the costs to the country providing the incentives.
Comment: Most of benefits are typically appropriated by firms themselves. Best way to get FDI is to improve skills, rule of law, local public goods

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Europe as a whole benefits when European cities or countries compete with each other by giving tax incentives to firms to locate operations in their jurisdictions.
Comment: Sets up a race to the bottom in terms of taxation

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question A: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the UK's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment:
Extensive work on this by myself, CEP, LSE, NIESR, etc. Trade costs with closest UK trading partner rise so trade & FDI fall. Incomes lower
-see background information here

Name: John Van Reenen
Qtext: Question B: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the rest of the EU's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment:
Because trade costs will rise with UK's closest neighbours, trade and FDI will fall. This depresses income (see work by CEP, NIESR, PWC, etc
-see background information here

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Germany's current account surplus is undesirable even from a purely German viewpoint: the country would be better off if, for example, it ran a smaller primary surplus, in turn leading to a smaller current account surplus.
Comment: More spending on infrastructure would appear particularly desirable

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: The Eurozone would be in better shape if fiscal policy were more expansionary, which would allow monetary policy to be slightly less so.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question C: If there is a recession in the Eurozone, it will be essential to have a coordinated fiscal expansion.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: The European Union goal of reaching net zero emissions of greenhouse gases by 2050 will be a major drag on economic growth.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Carbon taxes are a better way to implement climate policy than cap-and-trade.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question C: A carbon border tax targeting imports from non-EU countries with less strict climate policies is likely to harm developing economies.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Following the UK election result, the certainty that the country is going to leave the European Union will provide a substantial short-term boost to the UK economy.
Comment: Net effect of withdrawal certainty and heightened trade agreement uncertainty, given PM's commitment not to extend transition, is unclear

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Given that the transition period currently expires at the end of 2020, there is still a considerable risk that the UK will leave the European Union without a trade agreement.
Comment: Clear risk of UK/EU not concluding trade agreement in 2020, even for goods only. Irony that risk reduces the more UK aligns with EU rules.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question C: Leaving the European Union without a trade agreement would have a large negative impact on the UK economy.
Comment: Absence of trade agreement with UK's main trading partner would be a large negative supply shock at least in the short term

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Under current policies on climate change, the associated physical risks (such as those arising from total seasonal rainfall and sea level changes, and increased frequency, severity, and correlation of extreme weather events) will be at most a very small factor in monetary policy decisions over the next decade.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: The physical risks associated with climate change under current policies are likely to threaten financial stability over the next decade.
Comment: If such risks do threaten financial stability, it will be mainly because financial regulation (eg of bank capital) is too weak

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public R&D spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private R&D spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.
Comment: Public R&D might well be better directed but if near optimal to start with, private R&D externalities could do more good at the margin

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public medical research spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private medical research spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for answering some long unsettled questions in development economics research.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for making significant progress in poverty reduction.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Having companies run to maximize shareholder value creates significant negative externalities for workers and communities.
Comment: Uncertain because much depends on surrounding public policies towards such externalities.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Appropriately managed corporations could create significantly greater value than they currently do for a range of stakeholders – including workers, suppliers, customers and community members – with small impacts on shareholder value.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext:
Question C:
Effective mechanisms for boards of directors to ensure that CEOs act in ways that balance the interests of all stakeholders would be straightforward to introduce.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Rising inequality is straining the health of liberal democracy.
Comment: The health of liberal democracy is under strain not only in countries where inequality has risen

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Enacting more redistributive expenditures and policies would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe.
Comment: Causes of the rise of populism do not seem well enough understood

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question C: European governments should allocate more resources to policies that would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe, even if it means higher public debt or lower public spending in other areas.
Comment: While some policies that might curb the rise of populism in Europe have merit, some others plainly do not

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: At this point, there is little that the European Central Bank can do to increase or maintain output in the Eurozone.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: When the economy is operating below its potential, larger fiscal deficits are likely to increase demand and output.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question C: When the economy is operating below its potential and monetary policy is at the effective lower bound, fiscal policy should prioritize increasing output over decreasing public debt.
Comment: Yes if fiscal position is sound but not necessarily otherwise

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Selecting candidates for membership of the ECB Executive Board based primarily on nationality ahead of competence is likely to have a negative effect on the quality of monetary policy in the Eurozone.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Although the central bank can never be an entirely technocratic institution, the selection process for the ECB President and members of the Executive Board is significantly worsened by intergovernmental trade-offs involving appointments to other European institutions.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: On bids for infrastructure projects, the average European would be better off if Europe’s governments favored European firms over Chinese firms (or firms from any other country with non-profit-related geopolitical strategies) — even if it means sometimes choosing a higher-cost bidder.
Comment: It depends on whether there are serious security issues in play. If not, don't restrict bidders.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Breaking the “doom loop” — a negative spiral that can result when banks hold sovereign bonds and governments bail out banks — would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.
Comment: Breaking the doom loop would help but, irrespective of sovereign bond holdings, European banks need to be much better capitalised.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Regulators should try to break the doom loop by assigning positive risk weights — in calculating banks’ capital requirements — to banks’ holdings of domestic and other Eurozone sovereign bonds.
Comment: Sovereign bonds should plainly have positive risk weights in some circumstances, for obvious risk reasons, not just doom loop reasons.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question C: Breaking the doom loop would impose substantial costs on powerful political constituencies.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Residents of big European cities would be better off, on balance, if governments did more to counter gentrification, for example by using rent and other housing subsidies, public housing investments, zoning regulations, or similar policies.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.
Comment: But other measures matter more -- e.g. depositor preference for insured deposits. Then, if(??) resolution works, deposits are safe anyway.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the likelihood of another financial crisis in Europe.
Comment: Uncertain because could distract from more fundamental issues such as the need for European banks to have much more capital

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Overall, public spending on the arts in Europe creates benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Additional public spending on the arts in Europe would create incremental benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: The average European is better off if Europe’s competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.
Comment: Weakening of competition is likely to be negative, not positive, for the efficiency of European firms. So not the way to promote champions.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: If China and other countries use policies that create giant international firms, then the average European is better off if Europe's competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Letting publicly traded European firms report earnings annually rather than quarterly would lead their executives to place more weight on long-term issues in their investments and other decisions.
Comment: The change would heighten incentive problems around the annual results even if it eased the quarterly issues. Net effect unclear.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: A switch from quarterly to annual earnings reports would, on net, benefit shareholders of European firms.
Comment: Shareholders of such firms need more than annual visibility of corporate performance

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: To the extent that public corporations pursue social and environmental initiatives, they tend to achieve higher risk-adjusted (private) returns than otherwise similar corporations that pursue such initiatives less.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: To the extent that Norway’s global government pension fund makes investments for social and environmental objectives — apart from investments that would bring the highest expected risk-adjusted returns — it improves the welfare of Norwegians.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: The fiscal rules of the European Union should give more flexibility to member countries.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: The Italian budget for 2019 that the European Commission rejected in October would have increased Italy’s risk of fiscal insolvency substantially.
Comment: See bond yields

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question C: If France runs a 2019 budget deficit of around 3.4% of GDP, as announced by President Macron’s government, France’s risk of fiscal insolvency will increase substantially.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Capping the number of ride-sharing drivers as is being discussed in New York City, Chicago and London will make the average resident in that city worse off.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext:
Question B:
To achieve a given level of congestion, it would be better to use taxes for driving that vary based on the level of congestion, rather than limiting the number of ride-sharing vehicles.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: People who migrated to Europe between 2015 and 2018 are likely — over the next two decades — to contribute more in taxes paid than they receive in benefits and public services.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Ideas are nonrival, so increasing returns to scale is an essential feature of technological change in a market economy.
Comment: Assuming the question means increasing returns in production of output (as distinct from production of new technologies)

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Voters overestimate the effect that current governments have on their economies’ concurrent economic performance.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Over the next decade, autonomous cars will raise average welfare in the EU by at least as much as smartphones have over the past decade.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext:
Britain’s Labour party recently proposed giving the Bank of England a target of 3% annual labor productivity growth. Consider the following statement:
Central banks cannot significantly increase productivity growth over a ten year horizon, except perhaps by promoting macroeconomic stability.
Comment: Financial stability -- e.g. more bank equity capital -- helps investment incentives and productivity (but maybe is part of macro stability)

Name: John Vickers
Qtext:
Question A: The European Commission has proposed new rules to ensure that “digital business activities are taxed in a fair and growth-friendly way in the EU”. Consider two statements regarding this proposal:
An EU-wide 3% tax on revenue from digital activities would, on balance, be a good idea.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext:
Question B:
If the EU decides to tax digital service providers, it would be better — given the difficulties of measuring and verifying digital activity — to tax them on the revenue, rather than the profits, that they generate locally.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: The European Union often uses its antitrust powers to protect EU-based firms from international competition, rather than to promote greater competition in European markets.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Trade with China makes most Europeans better off because, among other advantages, they can buy goods that are made or assembled more cheaply in China.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Some Europeans who work in the production of competing goods, such as clothing and furniture, are made worse off by trade with China.
Comment:
Wider long-term gains from trade may offset short-run losses for workers in such sectors.
-see background information here

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question C: If the EU followed the new US steel tariffs by imposing similar EU tariffs on steel from China, it would improve Europeans’ welfare.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Assuming it exits its third bailout program this summer without an immediate restructuring or other debt relief, Greece is unlikely to default on its sovereign debt in the coming decade.
Comment: 10Y bond yield of 4.2% is well above bunds but does not suggest that default is more likely than not

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Greece would be better off if it had decided to exit the euro between 2011 and 2015.
Comment: Major exit costs v some benefits of devaluation. Euro-denominated debt would still need servicing.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question C: If Greece had defaulted on (or restructured) its private debt in 2010, while also staying within the euro, that combination would have been better for Greece than either exiting the euro or proceeding as it has actually done.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to currency.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to Dutch tulips in the 1630s.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext:
The US spends roughly 17% of GDP on healthcare, according to the OECD; most European countries spend less than 12% of GDP.

Higher quality-adjusted US healthcare prices contribute relatively more to the extra US spending than does the combination of higher quantity and quality of US care (interpreting quantity and quality to reflect both greater American healthcare needs due to underlying population health and the delivery of more or better healthcare services to Americans).

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Over the past two years, all else equal, the appeal of the US as a destination for immigrants has changed in ways that will likely decrease innovation in the US economy.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Holding other policies fixed, the average European would be better off if every European country taxed corporate profits at a rate of 20% (based as closely as possible on a common definition of profits).

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: If other policies were held fixed and every European country taxed corporate profits at a common rate of 20%, then reducing that common rate substantially below 20% would make the average European better off.
Comment: Answer might be different if other policies not held fixed

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, if corporations throughout Europe set quotas for a minimum number of women board members, the shareholder value of European companies would increase.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Taking into account the likely effects on investments in human capital by men and women, setting quotas throughout Europe for a minimum number of women board members would generate substantial net benefits for Europeans.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Subsidizing renewable energy sources is better than taxing fossil fuels, assuming the subsidy or tax would be set at levels that would reduce carbon emissions by an equivalent amount.
Comment: Activities that generate negative externalities need direct discouragement

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Germany’s solar-energy subsidies to date have produced net social benefits for Germany.
Comment: They look a high-cost way to get the benefits, many of which are non-German. Hard to judge the net effect.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question C: Solar-energy subsidies to date in Germany and other countries have produced net social benefits for the world.
Comment: Again they look a high-cost way of doing it, even allowing for dynamic cost-reduction effects on solar power.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Insights from psychology about individual behavior – examples of which include limited rationality, low self-control, or a taste for fairness – predict several important types of observed market outcomes that fully-rational economic models do not.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: The influx of refugees into Germany beginning in the summer of 2015 will generate net economic benefits for German citizens over the succeeding decade.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Holding labor market institutions and job training fixed, rising use of robots and artificial intelligence is likely to increase substantially the number of workers in advanced countries who are unemployed for long periods.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Rising use of robots and artificial intelligence in advanced countries is likely to create benefits large enough that they could be used to compensate those workers who are substantially negatively affected for their lost wages.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Consumers will be better off, on balance, if European cities treat firms that provide ride-sharing platforms (such as Uber) as substantively different from taxi firms, and thus not necessarily warranting the same regulation.
Comment: New technology changes the nature and extent of market failure. (De)regulation should reflect that.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Assuming that taxi and ride-sharing companies were treated as substantively similar — including requirements that they operate on an equal footing regarding safety, insurance and taxation — letting ride-sharing services compete without restrictions on prices or routes would raise consumer welfare.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question C: Regardless of how ride-sharing services are treated, existing regulations for traditional taxi firms in many European cities harm consumers by limiting competition.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Revising France’s labor market policies — by reducing employment protection, decentralizing labor negotiations to the firm level, and making training programs more accessible and responsive to labor demands — would, all else equal, increase productivity in France’s economy.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Reducing employment protection would reduce the equilibrium unemployment rate in France.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: The ECB's asset purchases over the past two years have reduced the threat of deflation in the euro area as a whole.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: If the economic outlook in the euro area becomes less favorable, then increasing the ECB's asset purchase program (in size or duration) would substantially increase the euro area's economic growth over the following five years.
Comment: Diminishing returns to such a policy

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: In general, absent any inside information, an equity investor can expect to do better by holding a well-diversified, low-fee, passive index fund than by holding a few stocks.
Comment: Assuming a degree of risk aversion. However some investors might rationally want some exposure to assets not available passively.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Without changes in policy, a rising share of people who are over age 65 will exert a substantial downward influence on per capita real GDP in western European countries.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: In European countries where the share of those over 65 is rising, there are net social benefits to adjusting retirement ages for state-financed (including pay-as-you-go) pension systems upwards, so that revised retirement ages better reflect longer life expectancies.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, there are substantial advantages to having much of Europe’s human capital and infrastructure for international financial activity clustered in a single city, as they are at present in London.
Comment: Large economies of agglomeration. But caveat that the hub is sensibly regulated and not prone to collusion.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: All else equal, Britain’s rules on hiring, firing and working hours are significantly more conducive to financial activity than those in other large European countries.
Comment: Ratio of value of flexibility to that of working terms regulation is relatively high in finance. UK is somewhat freer than most of EU.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Setting the EU rules aside, and assuming it would take 2.5% of Italy’s GDP to recapitalize its banks, the Italian government would improve financial stability in Europe if it injected this amount of public funds into its banks.
Comment: Banks have far too little capital so more is good. But another bail out would go backwards on incentives. A total mess, not only Italy.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: If Italy were to inject public funds into its banks without imposing losses on at least some claimants, an important cost would be the effect on future incentives (economic or political) in Europe.
Comment: A 100% bail-out after 8 years of "reform" would take us back to square one on TBTF.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: On the whole, the shift from state to private ownership of many industrial assets in central and eastern European countries after communism has increased productivity in those countries.
Comment: Gains have come from pro-market reforms more generally, but privatization was a pre-condition.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: In general, using more congestion charges in crowded transportation networks — such as higher tolls during peak travel times in cities, and peak fees for airplane takeoff and landing slots — and using the proceeds to lower other taxes would make citizens on average better off.
Comment: Curbing externalities while raising revenue is doubly good. But charging system may itself have cost.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Giving tax incentives to specific firms to locate operations in a country typically generates domestic benefits that outweigh the costs to the country providing the incentives.
Comment: Risks of over-estimating value of inducing location and of 'overpaying' for it.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Europe as a whole benefits when European cities or countries compete with each other by giving tax incentives to firms to locate operations in their jurisdictions.

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question A: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the UK's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: Brexit is v probably (but not certainly) bad for trade and investment. The £ drop reflects this but is an efficient way to be worse off..

Name: John Vickers
Qtext: Question B: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the rest of the EU's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: Trade uncertainty bad for EU too. Necessary EU reforms less likely without UK.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Germany's current account surplus is undesirable even from a purely German viewpoint: the country would be better off if, for example, it ran a smaller primary surplus, in turn leading to a smaller current account surplus.
Comment: "De gustibus non est disputandum"

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: The Eurozone would be in better shape if fiscal policy were more expansionary, which would allow monetary policy to be slightly less so.
Comment: Noy full employment yet in many countries. Low inflationary pressures. Limited room for more monetary loosening.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question C: If there is a recession in the Eurozone, it will be essential to have a coordinated fiscal expansion.
Comment: Need for a coordinated response (to avoid free riding), and given no room for robust monetary policy response.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: The European Union goal of reaching net zero emissions of greenhouse gases by 2050 will be a major drag on economic growth.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Carbon taxes are a better way to implement climate policy than cap-and-trade.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question C: A carbon border tax targeting imports from non-EU countries with less strict climate policies is likely to harm developing economies.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Following the UK election result, the certainty that the country is going to leave the European Union will provide a substantial short-term boost to the UK economy.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Given that the transition period currently expires at the end of 2020, there is still a considerable risk that the UK will leave the European Union without a trade agreement.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question C: Leaving the European Union without a trade agreement would have a large negative impact on the UK economy.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Under current policies on climate change, the associated physical risks (such as those arising from total seasonal rainfall and sea level changes, and increased frequency, severity, and correlation of extreme weather events) will be at most a very small factor in monetary policy decisions over the next decade.
Comment: I don't know if they will be an important factor, but I believe they should not be. There must be better tools to fight CC.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: The physical risks associated with climate change under current policies are likely to threaten financial stability over the next decade.
Comment: I'd think the next decade is too short a horizon to see any impact.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public R&D spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private R&D spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public medical research spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private medical research spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for answering some long unsettled questions in development economics research.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for making significant progress in poverty reduction.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Having companies run to maximize shareholder value creates significant negative externalities for workers and communities.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Appropriately managed corporations could create significantly greater value than they currently do for a range of stakeholders – including workers, suppliers, customers and community members – with small impacts on shareholder value.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext:
Question C:
Effective mechanisms for boards of directors to ensure that CEOs act in ways that balance the interests of all stakeholders would be straightforward to introduce.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Rising inequality is straining the health of liberal democracy.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Enacting more redistributive expenditures and policies would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question C: European governments should allocate more resources to policies that would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe, even if it means higher public debt or lower public spending in other areas.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: At this point, there is little that the European Central Bank can do to increase or maintain output in the Eurozone.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: When the economy is operating below its potential, larger fiscal deficits are likely to increase demand and output.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question C: When the economy is operating below its potential and monetary policy is at the effective lower bound, fiscal policy should prioritize increasing output over decreasing public debt.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Selecting candidates for membership of the ECB Executive Board based primarily on nationality ahead of competence is likely to have a negative effect on the quality of monetary policy in the Eurozone.
Comment: It is a self-evident proposition. Nationality seems as good a criterion as weight for the issue at hand.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Although the central bank can never be an entirely technocratic institution, the selection process for the ECB President and members of the Executive Board is significantly worsened by intergovernmental trade-offs involving appointments to other European institutions.
Comment: This is just an additional proof that, whether we like it or not, the EU is little more than intergovernmental agreement.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: On bids for infrastructure projects, the average European would be better off if Europe’s governments favored European firms over Chinese firms (or firms from any other country with non-profit-related geopolitical strategies) — even if it means sometimes choosing a higher-cost bidder.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Breaking the “doom loop” — a negative spiral that can result when banks hold sovereign bonds and governments bail out banks — would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Regulators should try to break the doom loop by assigning positive risk weights — in calculating banks’ capital requirements — to banks’ holdings of domestic and other Eurozone sovereign bonds.
Comment: Not doing so may raise serious questions about the independence of regulators. There is no such a thing as risk-free debt.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question C: Breaking the doom loop would impose substantial costs on powerful political constituencies.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Residents of big European cities would be better off, on balance, if governments did more to counter gentrification, for example by using rent and other housing subsidies, public housing investments, zoning regulations, or similar policies.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the likelihood of another financial crisis in Europe.
Comment: Not with adequate supervision and macroprudential policies

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Overall, public spending on the arts in Europe creates benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Additional public spending on the arts in Europe would create incremental benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: The average European is better off if Europe’s competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: If China and other countries use policies that create giant international firms, then the average European is better off if Europe's competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Letting publicly traded European firms report earnings annually rather than quarterly would lead their executives to place more weight on long-term issues in their investments and other decisions.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: A switch from quarterly to annual earnings reports would, on net, benefit shareholders of European firms.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: To the extent that public corporations pursue social and environmental initiatives, they tend to achieve higher risk-adjusted (private) returns than otherwise similar corporations that pursue such initiatives less.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: To the extent that Norway’s global government pension fund makes investments for social and environmental objectives — apart from investments that would bring the highest expected risk-adjusted returns — it improves the welfare of Norwegians.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: The fiscal rules of the European Union should give more flexibility to member countries.
Comment:
Given the limited synchronisation, and the single monetary policy, it is desirable to have a strong stabilizing tool at the country level.
-see background information here

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: The Italian budget for 2019 that the European Commission rejected in October would have increased Italy’s risk of fiscal insolvency substantially.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question C: If France runs a 2019 budget deficit of around 3.4% of GDP, as announced by President Macron’s government, France’s risk of fiscal insolvency will increase substantially.
Comment: Not if the increase is transitory. Developments in r, g and pi may dominate the impact of a small increase in the structural deficit

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Capping the number of ride-sharing drivers as is being discussed in New York City, Chicago and London will make the average resident in that city worse off.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext:
Question B:
To achieve a given level of congestion, it would be better to use taxes for driving that vary based on the level of congestion, rather than limiting the number of ride-sharing vehicles.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: People who migrated to Europe between 2015 and 2018 are likely — over the next two decades — to contribute more in taxes paid than they receive in benefits and public services.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Ideas are nonrival, so increasing returns to scale is an essential feature of technological change in a market economy.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Voters overestimate the effect that current governments have on their economies’ concurrent economic performance.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Over the next decade, autonomous cars will raise average welfare in the EU by at least as much as smartphones have over the past decade.
Comment: Have smartphones raised average welfare?

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext:
Britain’s Labour party recently proposed giving the Bank of England a target of 3% annual labor productivity growth. Consider the following statement:
Central banks cannot significantly increase productivity growth over a ten year horizon, except perhaps by promoting macroeconomic stability.
Comment: And it is doubtful the reducing macro stability further in the UK would attain any significant gains in terms of productivity growth.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext:
Question A: The European Commission has proposed new rules to ensure that “digital business activities are taxed in a fair and growth-friendly way in the EU”. Consider two statements regarding this proposal:
An EU-wide 3% tax on revenue from digital activities would, on balance, be a good idea.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext:
Question B:
If the EU decides to tax digital service providers, it would be better — given the difficulties of measuring and verifying digital activity — to tax them on the revenue, rather than the profits, that they generate locally.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: The European Union often uses its antitrust powers to protect EU-based firms from international competition, rather than to promote greater competition in European markets.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Trade with China makes most Europeans better off because, among other advantages, they can buy goods that are made or assembled more cheaply in China.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Some Europeans who work in the production of competing goods, such as clothing and furniture, are made worse off by trade with China.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question C: If the EU followed the new US steel tariffs by imposing similar EU tariffs on steel from China, it would improve Europeans’ welfare.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Assuming it exits its third bailout program this summer without an immediate restructuring or other debt relief, Greece is unlikely to default on its sovereign debt in the coming decade.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Greece would be better off if it had decided to exit the euro between 2011 and 2015.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question C: If Greece had defaulted on (or restructured) its private debt in 2010, while also staying within the euro, that combination would have been better for Greece than either exiting the euro or proceeding as it has actually done.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to currency.
Comment: Bitcoins, like currency, are used as a means of payment. Gold is not. Gold has a fundamental value.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to Dutch tulips in the 1630s.
Comment: Like the price of Dutch tulips in the 1630s, bitcoins' price seems to have a large bubble component. Gold's is likely smaller.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext:
The US spends roughly 17% of GDP on healthcare, according to the OECD; most European countries spend less than 12% of GDP.

Higher quality-adjusted US healthcare prices contribute relatively more to the extra US spending than does the combination of higher quantity and quality of US care (interpreting quantity and quality to reflect both greater American healthcare needs due to underlying population health and the delivery of more or better healthcare services to Americans).

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Over the past two years, all else equal, the appeal of the US as a destination for immigrants has changed in ways that will likely decrease innovation in the US economy.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Holding other policies fixed, the average European would be better off if every European country taxed corporate profits at a rate of 20% (based as closely as possible on a common definition of profits).

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: If other policies were held fixed and every European country taxed corporate profits at a common rate of 20%, then reducing that common rate substantially below 20% would make the average European better off.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, if corporations throughout Europe set quotas for a minimum number of women board members, the shareholder value of European companies would increase.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Taking into account the likely effects on investments in human capital by men and women, setting quotas throughout Europe for a minimum number of women board members would generate substantial net benefits for Europeans.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Subsidizing renewable energy sources is better than taxing fossil fuels, assuming the subsidy or tax would be set at levels that would reduce carbon emissions by an equivalent amount.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Germany’s solar-energy subsidies to date have produced net social benefits for Germany.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question C: Solar-energy subsidies to date in Germany and other countries have produced net social benefits for the world.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Insights from psychology about individual behavior – examples of which include limited rationality, low self-control, or a taste for fairness – predict several important types of observed market outcomes that fully-rational economic models do not.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: The influx of refugees into Germany beginning in the summer of 2015 will generate net economic benefits for German citizens over the succeeding decade.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Holding labor market institutions and job training fixed, rising use of robots and artificial intelligence is likely to increase substantially the number of workers in advanced countries who are unemployed for long periods.
Comment: Must be true in the short run, unless it takes place in the context of expanding aggregate demand, which would facilitate reabsoption

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Rising use of robots and artificial intelligence in advanced countries is likely to create benefits large enough that they could be used to compensate those workers who are substantially negatively affected for their lost wages.
Comment: True in theory. In practice, it will depend on the transfers system in place and other elements determined by the political process

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Consumers will be better off, on balance, if European cities treat firms that provide ride-sharing platforms (such as Uber) as substantively different from taxi firms, and thus not necessarily warranting the same regulation.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Assuming that taxi and ride-sharing companies were treated as substantively similar — including requirements that they operate on an equal footing regarding safety, insurance and taxation — letting ride-sharing services compete without restrictions on prices or routes would raise consumer welfare.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question C: Regardless of how ride-sharing services are treated, existing regulations for traditional taxi firms in many European cities harm consumers by limiting competition.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Revising France’s labor market policies — by reducing employment protection, decentralizing labor negotiations to the firm level, and making training programs more accessible and responsive to labor demands — would, all else equal, increase productivity in France’s economy.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Reducing employment protection would reduce the equilibrium unemployment rate in France.
Comment: It is likely to increase employment volatility (bad, it may improve efficiency (good), but the effect on the unemployment rate is unclear.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: The ECB's asset purchases over the past two years have reduced the threat of deflation in the euro area as a whole.
Comment:
The evidence (e.g. Andrade et al. (2016)) points to reductions in risk premia as well as in expected future policy rates at announcement.
-see background information here

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: If the economic outlook in the euro area becomes less favorable, then increasing the ECB's asset purchase program (in size or duration) would substantially increase the euro area's economic growth over the following five years.
Comment:
It could help marginally by exploiting the same channels, though possibly with decreasing returns. But alternatives exist: fiscal policy.
-see background information here

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: In general, absent any inside information, an equity investor can expect to do better by holding a well-diversified, low-fee, passive index fund than by holding a few stocks.
Comment: I agree with the statement as "doing better" is interpreted to mean enjoying a higher average return for any given level of risk.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Without changes in policy, a rising share of people who are over age 65 will exert a substantial downward influence on per capita real GDP in western European countries.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: In European countries where the share of those over 65 is rising, there are net social benefits to adjusting retirement ages for state-financed (including pay-as-you-go) pension systems upwards, so that revised retirement ages better reflect longer life expectancies.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, there are substantial advantages to having much of Europe’s human capital and infrastructure for international financial activity clustered in a single city, as they are at present in London.
Comment: There may be a tradeoff involving competition, economies of scale and regulatory/political risk. Two or three financial centers may be best.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: All else equal, Britain’s rules on hiring, firing and working hours are significantly more conducive to financial activity than those in other large European countries.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Setting the EU rules aside, and assuming it would take 2.5% of Italy’s GDP to recapitalize its banks, the Italian government would improve financial stability in Europe if it injected this amount of public funds into its banks.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: If Italy were to inject public funds into its banks without imposing losses on at least some claimants, an important cost would be the effect on future incentives (economic or political) in Europe.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: On the whole, the shift from state to private ownership of many industrial assets in central and eastern European countries after communism has increased productivity in those countries.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: If the "average" citizen is mobile it has certainly increased the range of opportunities available to him/her.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: Downward pressure on wages from immigrants with a lower reservation wage.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: Access to a larger variety of goods and services, at lower prices. A higher standard of living overall.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: Possibly, and at least in the short run, due to the reallocation of manufacturing activities in low wage new EU members.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: In general, using more congestion charges in crowded transportation networks — such as higher tolls during peak travel times in cities, and peak fees for airplane takeoff and landing slots — and using the proceeds to lower other taxes would make citizens on average better off.
Comment: Efficient allocation of a scarce resource to those who value it more.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Giving tax incentives to specific firms to locate operations in a country typically generates domestic benefits that outweigh the costs to the country providing the incentives.
Comment: At least in expectation the benefits should be positive if the deal is offered by a central authority.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Europe as a whole benefits when European cities or countries compete with each other by giving tax incentives to firms to locate operations in their jurisdictions.
Comment: Possibly not if competition is restricted to tax incentives, but more generally it may encourage more business-friendly policies for all.

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question A: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the UK's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: It all hinges on the post-Brexit arrangement between the UK and the EU. I wouldn't know how to predict that outcome, it's entirely political

Name: Jordi Galí
Qtext: Question B: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the rest of the EU's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: I cannot see the channels through which the rest of the EU would be significantly affected.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Germany's current account surplus is undesirable even from a purely German viewpoint: the country would be better off if, for example, it ran a smaller primary surplus, in turn leading to a smaller current account surplus.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: The Eurozone would be in better shape if fiscal policy were more expansionary, which would allow monetary policy to be slightly less so.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question C: If there is a recession in the Eurozone, it will be essential to have a coordinated fiscal expansion.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: The European Union goal of reaching net zero emissions of greenhouse gases by 2050 will be a major drag on economic growth.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Carbon taxes are a better way to implement climate policy than cap-and-trade.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question C: A carbon border tax targeting imports from non-EU countries with less strict climate policies is likely to harm developing economies.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Following the UK election result, the certainty that the country is going to leave the European Union will provide a substantial short-term boost to the UK economy.
Comment: There is still considerable uncertainty for firms (particularly in services) about the nature of the UK's future trading relationship.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Given that the transition period currently expires at the end of 2020, there is still a considerable risk that the UK will leave the European Union without a trade agreement.
Comment: Expect to hear "no deal is better than a bad deal" again. I suspect a bare-bones trade deal (zero tarrifs & quotas, no services) can be done

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question C: Leaving the European Union without a trade agreement would have a large negative impact on the UK economy.
Comment: This (rather than failure to sort out the other issues in the WA) is the biggest chance that Brexit has a large sudden negative shock.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Under current policies on climate change, the associated physical risks (such as those arising from total seasonal rainfall and sea level changes, and increased frequency, severity, and correlation of extreme weather events) will be at most a very small factor in monetary policy decisions over the next decade.
Comment: It's not clear climate change will be a major issue for central banks over this period, particularly given the narrow remit that many have.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: The physical risks associated with climate change under current policies are likely to threaten financial stability over the next decade.
Comment: I could be wrong here. There could be tipping point events where climate emergencies become a major financial issue.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public R&D spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private R&D spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.
Comment: Not an easy question. Private R&D more likely to spent in zero-sum competitions for market share and establishing dominant market positions.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public medical research spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private medical research spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.
Comment: Similarly, much of the benefit of private medical R&D goes to profits made by drug producers.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for answering some long unsettled questions in development economics research.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for making significant progress in poverty reduction.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Having companies run to maximize shareholder value creates significant negative externalities for workers and communities.
Comment: This could be the case (e.g. if profit maximizing involved polluting the environment) but these cases are best dealt with via regulation.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Appropriately managed corporations could create significantly greater value than they currently do for a range of stakeholders – including workers, suppliers, customers and community members – with small impacts on shareholder value.
Comment: I'm not sure there is sufficient empirical evidence to back up this statement.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext:
Question C:
Effective mechanisms for boards of directors to ensure that CEOs act in ways that balance the interests of all stakeholders would be straightforward to introduce.
Comment: Why would this be easy? It's a really complex issue.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Rising inequality is straining the health of liberal democracy.
Comment: More a political science question than an economics one. Stagnant median earnings perhaps a greater issue than inequality per se.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Enacting more redistributive expenditures and policies would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe.
Comment: Europe already does plenty of redistribution. And some populist parties (Brexit\Lega) actually have anti-redistribution policy platforms.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question C: European governments should allocate more resources to policies that would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe, even if it means higher public debt or lower public spending in other areas.
Comment: Unclear to me which areas of spending would do this. Better to evaluate spending proposals on their objective merits.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: At this point, there is little that the European Central Bank can do to increase or maintain output in the Eurozone.
Comment: With an unemployment rate of 7.5% there is still spare capacity in the EA. ECB can also boost investment which increases supply capacity.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: When the economy is operating below its potential, larger fiscal deficits are likely to increase demand and output.
Comment: There is plenty of empirical evidence for this proposition.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question C: When the economy is operating below its potential and monetary policy is at the effective lower bound, fiscal policy should prioritize increasing output over decreasing public debt.
Comment: Generally true though not, for example, in highly-indebted members of the Euro Area which do not have control of their own currency.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Selecting candidates for membership of the ECB Executive Board based primarily on nationality ahead of competence is likely to have a negative effect on the quality of monetary policy in the Eurozone.
Comment: ECB President is a key job and much has depended in recent years on Draghi's decisions. You need the right person for the job.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Although the central bank can never be an entirely technocratic institution, the selection process for the ECB President and members of the Executive Board is significantly worsened by intergovernmental trade-offs involving appointments to other European institutions.
Comment: "Significantly worsened" might be over-stating it but this kind of horse trading for top jobs certainly doesn't help.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: On bids for infrastructure projects, the average European would be better off if Europe’s governments favored European firms over Chinese firms (or firms from any other country with non-profit-related geopolitical strategies) — even if it means sometimes choosing a higher-cost bidder.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Breaking the “doom loop” — a negative spiral that can result when banks hold sovereign bonds and governments bail out banks — would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Regulators should try to break the doom loop by assigning positive risk weights — in calculating banks’ capital requirements — to banks’ holdings of domestic and other Eurozone sovereign bonds.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question C: Breaking the doom loop would impose substantial costs on powerful political constituencies.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Residents of big European cities would be better off, on balance, if governments did more to counter gentrification, for example by using rent and other housing subsidies, public housing investments, zoning regulations, or similar policies.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.
Comment: A common deposit insurance scheme will somewhat weaken the bank runs that occur in euro area countries with fiscal or banking problems.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the likelihood of another financial crisis in Europe.
Comment: While there is possibly an element of moral hazard with deposit insurance, crisis are generally due to inadequate banking regulation.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Overall, public spending on the arts in Europe creates benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Additional public spending on the arts in Europe would create incremental benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: The average European is better off if Europe’s competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.
Comment: “European champions” seems to be verbal linguistics to justify undermining competition policy.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: If China and other countries use policies that create giant international firms, then the average European is better off if Europe's competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.
Comment: There may be some areas with huge economies of scale where this is true (eg aircraft production) but it will not generally be the case.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Letting publicly traded European firms report earnings annually rather than quarterly would lead their executives to place more weight on long-term issues in their investments and other decisions.
Comment: I can't see any good arguments for this change in reporting frequency having any positive effect on managerial decision making.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: A switch from quarterly to annual earnings reports would, on net, benefit shareholders of European firms.
Comment: Shareholders are better off having access to regular information on the companies they own.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: To the extent that public corporations pursue social and environmental initiatives, they tend to achieve higher risk-adjusted (private) returns than otherwise similar corporations that pursue such initiatives less.
Comment: Companies most likely see CSP initiatives as part of a broader marketing budget. It may suit some to do more than others.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: To the extent that Norway’s global government pension fund makes investments for social and environmental objectives — apart from investments that would bring the highest expected risk-adjusted returns — it improves the welfare of Norwegians.
Comment: Hard to sum this up with such a short question. All countries have an interest in co-operative behavior that reduces risks of climate change

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: The fiscal rules of the European Union should give more flexibility to member countries.
Comment: The rules should focus on maintaining overall debt sustainability and not on randomly chosen figures (such as deficit limits of 3 percent).

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: The Italian budget for 2019 that the European Commission rejected in October would have increased Italy’s risk of fiscal insolvency substantially.
Comment: Insolvency risk is driven by loss of market confidence and failure to roll over existing debt. This government is close to provoking this.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question C: If France runs a 2019 budget deficit of around 3.4% of GDP, as announced by President Macron’s government, France’s risk of fiscal insolvency will increase substantially.
Comment: France has lower debt\GDP and there is far less likelihood of a bond market "strike" on buying French debt. 3 percent is an arbitrary limit.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Capping the number of ride-sharing drivers as is being discussed in New York City, Chicago and London will make the average resident in that city worse off.
Comment: Arbitrary caps on numbers employed in specific industries are unlikely to ever deliver good outcomes.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext:
Question B:
To achieve a given level of congestion, it would be better to use taxes for driving that vary based on the level of congestion, rather than limiting the number of ride-sharing vehicles.
Comment: Capping numbers of a specific group of drivers is not an efficient or useful way to deal with congestion.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: People who migrated to Europe between 2015 and 2018 are likely — over the next two decades — to contribute more in taxes paid than they receive in benefits and public services.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Ideas are nonrival, so increasing returns to scale is an essential feature of technological change in a market economy.
Comment: Nonrivalry of ideas is important for growth and means there are positive externalities to research. Does not have to mean economy-wide IRS.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Voters overestimate the effect that current governments have on their economies’ concurrent economic performance.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Over the next decade, autonomous cars will raise average welfare in the EU by at least as much as smartphones have over the past decade.
Comment: Even with technological progress in this area, my guess is it will face substantial regulatory barriers before being widely adopted.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext:
Britain’s Labour party recently proposed giving the Bank of England a target of 3% annual labor productivity growth. Consider the following statement:
Central banks cannot significantly increase productivity growth over a ten year horizon, except perhaps by promoting macroeconomic stability.
Comment: Even over a decade, macroeconomic stability and preventing investment slumps can probably have a positive influence on productivity.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext:
Question A: The European Commission has proposed new rules to ensure that “digital business activities are taxed in a fair and growth-friendly way in the EU”. Consider two statements regarding this proposal:
An EU-wide 3% tax on revenue from digital activities would, on balance, be a good idea.
Comment: Generally best to tax profits or value added and not revenue. Hard to know why 3% would be the right figure.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext:
Question B:
If the EU decides to tax digital service providers, it would be better — given the difficulties of measuring and verifying digital activity — to tax them on the revenue, rather than the profits, that they generate locally.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: The European Union often uses its antitrust powers to protect EU-based firms from international competition, rather than to promote greater competition in European markets.
Comment: This is not my area of academic expertise but this is not my impression of how antitrust rules have operated in the EU.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Trade with China makes most Europeans better off because, among other advantages, they can buy goods that are made or assembled more cheaply in China.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Some Europeans who work in the production of competing goods, such as clothing and furniture, are made worse off by trade with China.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question C: If the EU followed the new US steel tariffs by imposing similar EU tariffs on steel from China, it would improve Europeans’ welfare.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Assuming it exits its third bailout program this summer without an immediate restructuring or other debt relief, Greece is unlikely to default on its sovereign debt in the coming decade.
Comment: Uncertain. The debt is unsustainable (see the recent CEPR report) but there will likely be debt relief thus avoiding an outright default.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Greece would be better off if it had decided to exit the euro between 2011 and 2015.
Comment: Better to have larger sovereign default in 2011 restoring sustainability and avoiding the excessively tight fiscal policy of 2012 onwards.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question C: If Greece had defaulted on (or restructured) its private debt in 2010, while also staying within the euro, that combination would have been better for Greece than either exiting the euro or proceeding as it has actually done.
Comment: Euro membership provided stability and low interest rates. The damage was done by "debt denial " and excessively tight fiscal policy.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to currency.
Comment: On the relative similarity I agree but gold has actual uses (e.g. jewellery) which gives it some value. Bitcoin will likely end up worthless

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to Dutch tulips in the 1630s.
Comment: The tulips thing was a long time ago and there are various disagreements about it. But yes Bitcoin is more pure speculation than even gold.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext:
The US spends roughly 17% of GDP on healthcare, according to the OECD; most European countries spend less than 12% of GDP.

Higher quality-adjusted US healthcare prices contribute relatively more to the extra US spending than does the combination of higher quantity and quality of US care (interpreting quantity and quality to reflect both greater American healthcare needs due to underlying population health and the delivery of more or better healthcare services to Americans).
Comment: The US spends more on healthcare than European countries but covers a small fraction of the population and has inferior health outcomes.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Over the past two years, all else equal, the appeal of the US as a destination for immigrants has changed in ways that will likely decrease innovation in the US economy.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Holding other policies fixed, the average European would be better off if every European country taxed corporate profits at a rate of 20% (based as closely as possible on a common definition of profits).

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: If other policies were held fixed and every European country taxed corporate profits at a common rate of 20%, then reducing that common rate substantially below 20% would make the average European better off.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, if corporations throughout Europe set quotas for a minimum number of women board members, the shareholder value of European companies would increase.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Taking into account the likely effects on investments in human capital by men and women, setting quotas throughout Europe for a minimum number of women board members would generate substantial net benefits for Europeans.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Subsidizing renewable energy sources is better than taxing fossil fuels, assuming the subsidy or tax would be set at levels that would reduce carbon emissions by an equivalent amount.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Germany’s solar-energy subsidies to date have produced net social benefits for Germany.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question C: Solar-energy subsidies to date in Germany and other countries have produced net social benefits for the world.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Insights from psychology about individual behavior – examples of which include limited rationality, low self-control, or a taste for fairness – predict several important types of observed market outcomes that fully-rational economic models do not.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: The influx of refugees into Germany beginning in the summer of 2015 will generate net economic benefits for German citizens over the succeeding decade.
Comment: Germany has very poor demographics and its population is set to contract. Taking in immigrants will have many long-term economic benefits.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Holding labor market institutions and job training fixed, rising use of robots and artificial intelligence is likely to increase substantially the number of workers in advanced countries who are unemployed for long periods.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Rising use of robots and artificial intelligence in advanced countries is likely to create benefits large enough that they could be used to compensate those workers who are substantially negatively affected for their lost wages.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Consumers will be better off, on balance, if European cities treat firms that provide ride-sharing platforms (such as Uber) as substantively different from taxi firms, and thus not necessarily warranting the same regulation.
Comment: The business of these firms is not substantively different from taxis, so I don't see why they should be treated differently.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Assuming that taxi and ride-sharing companies were treated as substantively similar — including requirements that they operate on an equal footing regarding safety, insurance and taxation — letting ride-sharing services compete without restrictions on prices or routes would raise consumer welfare.
Comment: Imposing restrictions on a particular sub-set of the market is unfair and hurts consumers.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question C: Regardless of how ride-sharing services are treated, existing regulations for traditional taxi firms in many European cities harm consumers by limiting competition.
Comment: Restrictive regulations relating to pricing or quantity supplied are rarely a good idea unless there is a clear market failure.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Revising France’s labor market policies — by reducing employment protection, decentralizing labor negotiations to the firm level, and making training programs more accessible and responsive to labor demands — would, all else equal, increase productivity in France’s economy.
Comment: Probably not a big effect. Would also bring some relatively lower productivity workers into employment This would lower average productivity

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Reducing employment protection would reduce the equilibrium unemployment rate in France.
Comment: It is likely that high levels of employment protection raise the natural rate of unemployment. But this is just one of many factors.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: The ECB's asset purchases over the past two years have reduced the threat of deflation in the euro area as a whole.
Comment: QE is complex but most careful research shows it impacts long-term rates. ECB program has definitely reduced sovereign borrowing rates.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: If the economic outlook in the euro area becomes less favorable, then increasing the ECB's asset purchase program (in size or duration) would substantially increase the euro area's economic growth over the following five years.
Comment: The disagreement is because of the word "substantial". Not sure that any realistic policy can "substantially" improve European growth rates.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: In general, absent any inside information, an equity investor can expect to do better by holding a well-diversified, low-fee, passive index fund than by holding a few stocks.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Without changes in policy, a rising share of people who are over age 65 will exert a substantial downward influence on per capita real GDP in western European countries.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: In European countries where the share of those over 65 is rising, there are net social benefits to adjusting retirement ages for state-financed (including pay-as-you-go) pension systems upwards, so that revised retirement ages better reflect longer life expectancies.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, there are substantial advantages to having much of Europe’s human capital and infrastructure for international financial activity clustered in a single city, as they are at present in London.
Comment: There may be some wider advantages for Europe due to the clustering of financial service activity in London but it is likely to be small.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: All else equal, Britain’s rules on hiring, firing and working hours are significantly more conducive to financial activity than those in other large European countries.
Comment: I don't believe labour laws in France, Germany or Ireland, for example, will be a deterring factor for financial service firms.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Setting the EU rules aside, and assuming it would take 2.5% of Italy’s GDP to recapitalize its banks, the Italian government would improve financial stability in Europe if it injected this amount of public funds into its banks.
Comment: This may improve financial stability in the short-run but probably sets a bad fiscal precedent for other European governments in the future.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: If Italy were to inject public funds into its banks without imposing losses on at least some claimants, an important cost would be the effect on future incentives (economic or political) in Europe.
Comment: This would undermine the EU's BRRD approach though it always seemed likely loss imposition was more a policy intended for small countries.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: On the whole, the shift from state to private ownership of many industrial assets in central and eastern European countries after communism has increased productivity in those countries.
Comment: Agree but moving from state-sponsored monopolies to badly-regulated private sector monopolies does not do much for the average consumer.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: Agree, though effects on the average person are not the same as on every person.

Name: Karl Whelan
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: Empirical evidence on effects of migration from Eastern Europe suggest limited effects on wages in the UK for example.

Name: Karl Whelan
