Qtext: Over the past two years, all else equal, the appeal of the US as a destination for immigrants has changed in ways that will likely decrease innovation in the US economy.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question A: Holding other policies fixed, the average European would be better off if every European country taxed corporate profits at a rate of 20% (based as closely as possible on a common definition of profits).
Comment: My uncertainty stems from the fact that the question does not make clear how the tax cut will be financed (higher deficit, less spending)?

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question B: If other policies were held fixed and every European country taxed corporate profits at a common rate of 20%, then reducing that common rate substantially below 20% would make the average European better off.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, if corporations throughout Europe set quotas for a minimum number of women board members, the shareholder value of European companies would increase.
Comment: I have no expertise in this issue

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question B: Taking into account the likely effects on investments in human capital by men and women, setting quotas throughout Europe for a minimum number of women board members would generate substantial net benefits for Europeans.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question A: Subsidizing renewable energy sources is better than taxing fossil fuels, assuming the subsidy or tax would be set at levels that would reduce carbon emissions by an equivalent amount.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question B: Germany’s solar-energy subsidies to date have produced net social benefits for Germany.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question C: Solar-energy subsidies to date in Germany and other countries have produced net social benefits for the world.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Insights from psychology about individual behavior – examples of which include limited rationality, low self-control, or a taste for fairness – predict several important types of observed market outcomes that fully-rational economic models do not.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: The influx of refugees into Germany beginning in the summer of 2015 will generate net economic benefits for German citizens over the succeeding decade.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question A: Holding labor market institutions and job training fixed, rising use of robots and artificial intelligence is likely to increase substantially the number of workers in advanced countries who are unemployed for long periods.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question B: Rising use of robots and artificial intelligence in advanced countries is likely to create benefits large enough that they could be used to compensate those workers who are substantially negatively affected for their lost wages.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question A: Consumers will be better off, on balance, if European cities treat firms that provide ride-sharing platforms (such as Uber) as substantively different from taxi firms, and thus not necessarily warranting the same regulation.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question B: Assuming that taxi and ride-sharing companies were treated as substantively similar — including requirements that they operate on an equal footing regarding safety, insurance and taxation — letting ride-sharing services compete without restrictions on prices or routes would raise consumer welfare.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question C: Regardless of how ride-sharing services are treated, existing regulations for traditional taxi firms in many European cities harm consumers by limiting competition.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question A: Revising France’s labor market policies — by reducing employment protection, decentralizing labor negotiations to the firm level, and making training programs more accessible and responsive to labor demands — would, all else equal, increase productivity in France’s economy.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question B: Reducing employment protection would reduce the equilibrium unemployment rate in France.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question A: The ECB's asset purchases over the past two years have reduced the threat of deflation in the euro area as a whole.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question B: If the economic outlook in the euro area becomes less favorable, then increasing the ECB's asset purchase program (in size or duration) would substantially increase the euro area's economic growth over the following five years.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: In general, absent any inside information, an equity investor can expect to do better by holding a well-diversified, low-fee, passive index fund than by holding a few stocks.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question A: Without changes in policy, a rising share of people who are over age 65 will exert a substantial downward influence on per capita real GDP in western European countries.
Comment: Without changes in legislation the fiscal burden of pensions will require further taxation of the working population

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question B: In European countries where the share of those over 65 is rising, there are net social benefits to adjusting retirement ages for state-financed (including pay-as-you-go) pension systems upwards, so that revised retirement ages better reflect longer life expectancies.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, there are substantial advantages to having much of Europe’s human capital and infrastructure for international financial activity clustered in a single city, as they are at present in London.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question B: All else equal, Britain’s rules on hiring, firing and working hours are significantly more conducive to financial activity than those in other large European countries.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question A: Setting the EU rules aside, and assuming it would take 2.5% of Italy’s GDP to recapitalize its banks, the Italian government would improve financial stability in Europe if it injected this amount of public funds into its banks.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question B: If Italy were to inject public funds into its banks without imposing losses on at least some claimants, an important cost would be the effect on future incentives (economic or political) in Europe.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: On the whole, the shift from state to private ownership of many industrial assets in central and eastern European countries after communism has increased productivity in those countries.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: In general, using more congestion charges in crowded transportation networks — such as higher tolls during peak travel times in cities, and peak fees for airplane takeoff and landing slots — and using the proceeds to lower other taxes would make citizens on average better off.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question A: Giving tax incentives to specific firms to locate operations in a country typically generates domestic benefits that outweigh the costs to the country providing the incentives.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question B: Europe as a whole benefits when European cities or countries compete with each other by giving tax incentives to firms to locate operations in their jurisdictions.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question A: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the UK's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.

Name: Paul De Grauwe
Qtext: Question B: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the rest of the EU's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: The effect on the rest of the EU will be limited.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Rising inequality is straining the health of liberal democracy.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: Enacting more redistributive expenditures and policies would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question C: European governments should allocate more resources to policies that would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe, even if it means higher public debt or lower public spending in other areas.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: At this point, there is little that the European Central Bank can do to increase or maintain output in the Eurozone.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: When the economy is operating below its potential, larger fiscal deficits are likely to increase demand and output.
Comment: If the government’s money isn’t wasted.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question C: When the economy is operating below its potential and monetary policy is at the effective lower bound, fiscal policy should prioritize increasing output over decreasing public debt.
Comment: Ok if debt position is not in danger zone.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Selecting candidates for membership of the ECB Executive Board based primarily on nationality ahead of competence is likely to have a negative effect on the quality of monetary policy in the Eurozone.
Comment: To maintain broad support among euro member countries representativeness may also be relevant.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: Although the central bank can never be an entirely technocratic institution, the selection process for the ECB President and members of the Executive Board is significantly worsened by intergovernmental trade-offs involving appointments to other European institutions.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: On bids for infrastructure projects, the average European would be better off if Europe’s governments favored European firms over Chinese firms (or firms from any other country with non-profit-related geopolitical strategies) — even if it means sometimes choosing a higher-cost bidder.
Comment: I take it that the comparison includes all components (quality, on-time delivery, etc). Helping inefficient companies doesn’t improve them.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Breaking the “doom loop” — a negative spiral that can result when banks hold sovereign bonds and governments bail out banks — would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: Regulators should try to break the doom loop by assigning positive risk weights — in calculating banks’ capital requirements — to banks’ holdings of domestic and other Eurozone sovereign bonds.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question C: Breaking the doom loop would impose substantial costs on powerful political constituencies.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Residents of big European cities would be better off, on balance, if governments did more to counter gentrification, for example by using rent and other housing subsidies, public housing investments, zoning regulations, or similar policies.
Comment: A solid public education system is important, as is public health, in my view. Paying people to live in certain areas is more questionable.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.
Comment: A common system appears constraining, given differences in financial systems across countries.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the likelihood of another financial crisis in Europe.
Comment: Moral hazard is relevant but so is a risk of runs. I’m not an expert.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Overall, public spending on the arts in Europe creates benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.
Comment: I'm no expert on this but I think there are good reasons for some amount of support of the arts.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: Additional public spending on the arts in Europe would create incremental benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.
Comment: I'm not aware of the current level of support. As I said, some public support is called for.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: The average European is better off if Europe’s competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.
Comment: It depends on the particular sector and the particular foreign competition. I can see it going both ways.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: If China and other countries use policies that create giant international firms, then the average European is better off if Europe's competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Letting publicly traded European firms report earnings annually rather than quarterly would lead their executives to place more weight on long-term issues in their investments and other decisions.
Comment: My view is not based on research but on beliefs formed by talking to businesses.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: A switch from quarterly to annual earnings reports would, on net, benefit shareholders of European firms.
Comment: I just don’t think it would matter much.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: To the extent that public corporations pursue social and environmental initiatives, they tend to achieve higher risk-adjusted (private) returns than otherwise similar corporations that pursue such initiatives less.
Comment: I haven’t seen any evidence to support this claim and tested theory predicts the opposite. But if it’s a fad it can pay off, like any fad.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: To the extent that Norway’s global government pension fund makes investments for social and environmental objectives — apart from investments that would bring the highest expected risk-adjusted returns — it improves the welfare of Norwegians.
Comment: I define welfare in traditional ways (goods and services, leisure). If Norwegians attach a moral value to these actions, maybe it is a plus.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: The fiscal rules of the European Union should give more flexibility to member countries.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: The Italian budget for 2019 that the European Commission rejected in October would have increased Italy’s risk of fiscal insolvency substantially.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question C: If France runs a 2019 budget deficit of around 3.4% of GDP, as announced by President Macron’s government, France’s risk of fiscal insolvency will increase substantially.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Capping the number of ride-sharing drivers as is being discussed in New York City, Chicago and London will make the average resident in that city worse off.
Comment: I am not an expert on this!

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext:
Question B:
To achieve a given level of congestion, it would be better to use taxes for driving that vary based on the level of congestion, rather than limiting the number of ride-sharing vehicles.
Comment: I’m using basic micro theory; not evidence.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: People who migrated to Europe between 2015 and 2018 are likely — over the next two decades — to contribute more in taxes paid than they receive in benefits and public services.
Comment: In welfare states with poor integration the net monetary gain is likely negative. This does not mean one should not allow asylum seekers.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Ideas are nonrival, so increasing returns to scale is an essential feature of technological change in a market economy.
Comment: For motivation, see the brilliant document provided by the prize committee! :-) IRS also requires at least CRS in non-idea inputs.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Voters overestimate the effect that current governments have on their economies’ concurrent economic performance.
Comment: The evidence on this is perhaps not very strong but it is a plausible hypothesis.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Over the next decade, autonomous cars will raise average welfare in the EU by at least as much as smartphones have over the past decade.
Comment: Smartphones appear far more valuable for consumption and production. I am very far from an expert on either topic, hence the low confidence.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext:
Britain’s Labour party recently proposed giving the Bank of England a target of 3% annual labor productivity growth. Consider the following statement:
Central banks cannot significantly increase productivity growth over a ten year horizon, except perhaps by promoting macroeconomic stability.
Comment: I know of no result in the literature suggesting monetary policy would be able to affect technology growth.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext:
Question A: The European Commission has proposed new rules to ensure that “digital business activities are taxed in a fair and growth-friendly way in the EU”. Consider two statements regarding this proposal:
An EU-wide 3% tax on revenue from digital activities would, on balance, be a good idea.
Comment: I simply don’t understand the motivation.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext:
Question B:
If the EU decides to tax digital service providers, it would be better — given the difficulties of measuring and verifying digital activity — to tax them on the revenue, rather than the profits, that they generate locally.
Comment: It depends on the motivation behind the tax, which I don’t understand.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: The European Union often uses its antitrust powers to protect EU-based firms from international competition, rather than to promote greater competition in European markets.
Comment: I don’t know.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Trade with China makes most Europeans better off because, among other advantages, they can buy goods that are made or assembled more cheaply in China.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: Some Europeans who work in the production of competing goods, such as clothing and furniture, are made worse off by trade with China.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question C: If the EU followed the new US steel tariffs by imposing similar EU tariffs on steel from China, it would improve Europeans’ welfare.
Comment: It might trigger further tariff increased.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Assuming it exits its third bailout program this summer without an immediate restructuring or other debt relief, Greece is unlikely to default on its sovereign debt in the coming decade.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: Greece would be better off if it had decided to exit the euro between 2011 and 2015.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question C: If Greece had defaulted on (or restructured) its private debt in 2010, while also staying within the euro, that combination would have been better for Greece than either exiting the euro or proceeding as it has actually done.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to currency.
Comment: It has no intrinsic value: like currency. Its liquidity: unclear, but similar w many currencies. It is a medium of exchange for criminals.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to Dutch tulips in the 1630s.
Comment: Gold is also a medium of exchange though not a very liquid one.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext:
The US spends roughly 17% of GDP on healthcare, according to the OECD; most European countries spend less than 12% of GDP.

Higher quality-adjusted US healthcare prices contribute relatively more to the extra US spending than does the combination of higher quantity and quality of US care (interpreting quantity and quality to reflect both greater American healthcare needs due to underlying population health and the delivery of more or better healthcare services to Americans).
Comment: I'm quite uninformed on this issue!

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Over the past two years, all else equal, the appeal of the US as a destination for immigrants has changed in ways that will likely decrease innovation in the US economy.
Comment: President Trump is broadly disliked by highly educated people abroad and my GUESS is that these people think twice before moving to the U.S.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Holding other policies fixed, the average European would be better off if every European country taxed corporate profits at a rate of 20% (based as closely as possible on a common definition of profits).
Comment: Harmonization eliminates unnecessary wedges.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: If other policies were held fixed and every European country taxed corporate profits at a common rate of 20%, then reducing that common rate substantially below 20% would make the average European better off.
Comment: It depends on how the resulting debt will be financed.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, if corporations throughout Europe set quotas for a minimum number of women board members, the shareholder value of European companies would increase.
Comment: Initially the reaction may be the opposite but my belief is that over the longer run it would be a plus. No data to back it up though!

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: Taking into account the likely effects on investments in human capital by men and women, setting quotas throughout Europe for a minimum number of women board members would generate substantial net benefits for Europeans.
Comment: It's about making use of the talents of the entire population: good for prosperity. Much of management is (male) networking.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Subsidizing renewable energy sources is better than taxing fossil fuels, assuming the subsidy or tax would be set at levels that would reduce carbon emissions by an equivalent amount.
Comment: A tax is a more direct instrument for reducing emissions - the main goal - and R&D subsidies are at best an imperfect substitute.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: Germany’s solar-energy subsidies to date have produced net social benefits for Germany.
Comment: My understanding is that they have been very costly and not paid back for Germany.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question C: Solar-energy subsidies to date in Germany and other countries have produced net social benefits for the world.
Comment: The R&D has had benefits and the point is that they are global, not German-specific. I have not seen any cost-benefit analysis though.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Insights from psychology about individual behavior – examples of which include limited rationality, low self-control, or a taste for fairness – predict several important types of observed market outcomes that fully-rational economic models do not.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: The influx of refugees into Germany beginning in the summer of 2015 will generate net economic benefits for German citizens over the succeeding decade.
Comment: The adjustment likely takes longer (even though German labor markets allow low entry wages). Eventually the average benefits will be > 0.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Holding labor market institutions and job training fixed, rising use of robots and artificial intelligence is likely to increase substantially the number of workers in advanced countries who are unemployed for long periods.
Comment: Perhaps unemployment could rise in the short run but employment will respond to labor supply: there will be jobs.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: Rising use of robots and artificial intelligence in advanced countries is likely to create benefits large enough that they could be used to compensate those workers who are substantially negatively affected for their lost wages.
Comment: If it is profitable to employ robots it is very likely more efficient. So almost by definition they increase production efficiency.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Consumers will be better off, on balance, if European cities treat firms that provide ride-sharing platforms (such as Uber) as substantively different from taxi firms, and thus not necessarily warranting the same regulation.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: Assuming that taxi and ride-sharing companies were treated as substantively similar — including requirements that they operate on an equal footing regarding safety, insurance and taxation — letting ride-sharing services compete without restrictions on prices or routes would raise consumer welfare.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question C: Regardless of how ride-sharing services are treated, existing regulations for traditional taxi firms in many European cities harm consumers by limiting competition.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Revising France’s labor market policies — by reducing employment protection, decentralizing labor negotiations to the firm level, and making training programs more accessible and responsive to labor demands — would, all else equal, increase productivity in France’s economy.
Comment: Managing training programs is not necessarily so easy but I take the view that significant improvement is feasible.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: Reducing employment protection would reduce the equilibrium unemployment rate in France.
Comment: It may not do so immediately. One can do a reform with grandfathering though, leaving currently employed workers with protection.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: The ECB's asset purchases over the past two years have reduced the threat of deflation in the euro area as a whole.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: If the economic outlook in the euro area becomes less favorable, then increasing the ECB's asset purchase program (in size or duration) would substantially increase the euro area's economic growth over the following five years.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: In general, absent any inside information, an equity investor can expect to do better by holding a well-diversified, low-fee, passive index fund than by holding a few stocks.
Comment: I don't know of any convincing systematic evidence to the contrary.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Without changes in policy, a rising share of people who are over age 65 will exert a substantial downward influence on per capita real GDP in western European countries.
Comment: Mechanical argument but correct; behavioral responses exist but are limited.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: In European countries where the share of those over 65 is rising, there are net social benefits to adjusting retirement ages for state-financed (including pay-as-you-go) pension systems upwards, so that revised retirement ages better reflect longer life expectancies.
Comment: To the extent there is cont'd general productivity growth and we get richer, people may want more leisure, but this effect is likely small.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, there are substantial advantages to having much of Europe’s human capital and infrastructure for international financial activity clustered in a single city, as they are at present in London.
Comment: It's not clear to me what the positive agglomeration activities are. Agglomeration can be bad too. But I'm far from an expert on this!

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: All else equal, Britain’s rules on hiring, firing and working hours are significantly more conducive to financial activity than those in other large European countries.
Comment: Not obvious that labor regulation is that relevant in this particular sector. It is in others but finance is full of other incentives.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Setting the EU rules aside, and assuming it would take 2.5% of Italy’s GDP to recapitalize its banks, the Italian government would improve financial stability in Europe if it injected this amount of public funds into its banks.
Comment: I don't have enough info to say that it would help financial institutions elsewhere; depends on cross-holdings. In long run it's likely bad.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: If Italy were to inject public funds into its banks without imposing losses on at least some claimants, an important cost would be the effect on future incentives (economic or political) in Europe.
Comment: The expectations of future bailouts will likely be affected and induce excessive risk-taking.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: On the whole, the shift from state to private ownership of many industrial assets in central and eastern European countries after communism has increased productivity in those countries.
Comment: I have no knowledge in this area.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: People migrate because they want to. Secondary effects are likely positive too.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: Same as trade question. Some gain, some lose, also among low-skilled workers.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: I am not a trade economist by specialization, which explains why I selected somewhat limited confidence.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: I think mist low-wage competition is from outside of Europe. Of course some always lose from trade. But many low-skilled workers gain too.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: In general, using more congestion charges in crowded transportation networks — such as higher tolls during peak travel times in cities, and peak fees for airplane takeoff and landing slots — and using the proceeds to lower other taxes would make citizens on average better off.
Comment: this approach works in theory and seems to also work in practice

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Giving tax incentives to specific firms to locate operations in a country typically generates domestic benefits that outweigh the costs to the country providing the incentives.
Comment: this is good policy only if the government is able to select the right companies - which it is typically not

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: Europe as a whole benefits when European cities or countries compete with each other by giving tax incentives to firms to locate operations in their jurisdictions.
Comment: if we think corporate taxes are too low this may be a good thing, but it is then better to just lower them across the board

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question A: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the UK's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: There is some small chance that the EU will malfunction badly in the future, in which case Brexit may be good ex post.

Name: Per Krusell
Qtext: Question B: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the rest of the EU's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: biggest risk is political: Brexit's anti-establishment message spreads. purely economic spillovers likely minor.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Germany's current account surplus is undesirable even from a purely German viewpoint: the country would be better off if, for example, it ran a smaller primary surplus, in turn leading to a smaller current account surplus.
Comment: Surpluses defer consumption; doing this indefinitely makes no sense. That said, German opposition to inflation is understandably deep-rooted

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: The Eurozone would be in better shape if fiscal policy were more expansionary, which would allow monetary policy to be slightly less so.
Comment: The current monetary-fiscal-policy disconnect is unsustainable. Provided it is prudent and targeted, expansionary fiscal policy makes sense

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question C: If there is a recession in the Eurozone, it will be essential to have a coordinated fiscal expansion.
Comment: "essential" begs a lot of questions. Desirable definitely, though without new institutional structures, not clear how that can be effected

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: The European Union goal of reaching net zero emissions of greenhouse gases by 2050 will be a major drag on economic growth.
Comment: Growth may be lower; but could be lower still if environmental degradation proceeds unchecked. Markets undevalue environmental quality

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Carbon taxes are a better way to implement climate policy than cap-and-trade.
Comment:
Both are good alternatives to command-and-control, incentivizing concern for environmental quality. The choice between them is contingent
-see background information here

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question C: A carbon border tax targeting imports from non-EU countries with less strict climate policies is likely to harm developing economies.
Comment: Provided border taxes are not merely protectionist, they are likely to encourage better environmental policies in developing countries

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Following the UK election result, the certainty that the country is going to leave the European Union will provide a substantial short-term boost to the UK economy.
Comment:
This could happen if confidence improves, but exchange rate fluctuations in the first post-election week suggest markets are unconvinced
-see background information here

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Given that the transition period currently expires at the end of 2020, there is still a considerable risk that the UK will leave the European Union without a trade agreement.
Comment: UK policy seems focused on committing to leave hoping to get a better deal as a result. Unlikely to happen; EU has stronger bargaining power

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question C: Leaving the European Union without a trade agreement would have a large negative impact on the UK economy.
Comment:
All professionally-respected studies show that barriers with EU will impose economic costs for which no other trade agreement can compensate
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Under current policies on climate change, the associated physical risks (such as those arising from total seasonal rainfall and sea level changes, and increased frequency, severity, and correlation of extreme weather events) will be at most a very small factor in monetary policy decisions over the next decade.
Comment: Extreme weather events may destabilize financial markets tho risks from global warming increasing pressure on migration are likely greater

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: The physical risks associated with climate change under current policies are likely to threaten financial stability over the next decade.
Comment: Very hard to forecast

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public R&D spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private R&D spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.
Comment:
In principle publicly funding R&D can respond better to social priorities and internalize spillovers. Doing so in practice is a challenge
-see background information here

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Europeans would benefit more from an extra €1 billion of public medical research spent through existing (public) channels than from an extra €1 billion of private medical research spent through existing (private) channels, all else equal.
Comment: The same superiority in principle, and problems of implementation in practive, arise as for (A)

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for answering some long unsettled questions in development economics research.
Comment: A great addition to economists’ toolkit - tho we should not expect too much of them

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Randomized control trials are a valuable tool for making significant progress in poverty reduction.
Comment: Significant? Yes. Quantitatively important? Not in all cases. Need to keep the Deaton-Pritchett qualifications in mind

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Having companies run to maximize shareholder value creates significant negative externalities for workers and communities.
Comment: I agree with this statement, though maximizing shareholder value also encourages efficient profit-making which has social value

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Appropriately managed corporations could create significantly greater value than they currently do for a range of stakeholders – including workers, suppliers, customers and community members – with small impacts on shareholder value.
Comment: Modern corporations should be regulated, including anti-trust, regulation to ensure compliance with environmental and labor standards, etc.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext:
Question C:
Effective mechanisms for boards of directors to ensure that CEOs act in ways that balance the interests of all stakeholders would be straightforward to introduce.
Comment: Regulation is a multi-faceted goal; legistating on the composion of boards of directors may not be a good instrument to achieve it

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Rising inequality is straining the health of liberal democracy.
Comment: Rising inequality is a contributing factor; but real or imagined threats from immigration are more salient in Europe. Populists exploit both

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Enacting more redistributive expenditures and policies would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe.
Comment: Announcement effects of such policies could have short-term benefits; but the direct effects will only be long-term

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question C: European governments should allocate more resources to policies that would be likely to limit the rise of populism in Europe, even if it means higher public debt or lower public spending in other areas.
Comment: Retreating from austerity in UK, or boosting Eurozone aggregate demand, plus efforts to reduce inequality should help, if sold positively

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: At this point, there is little that the European Central Bank can do to increase or maintain output in the Eurozone.
Comment: ECB can’t do much given low interest rates, but I can stop things getting worse

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: When the economy is operating below its potential, larger fiscal deficits are likely to increase demand and output.
Comment: Only models with implausible degrees of wage/price flexibility predict otherwise.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question C: When the economy is operating below its potential and monetary policy is at the effective lower bound, fiscal policy should prioritize increasing output over decreasing public debt.
Comment: Agree, but this is more a political/moral judgement than a scientifically grounded view. And depends on circumstances, esp. size of deficit

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Selecting candidates for membership of the ECB Executive Board based primarily on nationality ahead of competence is likely to have a negative effect on the quality of monetary policy in the Eurozone.
Comment: "Competence" should be interpreted broadly: commanding academic respect but also with personal, political and administrative skills

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Although the central bank can never be an entirely technocratic institution, the selection process for the ECB President and members of the Executive Board is significantly worsened by intergovernmental trade-offs involving appointments to other European institutions.
Comment: The track record to date is not bad. Hopefully this will continue. It would clearly be worrying if the post became totally politicized.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: On bids for infrastructure projects, the average European would be better off if Europe’s governments favored European firms over Chinese firms (or firms from any other country with non-profit-related geopolitical strategies) — even if it means sometimes choosing a higher-cost bidder.
Comment: It depends. The trade-off is between security and buying from the best supplier. Excluding all foreign bidders is just protectionism.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Breaking the “doom loop” — a negative spiral that can result when banks hold sovereign bonds and governments bail out banks — would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Regulators should try to break the doom loop by assigning positive risk weights — in calculating banks’ capital requirements — to banks’ holdings of domestic and other Eurozone sovereign bonds.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question C: Breaking the doom loop would impose substantial costs on powerful political constituencies.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Residents of big European cities would be better off, on balance, if governments did more to counter gentrification, for example by using rent and other housing subsidies, public housing investments, zoning regulations, or similar policies.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the stability of European economies in the event of another financial crisis.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: A common European deposit insurance scheme, once fully implemented, would increase the likelihood of another financial crisis in Europe.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Overall, public spending on the arts in Europe creates benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.
Comment: This is a value judgement not a statement about efficiency. Cost issues and equity in access should be taken into account too.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Additional public spending on the arts in Europe would create incremental benefits that exceed the deadweight loss caused by taxation to fund it.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: The average European is better off if Europe’s competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.
Comment: Case-by-case considerations matter. Not clear that a general rule is ideal

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: If China and other countries use policies that create giant international firms, then the average European is better off if Europe's competition authorities let firms merge into European champions in their sectors, even it weakens competition.
Comment: If the choice is between a world Chinese monopoly or a world duopoly with a European firm, then subsidies are justified. But details matter

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Letting publicly traded European firms report earnings annually rather than quarterly would lead their executives to place more weight on long-term issues in their investments and other decisions.
Comment: Not my specialty. I would expect source of funding rather than frequency of reporting to be more important in promoting long-term thinking

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: A switch from quarterly to annual earnings reports would, on net, benefit shareholders of European firms.
Comment: Same answer as to (A), with the added proviso that long-term thinking may be good for society but not necessarily for all shareholders

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: To the extent that public corporations pursue social and environmental initiatives, they tend to achieve higher risk-adjusted (private) returns than otherwise similar corporations that pursue such initiatives less.
Comment: An old debate. John Stuart Mill nailed it: private sector to maximize efficiency; public to look after distribution, social goals etc.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: To the extent that Norway’s global government pension fund makes investments for social and environmental objectives — apart from investments that would bring the highest expected risk-adjusted returns — it improves the welfare of Norwegians.
Comment: Weakly agree; tho main benefit of the Norwegian fund is as the poster-boy of how to manage windfalls to mitigate the natural resource curse

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: The fiscal rules of the European Union should give more flexibility to member countries.
Comment: Maastricht rules are very restrictive. Some kind of closer fiscal union needed to control moral hazard, but stabilisation more important

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: The Italian budget for 2019 that the European Commission rejected in October would have increased Italy’s risk of fiscal insolvency substantially.
Comment: The right decision given current rules - which should be changed.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question C: If France runs a 2019 budget deficit of around 3.4% of GDP, as announced by President Macron’s government, France’s risk of fiscal insolvency will increase substantially.
Comment: What’s good for Italy ...

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Capping the number of ride-sharing drivers as is being discussed in New York City, Chicago and London will make the average resident in that city worse off.
Comment: Restricting quantity will raise prices and lower average welfare. Effects on congestion unlikely to be significant

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext:
Question B:
To achieve a given level of congestion, it would be better to use taxes for driving that vary based on the level of congestion, rather than limiting the number of ride-sharing vehicles.
Comment: Singapore pioneered road pricing decades ago. Sad that it has not been more widely copied. Scarce resources given away freely makes no sense

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: People who migrated to Europe between 2015 and 2018 are likely — over the next two decades — to contribute more in taxes paid than they receive in benefits and public services.
Comment: Simple demographics: all the studies I know show that, on average, immigrants are younger, healthier and have fewer dependents than natives

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Ideas are nonrival, so increasing returns to scale is an essential feature of technological change in a market economy.
Comment:
Ideas can be protected, and imitation is costly, but the statement is broadly correct, with huge implications for R&D and antitrust policy
-see background information here
-see background information here

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Voters overestimate the effect that current governments have on their economies’ concurrent economic performance.
Comment: Emergency intervention can have immediate effects. But policy mostly has slow effects, especially on aggregate productivity

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Over the next decade, autonomous cars will raise average welfare in the EU by at least as much as smartphones have over the past decade.
Comment: Autonomous cars could contribute to lower emissions and greatly reduced congestion; but only with consistent urban planning

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext:
Britain’s Labour party recently proposed giving the Bank of England a target of 3% annual labor productivity growth. Consider the following statement:
Central banks cannot significantly increase productivity growth over a ten year horizon, except perhaps by promoting macroeconomic stability.
Comment: This target is hard to influence with any instrument; monetary policy is not the right one

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext:
Question A: The European Commission has proposed new rules to ensure that “digital business activities are taxed in a fair and growth-friendly way in the EU”. Consider two statements regarding this proposal:
An EU-wide 3% tax on revenue from digital activities would, on balance, be a good idea.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext:
Question B:
If the EU decides to tax digital service providers, it would be better — given the difficulties of measuring and verifying digital activity — to tax them on the revenue, rather than the profits, that they generate locally.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: The European Union often uses its antitrust powers to protect EU-based firms from international competition, rather than to promote greater competition in European markets.
Comment: Given the size of the European market, favouring EU-based firms need not be so costly, provided a robust approach is taken to market abuse.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Trade with China makes most Europeans better off because, among other advantages, they can buy goods that are made or assembled more cheaply in China.
Comment:
Gains from trade on average is one of the most widely accepted predictions of economic theory, stemming from specialisation and wider choice
-see background information here

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Some Europeans who work in the production of competing goods, such as clothing and furniture, are made worse off by trade with China.
Comment:
As with any change to an economy's structure, it is inevitable that some groups will suffer. Such gains can be offset by a social safety net
-see background information here

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question C: If the EU followed the new US steel tariffs by imposing similar EU tariffs on steel from China, it would improve Europeans’ welfare.
Comment: Policy effects in multilateral contexts are hard to predict, but for both economic and political reasons such tariffs would entail self-harm

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Assuming it exits its third bailout program this summer without an immediate restructuring or other debt relief, Greece is unlikely to default on its sovereign debt in the coming decade.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Greece would be better off if it had decided to exit the euro between 2011 and 2015.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question C: If Greece had defaulted on (or restructured) its private debt in 2010, while also staying within the euro, that combination would have been better for Greece than either exiting the euro or proceeding as it has actually done.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to currency.
Comment: Bitcoins have feature of currency, though volatility makes them undesirable except for speculation. Blockchain technology more important

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to Dutch tulips in the 1630s.
Comment: If I knew the answer I would take a position on them!

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext:
The US spends roughly 17% of GDP on healthcare, according to the OECD; most European countries spend less than 12% of GDP.

Higher quality-adjusted US healthcare prices contribute relatively more to the extra US spending than does the combination of higher quantity and quality of US care (interpreting quantity and quality to reflect both greater American healthcare needs due to underlying population health and the delivery of more or better healthcare services to Americans).
Comment: More fragmented demand side (mainly private rather than public suppliers) a factor; also looser regulation on marketing (not R&D)

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Over the past two years, all else equal, the appeal of the US as a destination for immigrants has changed in ways that will likely decrease innovation in the US economy.
Comment: Hostility to immigrants deters newcomers. Mainland European and Asian countries are seeking to benefit from this.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Holding other policies fixed, the average European would be better off if every European country taxed corporate profits at a rate of 20% (based as closely as possible on a common definition of profits).

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: If other policies were held fixed and every European country taxed corporate profits at a common rate of 20%, then reducing that common rate substantially below 20% would make the average European better off.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, if corporations throughout Europe set quotas for a minimum number of women board members, the shareholder value of European companies would increase.
Comment: I am in favour of this kind of measure in principle but do not want to claim that it would affect shareholder value for the better; no worse

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Taking into account the likely effects on investments in human capital by men and women, setting quotas throughout Europe for a minimum number of women board members would generate substantial net benefits for Europeans.
Comment: Benefits yes; more openings for women, encouraging human capital acquisition, better decisions. I am not sure they would be "substantial"

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Subsidizing renewable energy sources is better than taxing fossil fuels, assuming the subsidy or tax would be set at levels that would reduce carbon emissions by an equivalent amount.
Comment: Given revenue neutrality, choosing between the policies hinges on uncertainty (which renewables?) & on macro considerations: stimulus better

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Germany’s solar-energy subsidies to date have produced net social benefits for Germany.
Comment: These policies are a global public good: clear net benefits for the world (emissions fall) but not necessarily for Germany

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question C: Solar-energy subsidies to date in Germany and other countries have produced net social benefits for the world.
Comment: Definitely positive, though clearly not necessarily very large relative to the scale of global emissions

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Insights from psychology about individual behavior – examples of which include limited rationality, low self-control, or a taste for fairness – predict several important types of observed market outcomes that fully-rational economic models do not.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: The influx of refugees into Germany beginning in the summer of 2015 will generate net economic benefits for German citizens over the succeeding decade.
Comment: Net benefits from increased labor supply. Losses to some workers possible. Poor integration could lead to social unrest: safety nets needed

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Holding labor market institutions and job training fixed, rising use of robots and artificial intelligence is likely to increase substantially the number of workers in advanced countries who are unemployed for long periods.
Comment: Some workers will be displaced, some will retrain, the new technology is likely to diffuse slowly, especially in service industries.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Rising use of robots and artificial intelligence in advanced countries is likely to create benefits large enough that they could be used to compensate those workers who are substantially negatively affected for their lost wages.
Comment: I agree in principle, though compensation rarely occurs in practice and would require Nordic levels of income support and retraining.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Consumers will be better off, on balance, if European cities treat firms that provide ride-sharing platforms (such as Uber) as substantively different from taxi firms, and thus not necessarily warranting the same regulation.
Comment: Taxis are excessively regulated in many cities, so increased competition is desirable. But regulation also has a role in protecting consumer

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Assuming that taxi and ride-sharing companies were treated as substantively similar — including requirements that they operate on an equal footing regarding safety, insurance and taxation — letting ride-sharing services compete without restrictions on prices or routes would raise consumer welfare.
Comment: More competition is desirable. In this scenario Uber's only advantage is its superior technology and organisation, likely to be short-lived.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question C: Regardless of how ride-sharing services are treated, existing regulations for traditional taxi firms in many European cities harm consumers by limiting competition.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Revising France’s labor market policies — by reducing employment protection, decentralizing labor negotiations to the firm level, and making training programs more accessible and responsive to labor demands — would, all else equal, increase productivity in France’s economy.
Comment: "All else equal" agreed. But it risks triggering further disillusionment with globalization. Accompanying macro stimulus would ease the pain

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Reducing employment protection would reduce the equilibrium unemployment rate in France.
Comment: All else equal again. And the details matter. Something like Danish "flexicurity" would be good, naive deregulation bad.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: The ECB's asset purchases over the past two years have reduced the threat of deflation in the euro area as a whole.
Comment: Reduced but not eliminated. Monetary policy alone cannot get the EU out of deflation, only a rise in external demand or a fiscal stimulus.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: If the economic outlook in the euro area becomes less favorable, then increasing the ECB's asset purchase program (in size or duration) would substantially increase the euro area's economic growth over the following five years.
Comment: "Substantial" Is a big ask, and growth will ultimately be affected more by structural issues and demand-side shocks

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: In general, absent any inside information, an equity investor can expect to do better by holding a well-diversified, low-fee, passive index fund than by holding a few stocks.
Comment: A small industry exists to help naive investors beat the market. It should be subject to mandatory health warnings.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Without changes in policy, a rising share of people who are over age 65 will exert a substantial downward influence on per capita real GDP in western European countries.
Comment: Automation could conceivably offset fall in labor input to population ratio but unlikely

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: In European countries where the share of those over 65 is rising, there are net social benefits to adjusting retirement ages for state-financed (including pay-as-you-go) pension systems upwards, so that revised retirement ages better reflect longer life expectancies.
Comment: Especially if not compulsory, such changes could even be welcomed by increasingly healthy 65-year olds

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: All else equal, there are substantial advantages to having much of Europe’s human capital and infrastructure for international financial activity clustered in a single city, as they are at present in London.
Comment: Local costs (high house prices, inequality) but clear EU-wide gains to agglomeration. Unsustainable outside the Single Market however.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: All else equal, Britain’s rules on hiring, firing and working hours are significantly more conducive to financial activity than those in other large European countries.
Comment: Balance in UK labour markets is more tilted towards employers: ironically this also makes incumbent firms less likely to stay post-Brexit

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Setting the EU rules aside, and assuming it would take 2.5% of Italy’s GDP to recapitalize its banks, the Italian government would improve financial stability in Europe if it injected this amount of public funds into its banks.
Comment: Sooner or later, bullets have to be bitten, zombie banks have to be bailed out. Sooner is better. Exactly how is much harder to answer.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: If Italy were to inject public funds into its banks without imposing losses on at least some claimants, an important cost would be the effect on future incentives (economic or political) in Europe.
Comment: Possibility of moral hazard in medium term versus high probability of financial instability in short term. A tough choice but a clear one.

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: On the whole, the shift from state to private ownership of many industrial assets in central and eastern European countries after communism has increased productivity in those countries.
Comment: Productivity has increased, though in Russia and other countries the distributional consequences have been regressive

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: All the evidence points to migration as improving productivity in host countries, with very small negative effects on displaced workers

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of people to live and work across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: This is definitely a widespread perception, whipped up by populist politicians; but migrants typically bring skills and consume few services

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made the average western European citizen better off since the 1980s.
Comment: Greater integration has led to classical gains from trade through specialization, as well as new gains from exploiting supply chains

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Freer movement of goods and services across borders within Europe has made many low-skilled western European citizens worse off since the 1980s.
Comment: It is not true that many low-skilled workers have lost out, especially considering improved quality and lower prices; but some have lost

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: In general, using more congestion charges in crowded transportation networks — such as higher tolls during peak travel times in cities, and peak fees for airplane takeoff and landing slots — and using the proceeds to lower other taxes would make citizens on average better off.
Comment: Travelling on congested roads, no matter how desirable to the individual, imposes costs on other users which governments should internalise

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Giving tax incentives to specific firms to locate operations in a country typically generates domestic benefits that outweigh the costs to the country providing the incentives.
Comment: Providing information and helping foreign firms cope with bureaucracy are desirable; direct grants are unlikely to match their full costs

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Europe as a whole benefits when European cities or countries compete with each other by giving tax incentives to firms to locate operations in their jurisdictions.
Comment: Competition on services and in providing information is desirable; competition on subsidies and tax breaks risks a race to the bottom

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question A: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the UK's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment:
Definitely a negative impact, though how much depends on how hard is the Brexit and how long the associated uncertainty persists
-see background information here

Name: Peter Neary
Qtext: Question B: Because of the Brexit vote's outcome, the rest of the EU's real per-capita income level is likely to be lower a decade from now than it would have been otherwise.
Comment: Europe is more important to the UK than vice versa, so the effect on the rest of the EU should be less severe though still negative

Name: Philippe Aghion
Qtext: Over the next decade, autonomous cars will raise average welfare in the EU by at least as much as smartphones have over the past decade.

Name: Philippe Aghion
Qtext:
Britain’s Labour party recently proposed giving the Bank of England a target of 3% annual labor productivity growth. Consider the following statement:
Central banks cannot significantly increase productivity growth over a ten year horizon, except perhaps by promoting macroeconomic stability.
